07304.description: Bridge the gap between seniors and children through the love of books. RSVP and AngelaCARES are seeking volunteers age 55+ to read once a week to 1 st graders in PS22. With just one hour a week, you can nurture a lifelong love of reading in a child. Volunteers must be age 55 or over. Contact Stephanie Grove at 973-637-1766 or sgrove@jfsmetrowest.org or Claire Carter-Smith at claire@angelacares.org or 201-685-7273 to sign up today! This program is a collaboration of the Retired & Senior Volunteer Program and AngelaCARES. AngelaCARES, Inc. is a 501(c) (3) nonprofit organization headquartered in Jersey City, NJ. Their mission is to serve as an advocate and support system for senior citizens, their caregivers, and a mentor to the youth by educating and empowering them to volunteer. They are committed to strengthening communities by enhancing the quality of life through the generations. RSVP is a comprehensive community service organization sponsored by Jewish Family Service of MetroWest designed to mobilize members of the community who are 55+ to give back to their own neighborhoods in Essex and Hudson counties through volunteer services.
07304.title: Reading Bridge

07704.description: Protect our environment and the special place in which we live! Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL) wants you! As a volunteer, you’ll be a member of the fastest growing and most effective climate advocacy group. You will work with concerned New Jersey citizens to slow the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our beautiful ecosystems, livelihoods and way of life. Please respond to our posting for an invitation to learn more. You will: Meet with Congressional leaders. Write letters to the editors and op-eds. Meet with local media. Educate your community about global warming and legislative solutions. We provide: Monthly national conference calls with expert guest speakers. Weekly skill building sessions. On-line network with CCL volunteers across the U.S. National conference and lobby week in D.C. Volunteers commit to an average of 4-6 hours a month. Some of our volunteers dedicate more time than that. We hold no upper limit on your dedication to a stable climate and livable world. To learn more about us, please join an Introductory Conference Call. The next call is Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Pacific/6:00 p.m. Mountain/7:00 p.m. Central/8:00 p.m. Eastern. This is an opportunity to learn about CCL. It is one hour, and there will be opportunities to ask questions. The conference call number is 1-866-642-1665, passcode 440699#.
07704.title: Sustainable Climate Environment Advocate Fair Haven NJ

07702.description: VITAS wants to enlist your services to care for terminally ill veterans living at home and in nursing homes, assisted living communities and medical centers. VITAS Veteran Volunteers may or may not be U.S. military veterans themselves. They are trained to meet the specific needs of terminally ill veterans living in their own homes, nursing homes, assisted living communities and veterans’ medical centers. Our Veteran Volunteers visit terminally ill veterans; drive and/or accompany a veteran to appointments, shopping and other events; help a veteran apply for benefits or learn about available assistance; help replace lost or stolen military medals by contacting appropriate agencies; listen to life stories or record or videotape a veteran’s reminiscences; telephone veterans to ask how they are doing; attend or help plan activities celebrating Memorial Day and Veteran’s Day; educate veteran’s groups about hospice services by speaking at their meetings. Volunteer orientation teaches the skills required to be a hospice volunteer. VITAS Veteran Volunteers are further trained to meet specific end-of-life needs of veterans to improve their quality of life. Time and dates are ongoing and flexible. Orientation and training to be a VITAS Veteran Volunteer is free. Veterans enjoy receiving visitors-people who will listen to their fading memories and reminiscences. Some veterans need transportation to appointments, shopping and other events. Others need help applying for benefits or researching other kinds of assistance. VITAS Veteran Volunteers learn to help. Show a veteran that he or she is not forgotten. For more information about VITAS visit VITAS.com.
07702.title: Be all You can Be as a Veteran Volunteer
07702.org: VITAS Healthcare of New Jersey Shore

07702.description: VITAS is looking for caring individuals to share their voice and time as Telephone Assurance Program (TAP) Volunteers to help terminally ill patients and their families. TAP is a program in which in home hospice patients (and their family members) receive \"check-in\" phone calls by VITAS TAP Volunteers. If you enjoy talking on the phone and have time to make a few phone calls, you may be a perfect TAP Volunteer. Volunteers work from their own homes or from the VITAS office, checking on VITAS patients in their homes. TAP Volunteers inquire about how patients and families are doing, provide grief support or simply listen. VITAS Volunteer orientation is provided free of charge to help you learn the skills required to be an outstanding TAP Volunteer. Time and dates are ongoing and flexible. For more information about VITAS visit VITAS.com.
07702.title: It’s Your Calling…Check-in on Hospice Patients and Families
07702.org: VITAS Healthcare of New Jersey Shore

07702.description: VITAS Healthcare(r) is looking for kind and caring massage therapists to pamper hospice patients living at home, in the hospital or in long term care facilities. A terminally ill patient’s sense of isolation is often made worse by the lack of comforting human touch. Muscles may be contracted and stiff. Patients may spend their days immobile in a recliner or bed. Knowledgeable massage therapists can offer compassionate touch, relaxation, a sense of well being and emotional health. For the volunteer, getting to know someone at the end of life is a gift in itself. All VITAS volunteers receive orientation in end-of-life care. VITAS massage-therapy volunteers must have a current massage license. This is a great opportunity for you to give back to the community. By taking time out of your busy work week you can make the biggest difference in another’s life. VITAS takes pride in its volunteers, and we welcome you to become part of our team. There are many locations throughout the area you can choose from. Your commitment is completely up to you, whether you spend one day a week or one day a month. Your time is always appreciated. For more information about VITAS visit VITAS.com.
07702.title: Promote Relaxation to Hospice Patients with Massage Therapy
07702.org: VITAS Healthcare of New Jersey Shore

07702.description: VITAS Healthcare(r) is looking for musical volunteers who are able to play musical instruments and/or sing for hospice patients living at home, in the hospital or in long term care facilities. Sometimes what a hospice patient needs most is a way to express feelings without talking. By playing or singing their favorite songs or hymns, VITAS music volunteers help patients and families reconnect with feelings and memories that can bring about a sense of peace and happiness. VITAS provides training on how to work with people at the end of life. The volunteer provides the talent, compassion and time. Assignments are made according to the volunteer’s time and location. For more information about VITAS visit VITAS.com.
07702.title: Volunteer to bring Harmony and Happiness to Hospice Patients
07702.org: VITAS Healthcare of New Jersey Shore

07702.description: Administrative volunteers promote hospice care by helping perform clerical assignments in an office setting. These assignments can include helping process mail outs, filing, data entry, answering phones, restocking supplies, making packets, plus many other tasks. VITAS Volunteer orientation is provided free of charge to help you learn the skills required to be an outstanding Office Volunteer. Volunteers are needed between the hours of 8am and 5pm, Monday through Friday. For more information about VITAS visit VITAS.com.
07702.title: Help Provide Clerical Duties in Hospice Office
07702.org: VITAS Healthcare of New Jersey Shore

07702.description: VITAS invites friendly and well-behaved pets to join the Paw Pals SM program, in which animals and their humans learn how to visit patients at the end of life. A registered VITAS Paw Pals SM visitor can offer comfort, bring back memories, encourage activity and provide unconditional love to VITAS patients. Your visits leave behind memories of you and your pet, and rekindle thoughts of other pets. All kinds of pets are invited to join VITAS’ Paw Pals Club. Pet visits can sometimes reach a patient when no one else can. Our Paw Pals SM brightens the day for everyone when they visit. Paw Pals SM must be well-groomed, at least one- year old, and have up-to-date health records. For more information about VITAS visit VITAS.com.
07702.title: Pet Volunteers needed to Lick away Loneliness or Cuddle in a Lap or Make a "Dog-Gone" Difference in
07702.org: VITAS Healthcare of New Jersey Shore

07702.description: VITAS is looking for kind and caring people to help terminally ill patients and their families. Friendly visits, simple errands, providing a listening ear and the gift of friendship at a crucial time can make a real difference in another's life. Yours, too! Other VITAS volunteer activities: relief care (sit with a patient while the caregiver takes a break); friendly visits to patients and their families at home or in a nursing home; driving a patient or family member to appointments; accompanying a patient to a church function, wedding, beauty shop, play, ballgame; run errands to the grocery store, drug store, post office; assist with programs and special events. VITAS Volunteer orientation is provided free of charge to help you learn the skills required to be an outstanding hospice volunteer. Time and dates are ongoing and flexible. For more information about VITAS visit VITAS.com.
07702.title: Provide Friendly Visits to Hospice Patients and their Families
07702.org: VITAS Healthcare of New Jersey Shore

10028.description: You must be a Gujarati Folk Singer or Musician.
10028.title: GUJARATI FOLK MUSICIANS WANTED

10028.description: This opportunity is available every Saturday & Sunday from 7 PM-7:30 PM! Rescuing Leftover Cuisine is a nonprofit food rescue organization dedicated to reducing food waste and feeding the hungry. We are currently looking for Lead Rescuers to join our leadership team. A Lead Rescuer is a passionate and dedicated volunteer who commits to leading one event, once per week. Training is provided. Help rescue delicious leftover organic food and juices that would otherwise have been thrown away and bring it to those who need it the most! You will pick up food donations from a popular organic food cafe and deliver it on-foot to a nearby homeless shelter. Lightweight: the average amount of food is a total of 15 lbs.
10028.title: Weekly Volunteer Needed for 7PM-7:30PM Weekend UES Food Rescue Events!

10028.description: Anjellicle Cats Rescue, Inc. is seeking a volunteer Medical Coordinator. This person is the main point of contact for all of our fosters and recent adopters when the cats in their care have medical issues or need to schedule routine veterinary care. This position is handled primarily through email correspondence with some limited phone communication. The ideal candidate would be local to NYC, but this is flexible for the right person. Duties: Answer emails. This is the biggest part of the job. The medical coordinator responds to questions about vaccinations, records, illnesses, vet appointments, spay and neuter, etc. Update PetPoint (our online records system) with any vet visits, spay/neuter, etc. There are also a handful of Google Docs and online document storage ( Box.com) used for this position. Call vets during business hours to approve appointments, request records, etc. Generally about 10 minutes per day are spent on the phone, sometimes more if other things are needed. Basic Requirements and Time Commitment: The volunteer should have the ability to check the account every few hours and respond to any urgent emails. Many emails can be answered on a mobile phone if desired. Reliable access to a computer -- at least two hours per day to look up information or update online records. We prefer someone who readily has computer access throughout the day, but it is possible to do computer work in one session per day if other emails are answered as they come in. Proficiency with email is a MUST. This position involves a high volume of email. The medical coordinator must be comfortable with spelling, grammar and standards of professional correspondence. Time and ability to call vet offices during regular business hours. Familiar with Google Docs is a plus, but this can be trained. Desired Qualifications: Experience working with a cat rescue or animal shelter is a plus. Experience with cat care and illness, including kittens and their medical needs. (Specific medical knowledge can be learned on the job. There will be other staff members who can help.) Diplomatic multi-tasker who will remain calm and professional in difficult situations. Comfortable with customer service. Benefits: Our medical coordinator is a key member of our all-volunteer staff. This is a great opportunity to get involved with one of the most active cat rescues in NYC as we are about to celebrate our 10-year anniversary. The medical coordinator will attend bi-monthly core staff meetings and will have the opportunity to contribute to many aspects of the workings of our nonprofit organization. Your work will also have a direct impact on the lives of hundreds of rescued cats in foster and adoptive homes. To apply or inquire about this position, email info@anjelliclecats.com. We would like to fill this position by August 15, but we will continue to review applications after that date.
10028.title: Medical Coordinator Needed -- Anjellicle Cats Rescue

10029.description: We're looking for several people to volunteer with our Meals on Wheels program on Saturday, February 25th! We welcome both individual volunteers and small groups. For over 40 years, Union Settlement has provided Meals on Wheels to East Harlem's older residents that are often economically struggling and living alone. Our Meals on Wheels program currently serves approximately 450 homebound seniors each day, and as of May 31, 2016, we have provided 143,313 meals to homebound seniors. Prior to the volunteer date, volunteers will be sent a short training video and brief quiz to help prepare them for participation with Meals on Wheels. Volunteers will help pack hot and cold meals and then join staff on deliveries where they will get to hand out meals to our clients and interact with the East Harlem community. When: Saturday, Feb. 25th from 9am to 12:30pm Where: Jefferson Senior Center, 2205 First Avenue (at E. 113th St.) Interested individuals or groups should email volunteers@unionsettlement.org with the subject line \"Saturday, Feb. 25th Meals on Wheels Volunteer\".
10029.title: Volunteer with Meals on Wheels on Saturday, Feb. 25th!

10029.description: 5 volunteers are needed to read a story chosen by the teachers to a group of students or a class. After reading the story, the guest reader engages the class in a discussion about the book.
10029.title: P.S. 182 Guest Reader Thursday!

10029.description: We're excited to announce that our 19th annual Concern Spring Run will take place on Saturday, April 8th, 2017 at 9:30am in Central Park! The Concern Spring Run is a grassroots fundraiser here in NYC. Starting in 1998, the run has grown to welcome over 1,000 participants who run, jug, or walk the 4 mile course in Central Park. All funds raised enable us to continue helping those living in extreme poverty acheive major inprovements in their lives. We are lucky to have such a great team here in our NYC office but we can't do it without the help of our amazing volunteers! Today we are asking for your help to ensure that the Concern Spring Run can once again be a success. Email us with the following details if you are interested in volunteering: 1. Name: 2. Email: 3. Cell Phone #: 4. School or company: 5. Have you volunteered at the Spring Run before? If so, when? 6. Will you be volunteering alone or with a group? If with a group, please provide the number of individuals and their contact details.
10029.title: Volunteer for Concern's 2017 Spring Run in Central Park!

10029.description: We need an Office Assitant to help our in various LSA programs, inlcuding Development and also our Early Childhood program. Help with a multitude of tasks to help support our Development Office and/or Early Childhood Parent and Child Development program. Duties may include organizing projects, assist as may be needed in a very busy office environment that support parents at children at the LSA Family Health Service. Computer skills not necessary; just need someone who likes to help out as needed in a busy office environment. Hours: flexible: 2 - 3 hours two days a week. Please contact the Volutneer Director for more details tgough@lsafhs.org
10029.title: Office Helper Needed!

10029.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10029.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child(East Harlem Tutorial Program, Manhattan)

10029.description: Urgent! We need caring, responsible Child Care volunteers to assist with toddlers (age 15 months - 3 years old) while their mothers are in counseling sessions or counseling groups. Times available: Thursdays 9 - 12 am; also 4 hours flexible during the rest of the week. Must enjoy working with toddlers, engaging in developmental play.
10029.title: URGENT: Child Care Volunteers Needed!

10029.description: Join New York Common Pantry's Hot Meals program in it's fight to end hunger! Every week day morning, we serve a healthy hot breakfast to 200 food insecure guests. All of our meals are cooked in our kitchen on site, our staff cook prepares hearty balanced meals with whole some ingredients. Our dining room offers participants a chance to eat, sit, and socialize in a relaxing, safe, friendly atmosphere that offers a retreat from the tension of being homelewss or living in poverty. To serve breakfast we need your help on Monday or Tuesday from 7:30 to 9:30 am distributing tray, serving hot or cold food and drinks, collecting guest information, replenishing supplies, and washing dishes.
10029.title: Help Serve Breakfast at New York Common Pantry

10029.description: Are you a certified fitness instructor looking to give back to your community? Shape Up New York is a free fitness program for all ages and is looking for Fitness instructors like you in the Queens area. Volunteer opportunities are available for a variety of classes and activities, including zumba, yoga and pilates. Volunteers must have some experience as a fitness instructor, and once accepted, will have the opportunity to shadow a current instructor before leading their own classes. This position offers flexibility and creativity for enthusiastic volunteers interested in giving back to their communities and addressing pressing health issues such as Diabetes and Obesity.
10029.title: Fitness Instructors Needed in Queens

10029.description: Would you be willing to spend some time each week doing something fun and fulfilling- especially if you knew it would change a child’s life forever? We are looking for older adults 50+ to work one-on-one with a student, grades K-3, who needs help developing reading and language skills during the course of the academic year. If you're interested in being a tutor and mentor to a East Harlem student, please email us at volunteers@unionsettlement.org for more information! Volunteers must attend 3 orientation/training sessions. Schedule is below: Part 1: Tuesday, February 14, 2017, 10:00 am - 2:00 pm Part 2: Thursday, February 16, 2017, 10:00 am - 2:00 pm Part 3: Friday, February 17, 2017, 10:00 am - 2:00 pm (All 3 training sessions are required. Lunch will be provided each day)
10029.title: Volunteer with our Intergenerational Tutoring Program!

10029.description: Looking for volunteers looking to learn how to coach basketball and to help professional coaching staff with growing our program in the city.
10029.title: Volunteers needed for youth basketball program in Manhattan

10029.description: Harlem RBI, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer tutors to provide academic support to middle school students in East Harlem and the South Bronx start in the fall of 2016. Tutors work with youth individually and in small groups to help improve student success in class, increase subject-specific retention, and contribute to overall academic development. What You'll Do Lead weekly tutoring sessions supported by staff and volunteers; Support participants with homework completion in a middle school subject of your choice, including: English, Math, Science, and Social Studies; Serve as a role model and build positive relationships with youth; What We're Looking For Strong command of one or more of the following academic subjects: English, Math, Science, and/or Social Studies Previous experience working with youth; Possess creativity, enthusiasm and patience; Solid oral communication skills; Ability to make a consistent, weekly commitment; Bachelor's Degree (a plus). 1-2 years previous tutoring experience (a plus); 1-2 years teaching experience (a major plus); Benefits Gain invaluable experience and opportunities for professional development at an award winning youth development program; Receive an optional professional reference upon completion of your service term; Join an incredible community of passionate staff and volunteers. Hours: At least one 2 hour to 2.5 hour session per week, Monday-Thursday. Times vary between 4:00pm and 6:30pm, based on youth/volunteer availability and program schedule. Commitment: At least 3 months, beginning in fall of 2016. Harlem RBI provides equal opportunity for all volunteers. Apply here: http://careers.harlemrbi.org/careers/position/volunteer-tutor-east-harlem-ny
10029.title: Make A Difference- Tutor A Middle School Student!

10029.description: Harlem RBI, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer tutors to provide subject-specific academic support to our middle school students in East Harlem and the South Bronx. Tutors work with youth individually and in small groups to help improve student success in class, increase subject-specific retention, and contribute to overall academic development. What You’ll Do Lead weekly tutoring sessions supported by staff and volunteers; Support participants with homework completion in a middle school subject of your choice, including: English, Math, Science, and Social Studies; Serve as a role model and build positive relationships with youth; What We’re Looking For Strong command of one or more of the following academic subjects: English, Math, Science, and/or Social Studies Previous experience working with youth; Possess creativity, enthusiasm and patience; Solid oral communication skills; Ability to make a consistent, weekly commitment; Bachelor’s Degree (a plus). 1-2 years previous tutoring experience (a plus); 1-2 years teaching experience (a major plus); Benefits Gain invaluable experience and opportunities for professional development at an award winning youth development program; Receive an optional professional reference upon completion of your service term; Join an incredible community of passionate staff and volunteers. Hours: At least one 2 hour to 2.5 hour session per week, Monday-Thursday. Times vary between 4:00pm and 6:30pm, based on youth/volunteer availability and program schedule. Commitment: At least 3 months. Harlem RBI provides equal opportunity for all volunteers. Apply here: http://careers.harlemrbi.org/careers/position/volunteer-tutor-east-harlem-ny
10029.title: Volunteer Tutor

10029.description: Harlem RBI, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer coaches to work with youth between the ages of 11-18 in practices and games. Coaches teach baseball/softball and provide youth with opportunities to play, learn, and grow, inspiring them to recognize their potential and realize their dreams. Each coach serves as a member of a team made up of coaches and managers. Harlem RBI volunteer coaches can have a direct and meaningful impact on the positive development of the youth they coach. The ideal candidate is passionate about youth development, has played and/or coached baseball/softball, and is an effective communicator. Roles and Responsibilities * Coach youth in technical skills, teambuilding and personal development; * Lead practices, facilitate team meetings and attend professional development trainings; * Provide a positive, team-based environment focused on teaching baseball, softball and life skills; * Attend 1 weeknight practice and 1 weekend game each week during the season. Qualifications * Passionate about youth development; * Understanding of the power of teamwork; * Ability to create a positive, team-based environment focused on teaching baseball/softball; * Organizational skills, energy and flexibility; * Solid oral communication skills; * Ability to commit to the coaching position for at least one full season; * Baseball/Softball playing or coaching experience for ages 13 and up; * Experience with inner-city coaching (a plus); * At least 18 years of age. Hours Time commitment varies by age group but is generally 4-8 hours/week. Practices (weeknights) typically last 1.5 hours and games (weekends) last between 2-5 hours. The coaching staff of a Harlem RBI team consists of up to five adult volunteers: a manager and four coaches.
10029.title: Volunteer Baseball and Softball Coach

10029.description: Want to help make your community healthier? Volunteer to be a fitness instructor for Shape Up NYC! Shape Up organizes free fitness classes across New York City, particularly in neighborhoods with high rates of obesity and diabetes. We are looking for a dedicated fitness instructors to teach a Tai Chi class in Queens. Volunteers must be certified in Tai Chi group fitness and, once accepted, will have the opportunity to shadow a current instructor before leading their own classes.
10029.title: Tai Chi Instructor Needed in

10029.description: Do you enjoy interacdting with young toddlers? We need Classroom Aides for our Early Childhood Parent and Child Development Program, which is a classroom setting for moms and toddlers. Volunteer will interact with moms/toddlers to support an interacdtive learning setting. Art activities, musica activities and other activities serve to support the leanring needs of the child and foster bonding between parent and child. Hours needed: 3 sessions a day available between Monday and Friday: 9:30 - 11:30 am 12:30 - 2:30 pm 3:00 - 5:00 pm Bilingual helpful, but not necessary.
10029.title: URGENT! We need Classrooms Aides for our Early Childhood Socialization Program

10029.description: Join one of our early childhood day care programs as a volunteer! We are looking for individuals with outgoing personalities who can welcome children and their parents when they enter the building. Volunteers will also monitor the lobby area, direct children and parents to the right classroom or office, and assist the early childhood staff with administrative tasks. This volunteer opportunity is during the week from 3pm to 5pm. Those interested in applying should contact Cristina Valbuena-Castor at cvalbuenacastor@unionsettlement.org. An application will need to be filled out and a background check and fingerprinting conducted.
10029.title: Volunteer Assistant with Early Childhood Program

10029.description: The Carter Burden Center for the Aging (CBCA) is dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their homes living independently, safely, and with dignity. Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Center’s 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBCA can accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. Every month, over 150 seniors benefit from the food pantry in partnership with the New York Common Pantry. While we organize a distribution on site at the Carter Burden/Leonard Covello Senior Program, we also facilitate the process for the seniors who are unable to come to the main site to pick up their bags of food. Volunteers will facilitate pantry operations by: Packing about 150 small bags of food with different types of items depending on the shopping list. The pantry goods may include juice, milk, cans, cereals etc. All the items are delivered in the morning by the NY Common Pantry and a room is set up to pack the bags and organize different stations. Loading the bags of food into our van to be delivered to another senior center. This project takes place the 1st Wednesday of the month at our Adult Social Day Program located at 301A East 99th Street, New York, NY 10029. Volunteers are needed for a two hour shift from 9am to 10-30am. They should be able to lift 12-15 pounds. A Volunteer Coordinator is on site to coordinate the volunteers. This volunteer opportunity is adapted for groups (up to 10 people). Individuals or smaller groups are also welcomed. If you are interested in this volunteer opportunity, please contact us at: volunteer@carterburdencenter.org
10029.title: Food Pantry Volunteers
10029.org: The Carter Burden Center for the Aging

10029.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for volunteer tutors to provide academic support to Harlem RBI's after school program. You would be supporting middle school students with their homework during their study group hours, once a week, any day between Monday-Thursday from 4PM-6PM, or twice a week from 4-5PM or 5-6PM. As a tutor, you will have the chance to work with a small group and collaborate with the site coordinator to improve the program as a whole. To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor. Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have received a degree recently. Be willing to complete 11.5 hours of College Reading and Learning Aligned (CRLA) training at City College of New York. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Spring semester. We can accommodate your schedule for the training sessions. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having tutors in these sessions early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about Harlem RBI here: http://www.harlemrbi.org/
10029.title: Support Middle School Students with Their Homework at Harlem RBI

10029.description: Are you a piano player who would like to play on our beautiful baby grand piano in the hospital lobby? We are looking for volunteers to play every day, once a week, or once a month (Monday - Friday between 9AM and 6PM). It is a wonderful experience, between a practice room and a concert hall! The music will be enjoyed by patients, families, visitors and staff members, and you will bring joy to the environment. A prerequisite is a one-time audition.
10029.title: Hospital Piano Player

10029.description: Go the extra mile with Back on My Feet NYC's Team Bowery North! Dedicated teams of volunteers run 2-4 miles with our members who are transitioning out of homelessness. We encourage runners of all speeds to become a part of our community! Team Bowery North meets at 315 E 115th St. every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 5:45-6:45AM. To find out more and sign up for an orientation, visit nyc.backonmyfeet.org/nyc-run-with-us
10029.title: East Harlem Morning Runner

10029.description: The Carter Burden Center for the Aging (CBCA) is dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their homes living independently, safely, and with dignity. Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Center's 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBCA can accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. We're looking for compassionate, patient, and committed people to visit with seniors on a regular basis. The Friendly Visiting program matches volunteers with seniors who share common interests and hobbies for social interaction. Volunteers participate in visits at least twice a month (for 1-2 hours) in a senior's home and may chat, play a game, read a book, take a walk (if the senior is able), or another activity. Seniors are located on the Upper East Side and East Harlem. The Friendly Visiting program is an on-going opportunity. Time is flexible but we are looking for volunteers available on weekdays (preferably in the afternoons) and weekends. If you are interested in this opportunity, please email us at: volunteer@carterburdencenter.org
10029.title: Friendly Visiting with Seniors
10029.org: The Carter Burden Center for the Aging

10029.description: The PACT (Preventable Admissions Care Team) Volunteer Program utilizes volunteers to assist with essential, non-clinical tasks; allowing PACT workers to focus on a patient’s clinical needs. Tasks include, but are not limited to: Researching community resources for patients Scheduling appointments and transportation Performing telephone advocacy on patient behalf in regards to community resources and entitlements as identified and explained by the PACT Social Worker Making appointment reminder calls to patients Going on runs to pharmacy or other stores to purchase items for patients Calling insurance companies and pharmacies to verify benefits Performing clerical tasks - faxing, making copies Referring patients to community resources such as Access-A-Ride and Meals on Wheels Please note there is a minimum commitment of 8 hours/week. Additionally, the PACT office is not open on weekends, therefore only weekdays shifts available. Please contact PACT.VolunteerCoordinators@mountsinai.org if you are interested in joining the PACT Volunteer Program. Thank you!
10029.title: Help individuals at high risk for hospitalization, join the PACT Volunteers Partners at Mount Sinai
10029.org: Mount Sinai Hospital: Social Work Department

10029.description: Want to help make your community healthier? Volunteer to be a fitness instructor for Shape Up NYC! Shape Up organizes free fitness classes across New York City, particularly in neighborhoods with high rates of obesity and diabetes. We are looking for a dedicated fitness instructors to teach a Yoga class in Queens. Volunteers must be certified in yoga/group fitness and, once accepted, will have the opportunity to shadow a current instructor before leading their own classes.
10029.title: Yoga Instructor needed in Queens

10029.description: We have an urgent need for after school Home Work Help volunteers to assist school aged East Harlem children in our after school Home Work Help program. You can volunteer on either Tuesdays from 5 - 6 pm or Thursdays from 5 - 6 pm. We have a group of 25 children who receive tutoring twice a week and who come twice a week with their homework. You might assist one child during the entire session or additional children as may be needed. The children in this program are children who cannot always receive help from their parents with their homework; and so this program is very important for their school success. You can do one or both sessions a week. Please contact the Volunteer Director at tgough@lsafhs.org Thank you for your consideration!
10029.title: URGENT!  Home Work Help Volunteers Needed!

10029.description: Shape Up NYC is a free citywide fitness program operated by NYC Parks, in partnership with Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield and NYC Service that provides more than 300 free group exercise classes each week at 175 locations across the five boroughs. Want to help make your community healthier? Volunteer to be a fitness instructor for Shape Up NYC! Shape Up organizes free fitness classes across New York City, particularly in neighborhoods with high rates of obesity and diabetes. We are looking for dedicated fitness instructors who would be willing to run classes in the NYC area. Volunteers must have some experience as a fitness instructor, and once accepted, will have the opportunity to shadow a current instructor before leading their own classes. This position offers flexibility and creativity for enthusiastic volunteers interested in giving back to their communities and addressing pressing health issues. Purpose: Shape Up Volunteers are dedicated fitness instructors who teach group exercise classes in neighborhoods across all five boroughs, especially those with high rates of obesity and diabetes. They are interested in giving back to their communities and have an understanding of urban health issues, working with diverse populations, and community outreach. Location: City-wide Key Responsibilities: Conduct group fitness classes (safe/fun). Report attendance weekly. Time Commitment: One hour, once a week. For a least 6 months. Certification or Education Requirements: Currently certified in fitness instruction by one or more of the following: ACE, ACSM, AFAA, NASM or any other accredited health and fitness certifying organization (i.e. Zumba, Pilates, Yoga, PiYo...) A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university in the health field such as human performance, sports medicine, exercise physiology, kinesiology or other health related concentrations are a plus. Required skills: Effective communication, fitness leadership, group instruction. Benefits: Enthusiastic and supportive atmosphere. Opportunity to give back to the community. Applicable Skills: Fitness, Sports Medicine, exercise, physiology, public health
10029.title: Certified Group Fitness Instructor for Shape Up NYC!

10029.description: El Taller is looking for volunteers to help out during our concerts and events. Tasks include collecting money at the door, letting people into the space, setting up chairs, taking donations at the wine bar, and cleaning up after the show. Meet interesting people and hear world-class live music for free!
10029.title: Concerts and Special Events at El Taller Latino Americano

10029.description: As we are currently facing very difficult budget cuts in New York State, our Food Pantry which serves East Harlem children and families is experiencing a dramatic reduction of donations. Our shelves are barely stocked. If you work for an organization that might be interested in hosting a Food Drive, please be in touch (646) 672-0434. Canned food, dry goods, and other practical foodstuffs are most needed. We can pick up at any site in New York City. Thank you for remembering our most vulnerable New Yorkers!!
10029.title: Can Your Organization host a Food Drive for our Food Pantry?

10029.description: URGENT NEED! Help us help the neediest students in New York City! ! We need caring, committed after school Tutors for our After School Tutoring Program. WE HAVE A WAITING LIST FOR CHILDREN FOR THIS PROGRAM, AS WE NEED VOLUNTEER TUTORS. ONLY NEED ONE MORE TUTOR! MONDAYS FROM 3:30 - 4:30 You will tutor one-on-one a child in grades K- 3 who struggles with reading and writing at grade level. Most of the children are children of immigrants and English is not spoken at home, so they struggle with English reading and writing at school. Tutoring begins mid October and continues through the spring sememster (until June 2017). Please help an East Harlem child! Tutoring makes all the difference for our children -- the difference between success and failure in school. If you would like to volunteer, please email your resume to tgough@lsafhs.org
10029.title: URGENT!!  We Need Just One More Tutor - for Mondays, for East Harlem Children!

10029.description: The Ambassador Volunteer Program welcomes patients, families and visitors as they enter the Hospital and escorts them to their destination. The hours are Monday -Friday from 8AM - 5:00 PM. Mount Sinai is large and there are 12 buildings most of which are connected by a main corridor (underground) level. The Ambassadors help patients, families, and visitors figure out where they have to go (through Ipad technology and skills we teach them) and then escort them there. We ask Ambassadors to serve at least one 3 hour session per week. We have an orientation and then pair new Ambassadors up with an experienced Ambassador. It is an excellent opportunity to improve your communication skills, learn what it is like to be part of a large healthcare organization, find out how gratifying it is to help others, and become a more active person. If you are kind, compassionate, willing to walk throughout the Hospital, and like to help people we can teach you to be an Ambassador!
10029.title: Mount Sinai Volunteer Ambassador

10029.description: Do you work for a company that wants to assist underpriviliged children in New York City? Here are some ways you can help: 1) Your company can host a Toy or Book Drive for children in our programs. We are always in need for educational toys and books for children ages 0 - 12. (we can pick up donations as needed). Our Holiday Program for Families is always in need of new clothing/toys/books for children, especially as gifts for the holidays. 2) Your company can host a Party for children at your office - a great \"team building\" activity for your company and a great way for our children to enjoy an outing and interaction with caring adults. Activities typically include an activity, i.e. art or craft making, and treats (food/snacks). Activity can also be at a local restaurant, or an educational or cultural venue. 3) Your company can work with children at our center for a \"team building\" activity - for example, a 1.5 hour arts and crafts activity or outdoor sports activity are just a couple of ways your group can connect with East Harlem children in our programs. Contact the Volunteer Director for more information. 3) Your company can sponsor a summer trip for our children (to NY state parks, beaches, the Bronx zoo, etc.). For more information about how your company can participate in an activity with our East Harlem children, please contact the Volunteer Director at LSA Family Health Service (646) 672-0434 or email at tgough@lsafhs.org.
10029.title: Corporate Sponsorship Needed for Special Events for East Harlem Children

10029.description: If you like thrift shops, you'll love the Sharing Place thrift shop. The Sharing Place offers high quality goods at very low prices for members of the East Harlem community. We need help in sorting and pricing clothes, helping customers, helping to decorate/set up store. We also need a volunteer who can assist with administrative tasks; i.e. help with thank you letters to donors, or helping to organize special store sales for the community.
10029.title: Thrift Shop Helpers Needed!

10027.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. Through our innovative programs, accomplished authors lead workshops in high-needs classrooms, where they guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. No experience or training is necessary to work with pre-K-12 students. As a writing, research or art coach, you'll engage and encourage their progress on a project. This workshop needs your support at a school in Harlem: Program 1542TH-PB Wednesday, March 1st, 2017 11:30 AM - 1:00 PM Research Coach Second graders read The Bear Report by Thyra Heder, the story of Sophie, a young girl who befriends a polar bear named Olafur who teaches her about his home and life in the Arctic. Assisted by research coaches, students will gather facts about an animal of their choice from provided resources. For details about other Behind the Book programs around the city, visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new volunteer opportunities, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10027.title: Inspire Harlem, NYC public school students to love reading

10027.description: Inspire NYC public school students to love reading Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. Through our innovative programs, accomplished authors lead workshops in high-needs classrooms, where they guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. No experience or training is necessary to work with pre-K-12 students. As a writing, research or art coach, you'll engage and encourage their progress on a project. This workshop needs your support at an elementary school in Harlem: Program 1542TH-PB Wednesday, March 8th, 2017 11:30 AM - 1:00 PM Writing Coach Second graders read The Bear Report by Thyra Heder, the story of Sophie, a young girl who befriends a polar bear named Olafur who teaches her about his home and life in the Arctic. Writing coaches will help them edit and polish the final drafts of their research reports about an animal of their choice.
10027.title: Inspire Harlem, NYC public school students to love reading

10027.description: The Harlem Arts Festival (HAF) works to continue Harlem's legacy of making art that preserves the history and develops the identity of the neighborhood. HAF provides resources, visibility, and career opportunities to Harlem-based artists, and increases participation in the arts by the Harlem community through year-round events, culminating in our free, weekend-long festival in Marcus Garvey Park in June. Check out our website http://www.harlemartsfestival.com/ to learn more about what HAF does. Our annual gala is HAF's second biggest event of the year, and we need your help! This is one of our major fundraising events, and its success is crucial to our ability to carry out our mission to support the incredible talents of Harlem artists. This year's gala will take place on Thursday, March 30 at the Riverside Church Assembly Hall in Harlem. We're looking for volunteers to give a few hours of their time to help us pull off the big event. Things volunteers might do include checking in guests, liaising with the performers, collecting night-of donations, and encouraging guests to bid on auction items. The dress code is semi-formal, and volunteers will receive dinner and opportunities for breaks. So if you can spare a bit of your time, come help make this year's HAF gala a smashing success. And of course, everyone at HAF is immensely thankful for whatever time you can give!
10027.title: Harlem Arts Festival - gala volunteers needed!

10027.description: We're looking for instructors who have the ability, fluidity, and patience to work with students in grades 6, 7, and 8 with instruction on app development, website development, robotics, or game development. You will be on the cutting edge of teaching computer science concepts, as less than 10% of New York City and Northern New Jersey public schools has a computer science curriculum! What's more, 10% of US schools have a computer science curriculum. You will utilize the existing creativity that already exists within the spirits of children, as well as their knack for apps and video games, and channel this energy into supporting them in learning wireframing, weibsite, app & game development. We operate within an afterschool model, in that schools and community based organizations utilize our expertise to provide quality programming to their students and program participants. Your schedule and availability will be matched with the school or community-based afterschool program. If you are into Scratch, Arduino, JAVA, or HTML, this is a PLUS. Come contribute your mastery to increase the interest in STEM in our students in Harlem!
10027.title: Scratch, HTML, JAVA Instructors Needed - NYC!

10027.description: Position: The Admissions Intern is a part-time position handling tasks associated with recruiting, screening and admitting students into the HEAF program for our two program sites. Intern will be trained and placed at program headquarters in Manhattan, and report to HEAF’s Manager of Admissions & Community Relations. Intern’s weekly hours range from 10-15 hours per week depending on designated weekly work levels. Program & Administrative Duties Include: Orient, and support prospective students participating in the Admissions process. Help plan Admissions special events (e.g. Open Houses, Appreciation Events, and Special Tours). Collect and maintain student information, including application and other supplemental materials (such as report cards). Prepare written weekly Admissions status reports on received applications, interviewed candidates and accepted students. Design and update Admissions collateral. Use technology (including, but not limited to, email, databases) as means of engaging in communications with prospective families and HEAF staff. Serve as a flexible team member and provide perform other related tasks as deemed necessary by the organization. Qualifications College students in education, social work or related field encouraged to apply. High School diploma and two additional years of volunteer or youth management experience may be considered. Motivated self-starter and team player with strong interpersonal and communication skills, both oral and written, and a positive attitude. Ability to set clear goals and follow through with flexible and creative problem solving. Conceptual ability for the larger perspective with a strong attention to detail and ability to multitask. Working knowledge of computer and internet-based programs for use in communication, data entry and research. (e.g. using Microsoft Software (Word, Excel, and PowerPoint)). Compensation and Benefits This position is unpaid
10027.title: Admissions Volunteer Intern

10027.description: Current Projects Assist in Finance Department Enter incoming invoices into QuickBooks Prepare monthly and weekly reports Assist in managing accounting and record keeping systems in QuickBooks Assist in Reconciliation of business account with American Express on a monthly basis. Assist in Generating, monitoring, and reviewing financial transactions ensuring accuracy and appropriateness. These include Check requests (payments of all vendor invoices), Petty Cash, and Reimbursements. Assist with weekly bank deposits Required Skills 4 year accounting Degree Microsoft Excel Volunteer Benefits Gain & expand new skills. Support HEAF staff in their work. Learn about the internal processes of a non-profit. Receive academic credit if applicable. Expand your professional network. Be part of a lively, dedicated, caring, and passionate team. Location: HEAF’s offices (2090 7 th Avenue, 10 th Floor, New York NY 10027) Supervising Staff: Deirdre Bennett & Shatia Mckinnon (Finance & Administration Team) Time Commitment: (24 hours per week) Documents Necessary Online volunteer application: ______ Background check: _______ Confidentiality form: ______
10027.title: Finance Volunteer

10027.description: The Food Pantry Volunteer will help sort food products for assembling; preparing food packages according to a pre-selected menus. Assist in the delivery of food packages in the seniors building. This project is in the Manhattan and Brooklyn area.
10027.title: Food Pantry Volunteer

10027.description: Researchers at Teachers College, Columbia University are seeking adolescents and young adults (ages 12-19 years) to participate in a study aimed at understanding different patterns of thoughts and feelings experienced throughout this developmental period. We are recruiting adolescents with diverse backgrounds, some who have been depressed or had thoughts of hurting themselves, and some who have never had these thoughts. Adolescent participation involves one laboratory visit involving computer tasks, interviews, and a self-report packet Eligible participants will be compensated at the end of the visit Parent consent is required for adolescents under 18 years If interested, please call 212-678-7487 or email lcds@tc.columbia.edu with your child to see if he/she qualifies for participation. Adolescents under 18 years must complete this phone screen in the presence of a parent.
10027.title: Tweens and Teens for Well-Being Study

10027.description: Do you have a love for Science and engaging in hands-on science activities with students? Do you enjoy speaking with students about what you do? Then join us at least once, or frequent our STEM Kids NYC Science Cafe that will open on alternate Fridays throughout the year. In this cafe, which will be run mostly by the students, you'll have the opportunity to share your love for Science and engage with them on a hands-on activity that supports what you do for a living, or some other area in Science you have a penchant for. Don't worry about teaching! You'll receive all the support you need from us who will develop the lessson plan around your expertise, and be there with you to help facilitate the sessions. Your presence and contribution of mastery is invaluable in helping students tap into their natural ability for Science, as well as enable them to develop their own identify around being a Scientist themselves. Your time commitment would be for a 3 hour segment for one or multiple Fridays. It's your choice. Thank you in advance for your consideration!
10027.title: Calling All Scientists! Join Our Student Science Cafe!

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a part-time 14-hours per week, unpaid telecommuting internship. The internship is 4-months and responsible for leading public and political outreach in the state and district assigned to. Key Responsibilities: - Must be available Mondays 4:30-6:00 PM PST for The Borgen Project’s national conference call. - Meet with members of Congress and/or Congressional staffers in your State and District. - Represent The Borgen Project at various business, political and community events. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Mobilize individuals to contact their members of Congress in support of key poverty-reduction legislation. - As needed, speak to groups, classes and organizations. - Write letters of support for key programs to political leaders, media and other groups. Qualifications: - Outstanding writing skills. - Self-starter who can produce great results with limited supervision. - Strong oral communication skills and ability to lead meetings and give speeches.
10027.title: Political Affairs Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a 12-week, part-time, unpaid internship. The selected candidate will be able to work from home and set their own schedule, but must meet weekly deadlines. Articles submitted will appear on BORGEN Magazine or The Borgen Project Blog. Key Responsibilities: - Interview sources and research topics in-depth. - Write 2 well-researched articles per week. - Communicate with editors and supervisors. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Attend national conference call and/or training every Monday at 4 - 5:30 PM PST. Qualifications: Strong journalism writing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing for newspapers is helpful, but not required.
10027.title: Journalism Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a 12-week, part-time, unpaid internship. The selected candidate will be able to work from home and pick their own schedule, but must meet weekly deadlines. Articles submitted will appear on BORGEN Magazine or The Borgen Project Blog. Key Responsibilities: - Write 2 articles per week. - Research topics. - Assist with advocacy efforts. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Attend national conference call and/or training every Monday at 4 - 5:30 PM PST. Qualifications: Strong research and writing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing SEO friendly content is helpful, but not required.
10027.title: Writer Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. The Borgen Project is hiring an HR Intern who will work remotely. This human resources role will focus on national recruitment and updating job postings. Key Responsibilities: - Update job postings (80% of internship). - Inform groups and classes of openings. - Take on various tasks as needed. - Everyone who is part of the organization assists the team with fundraising, 25-hours of this position is dedicated to creating and implementing a personal fundraising campaign. - Assist with advocacy efforts. Details: This is an unpaid internship, although college credit is available. The HR internship is 16-hours per week for 12-weeks. Must meet weekly deadlines and be available Monday evenings 5-6PM PST for meetings and national conference calls.
10027.title: HR Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. The Borgen Project is hiring a Public Relations/Marketing Intern who will work remotely. This public relations intern will be involved in a variety of aspects of marketing and communications. Key Responsibilities: - Create a branding campaign. - Conduct an informal focus group and gather feedback for market research. - Pitch story ideas to print, broadcast and digital media. - Create and implement a fundraising strategy. - Plan, market and present at an informational meeting. - Utilize social media and develop strategies for web-based messaging. - Assist with The Borgen Project's advocacy efforts. - Take on assignments as needed. Details: This is an unpaid internship, although college credit is available. The internship is 16-hours per week for 12-weeks. Must meet weekly deadlines and be available the first Monday evening of the month, at 5pm PST for meetings.
10027.title: Public Relations/Marketing Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. You don’t need to be a lobbyist to help influence foreign policy. As a Regional Director, you’ll serve as a Borgen Project Ambassador in your city - mobilizing your friends, family and colleagues to contact Congress in support of key poverty reduction legislation. This is an unpaid, volunteer position. Key Responsibilities: - Attend one (30-60 minute) national conference call per month: 5PM PDT 6PM MDT 7PM CDT 8PM EDT - Meet with local congressional leaders and lobby for legislation that improves living conditions for the world’s poor. - Mobilize people in your community to contact their congressional leaders to support poverty reduction legislation. - Manage and implement fundraising campaigns. - Build a network of people engaged in the cause. - Serve as The Borgen Project’s ambassador in your city. Qualifications: - Basic understanding of U.S. Politics and international development. - Highly organized with the ability to prioritize multiple functions and tasks while managing their work time efficiently. - Strong team player that loves to bring new ideas to the table. - Ability to demonstrate frequent independent judgment with decisiveness. - Excellent overall communication skills: oral, written, presentation.
10027.title: Regional Director

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. This is a great entry-level volunteer position for someone looking to be part of The Borgen Project. Advocates can operate from anywhere in the U.S. This is an unpaid, volunteer position. Key Responsibilities: - Attend one (30-60 minute) national conference call per month: 5PM PDT 6PM MDT 7PM CDT 8PM EDT - Serve as an ambassador for the world’s poor. Build awareness of the issues and ways people can help. - Manage and implement fundraising campaigns. - Represent The Borgen Project in your city - attend events and engage people in the cause. - Contact congressional leaders in support of key poverty-reduction programs. Qualifications: - Excellent overall communication skills: oral, written, presentation. - Ability to self-manage and prioritize assignments.
10027.title: Advocate

10027.description: The Jewish Board's Harlem Community Residence provides transitional living studio apartments and mental health services for adults with mental illness. As a Team Activity Leader at our Harlem Community Residence, you can share your passions, hobbies with our residence. We are currently looking for someone to lead a writing group, a music group, and a board games group. Other ideas include a cooking group in which residents can learn about healthy foods and try out new recipes, or a current events group in which everyone gathers with a coffee and a newspaper and talks about what is happening around the world.
10027.title: Team Activity Leader - Manhattan (Harlem)
10027.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10027.description: The Jewish Board's Harlem Community Residence provides transitional living studio apartments and mental health services for adults with mental illness. As a fitness instructor, you can lead classes such as yoga, zumba, or a walking group. Experience leading fitness classes is a plus.
10027.title: Fitness Instructor - Manhattan (Harlem)
10027.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10027.description: The Jewish Board's Manhattan-based Adult Residence provides transitional living studio apartments and mental health services for adults with mental illnesses. As the Art Group Leader, you will lead adult clients in a structured, hands on, interactive and engaging art class! Teach basic art skills to a small group of adults and get their creative juices flowing. Art is a great avenue to help our residents at 124 th St to get back on their feet. Background in creative or visual arts preferred. This opportunity is available Monday Friday. Volunteer shifts will be from 3-5pm for at least 6 months.
10027.title: Visual Art Leader- Manhattan
10027.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10027.description: Urban Church Intern: Mt. Pleasant Church City Vision Internships is a Christian one-year, multi-year or summer internship program based on the AmeriCorps model. Interns serve at one of over 40 positions across the USA and Canada. In the past 10 years, we have placed over 500 full-time interns and 68,000 volunteers in hundreds of Christian ministries. Description: We seek to provide opportunities that will cause growth and prepare the interns for the commitment that the work world requires. Listed below are some of the possibilities that the intern may have to choose from: -Teaching Children and teenagers during the Sunday Church School, ages 4-18. -Learning the curriculum of our Christian school and assisting in our learning center during the school day. -Working in the after school program with neighborhood students who have learning challenges. -Assisting in the morning worship experience by reading scripture, prayers, leading the congregation in worship songs, or sharing a spiritual thought. -Working with the girls in the residential program as they get their homework done, prepare meals, and supervise the bed time process. Benefits: For Interns without a Bachelors Degree: One Year Work Study Internship -Provides a work study internship with free tuition in City Vision College for a full year paid by hosting ministry. -Online courses providing accredited degrees in Nonprofit Management, Addiction Studies, and Urban Missions. -Any Pell grant or other federal financial aid paid as cash payment to student (up to $5,645). -Expectation is typically 29 hours of volunteer work with 16 hours of class work per week (45 hours total). For Interns with a Bachelors Degree: One Year Paid Internship, Multi-Year Graduate Fellowship or Technology Ministry Master's Fellowship One Year Paid Internship -Volunteer Interns paid a living stipend from $200-$600/month (depending on site). -Free tuition in City Vision College for a full year paid by hosting ministry. (Optional) -Expectation is typically 40 hours of volunteer work per week. Multi-Year Graduate Fellowship -Free tuition in Bakke Graduate University programs including MBA, Masters in Global Leadership or Social Entrenpreneurship or Doctorate in Ministry or Transformational Leadership -Some sites may provide an additional stipend for outstanding candidates. -Candidates may receive up to 6 hours of independent study credit based on practicum work at ministry site. -Supervised nonprofit or ministry experience interning 29 hours per week. Requirements -At least 18 years old and have a high school diploma or equivalent (GED) -Must be a Christian -U.S. citizen, U.S. national or lawful permanent resident alien, or have a valid student or work visa -Able to make at least a summer, six month or one year commitment (may be extended by mutual agreement) depending on internship type -Able to financially live on just free housing (if offered) and any outside income sources you have. -Able to relocate (unless there is a site near you) For more information or to apply visit cityvisioninternships.org.
10027.title: Urban Ministry Internship: Mt. Pleasant Church in Harlem, NY

10024.description: Please join us for a special intergenerational reading adventure for 2nd and 3rd graders and older adults. The program is ideal for youth who need extra encouragement to reach for a book and spend time discussing books. Nurture your child’s natural love of reading and chatting through a variety of fun and creative intergenerational activities. The group will read aloud a few books over the course of 14 sessions and discuss the major themes of the books respecting other’s differences and the value of kindness. Great food and art activities will follow. 2017 Dates: February 1 - orientation (for youth only) February 8, 15 March 1, 8, 15, 22 April 5, 19, 26 May 3, 10, 17, 24 Register online starting December 12. Only 12 spaces are available for youth. Parents need a pre-phone interview. For more information, please contact Shelley Levine at slevine@dorotusa.org. Please note: This program is only for students in 2nd and 3rd grade. We are not in need of teen or adult volunteers to assist in the program.
10024.title: Intergenerational Reading Adventure for 2nd and 3rd Grade Students

10024.description: Intergenerational Chess at DOROT Share your love of the game and bring a smile to a senior. \"One of the best things about playing chess with Mr. B is how excited we are to see each other.\" -Zach, age 13 Winter/Spring: Jan. 30-May 15 from 4:00-5:30pm Students and DOROT Seniors will get to know each other and play chess together. Refreshments will be served. Free. Requirements: for 6th - 12th grade students must commit to all sessions understand the game of chess understand the different chess pieces and how to move them Intergenerational Chess at DOROT is sponsored by the Targoff family and friends
10024.title: Intergenerational Chess - Youth Needed to Play Chess with Seniors

10024.description: Register at www.dorotusa.org Brighten the day of a senior! Deliver a package and visit with an older person. We offer three locations for DOROT orientation and assignments: West Side DOROT 171 West 85th Street Off Amsterdam Avenue East Side Westchester
10024.title: Deliver a Passover/Spring Package and visit with a isolated senior

10024.description: Volunteer as an EMT or non-medical provider with CPMU! http://www.cpmu.com/index.php/join-cpmu/
10024.title: Volunteer with the Central Park Medical Unit!

10024.description: From a teen who visited a DOROT Senior: I LOVED THIS VISIT SO MUCH!!! It was really heartwarming and gratifying to see how elated Angie was after she opened the gifts that were in the birthday package. It was so nice to see someone so happy by our visit and what we brought with us. I felt very at ease and it was great talking to her and seeing her reaction to the gifts. -Jessica, 10th grade Teens help alleviate loneliness and social isolation of DOROT's seniors through a variety of hands-on experiences in the community and onsite at DOROT. Teen Interns may: visit seniors in their home for companionship. teach seniors how to use a computer, iPad, iShuffle, and other types of technology. celebrate seniors’ birthdays. deliver meals to seniors. send birthday cards out to seniors. read to visually impaired seniors. shop and delivery groceries to seniors. play chess, cards, scrabble, and other games with seniors. assist with office work at DOROT. take part in a variety of other opportunities and experiences. 10025.description: Top Honors is a non-profit educational organization that provides free math tutoring to NYC 6th, 7th, and 8th-graders. Tutoring takes place on Saturdays and Wednesday evenings at a school on the Upper West Side. New volunteer orientation and training sessions take place on a rolling basis. To receive an invitation, please submit an application here . Frequently asked questions about the TH volunteer experience can be found on our website . All tutoring sessions take place on the Upper West Side in Manhattan on the following days and times: Session 1: Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. Session 2: Saturdays from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. Session 3: Wednesdays from 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. Volunteers may be professionals, advanced high school, college, or graduate students (community service credit is available). Applicants should be available on Saturdays for two hours starting at 10 a.m. or 1:00 p.m. or on Wednesdays from 6:30 - 8 pm, like math, and enjoy working with students in the middle school age group (10-14 years). No prior experience is necessary. A note on volunteer commitment: Tutors attend 2-3 Saturdays from October and May, which includes holidays and school breaks. Attending 20 out of 24 scheduled sesions will meet this requirement. To apply, submit an online application at www.tophonors.org/volunteer. Upon receipt, Top Honors will contact the candidate directly.

10025.description: Would you like to make a difference with your dog? Disadvantaged children in New York City need help. Now you and your dog can help them. Become a volunteer team for A Fair Shake for Youth. A Fair Shake for Youth, Inc. is a non-profit that uses therapy dogs and AKC Canine Good Citizens to help middle-school aged youth in underserved communities build greater empathy and self-esteem, and reduce bullying. Dedicated volunteers and their dogs are at the heart of our program, power and success. Here's how it works: Three volunteer/dog teams each commit to a ten-week program Transportation is provided Teams work with the same group of 12 kids, becoming a consistent part of their school life Kids form a relationship with the volunteers and share the experience of making the dogs successful Volunteers experience a profound connection to the students - their struggles and success. Volunteers must be registered therapy dogs or AKC Canine Good Citizens.If your dog is not already one of these, training is available. We are looking for dogs that love people (especially children), are good with new situations, are resilient and well-mannered. For more information, please visit our website at www.afairshakeforyouth.org . If you and your dog would like to volunteer with us, please email volunteer@afairshakeforyouth.org

10025.description: Walking Tour Guide Would you love to meet people from around the world? Do you love to show people around New York City? Everyday, we offer walking tours to see and experience New York City. This is the perfect opportunity to meet people from around the world. Daily Walking Tours meet at our beautiful Victorian mansion on the Upper West Side. From meeting location, we offer tours to Central Park, Brooklyn Bridge and all types of locations in the five boroughs of New York City.. Note: All volunteers must be punctual and able to commit to regular attendance over a 12-week term. Volunteers will: Give weekly or multi-weekly tours Foreign language ability is a plus but not a requirement Leaders can request tours for specific locations in the five boroughs Serve as representatives of New York to a global audience Help develop your public speaking and communication skills Receive volunteer hours that can be applied towards free hostel stays anywhere in our network of over 50 hostels in the USA Be eligible for volunteer trainings, appreciation events and more If you’re interested, please contact activities.newyork@hiusa.org for an application and more information or visit http://hinewyork.org/volunteer to apply. We’re looking for people who love to travel! HI New York is the largest nonprofit organization dedicated to youth travel in New York, and the largest hostel in North America.

10025.description: Volunteer, Community Tax Aid Community Tax Aid, Inc. (CTA) is a nonprofit community service organization that provides free tax preparation for low-income individuals and families in New York City. We are the oldest free tax preparation service in the country. Extremely complex tax rules, the high price of accountants, and the fear of owing money make it both difficult and scary for low-income taxpayers to file their tax returns. At CTA, we offer training for our volunteers to guide these taxpayers through the filing process, and prepare and file the tax forms for them, all for free. We have locations in four boroughs: Brooklyn, Manhattan, The Bronx, and Queens. We offer CPE credits for qualifying CPAs and Volunteer certificates to those who request them. We are seeking responsible volunteers to assist our multiple locations from February through April. We provide necessary training, and have managers at each location review all tax returns. You can choose the volunteer location and days that are convenient for your schedule. We have opportunities during weekend days and weekday evenings. RESPONSIBILITIES INCLUDE: interviewing taxpayers data entry assembling returns SKILLS/QUALIFICATIONS: good written/oral communication previous tax experience is helpful but not required strong attention to detail second language skills a huge plus: Spanish, Haitian Creole, Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, ASL positive, flexible, and friendly personality Contact: 646-200-5080, or email to ctaVolunteerInfo@aol.com (EMAIL preferred.) For additional information check out our website: www.communitytaxaidnyc.org
10025.title: Volunteer, Community Tax Aid NYC
