07666.description: If you are handy and want to give back to the community, this might be the perfect volunteer opportunity for you! We provide affordable housing and quality care to seniors in need. We are looking for a volunteer(s) to build shelves in the closet to properly store our supplies. THANK YOU!
07666.title: Handyman (or woman) Special

07666.description: I am looking for someone that can facilitate a musical class with our residents at Bright Side Manor! At Bright Side Manor we provide affordable housing and support services to older adults of all income levels in our clean, charming, converted Victorian home in Teaneck, NJ. We have musical instruments but require someone who can help us find a beat! Thank you! Liz
07666.title: Music Class for Seniors

07666.description: JFCS establishes a corps of trained Preparedness and Response volunteers prepared to mobilize at a moment`s notice. They help older adults and individuals with disabilities to prepare kits in advance of a disaster and deliver emergency supplies to, and conduct home checks on, \"at risk\" older adults and individuals with disabilities who may be without power and unable to leave their homes.
07666.title: Disaster Preparedness & Response Program
07666.org: Jewish Family & Children's Services of Northern New Jersey

07666.description: JFCS builds accomplished children with engaging programming in a safe environment. Club ED is our afterschool program for students from Kindergarten through 5 th grade. JFCS recruits volunteers for the programs operating in the Fort Lee and Fairview school districts. Volunteers provide one hour per week of homework assistance (Monday through Friday).
07666.title: Club ED - Homework Assistance Program
07666.org: Jewish Family & Children's Services of Northern New Jersey

07666.description: YOU can make a difference in someone’s life! YOU can brighten the day of a homebound, isolated Senior! YOU can have fun and get to know someone in your community! Friendly Visitor Volunteers enjoy one-on-one relationships, while alleviating loneliness and isolation with important human contact encouraging lonely elders to socialize. Volunteers are specifically trained to understand and appreciate underlying social needs and, in doing so, to provide a sense of dignity and worth for the clients that is so often lacking. For more information, e-mail ninaa@jfsbergen.org or call Nina Ashurov at 201-837-9090 ext. 238
07666.title: Friendly Visitor
07666.org: Jewish Family & Children's Services of Northern New Jersey

07666.description: YOU can make a difference in someone’s life! YOU can brighten the day of a homebound, isolated Elder! YOU can have fun and get to know someone in your community! The Adopt-a-Grandparent telephone reassurance program sponsored by Jewish Family and Children's Services (JFCS) of Bergen, Passaic Counties and North Hudson, pairs teens with frail, homebound elders in their community. Teens call their \"bubbies\" once a week to provide companionship and social interaction as well as helping orient the Elder to time and place and assuring their safety and well being. A JFCS staff member provides training for all volunteers. The training includes an overview of how to make the call, effective communication with the elderly and recordkeeping. TOUCH A LIFE - ADOPT AN ELDER! You may find you get more than you give! For more information, e-mail ninaa@jfsbergen.org or call Nina Ashurov at 201-837-9090 ext. 238
07666.title: Adopt-a-Grandparent
07666.org: Jewish Family & Children's Services of Northern New Jersey

07666.description: The Kosher Meals on Wheels (KMOW) program of Bergen and Passaic Counties, NJ, is looking for volunteers to deliver meals to our homebound and isolated seniors and people with disabilities. Each route takes no more than one hour to drive. If you're 17 years of age or older and have a valid driver's license you can join our dedicated team of volunteers. Meals are picked up in Teaneck, NJ, mornings, afternoons or evenings. If you can drive every other week or every week, we need you. Interested? Contact us at ninaa@jfsbergen.org or call 201-837-9090 ext. 238
07666.title: Kosher Meals on Wheels (KMOW) Driver
07666.org: Jewish Family & Children's Services of Northern New Jersey

07666.description: Assist clients and staff with recreation program activities including games, arts and crafts, woodworking activities, painting, jewelry making, and more.
07666.title: ACTIVITIES/RECREATION ASSISTANT

07666.description: Volunteer 4 hours per week to respond to emergency ambulance calls in the Township of Teaneck, NJ
07666.title: Emergency Medical Technician (EMT)

10013.description: LearningSpring School, a K-8 non-profit school for children on the autism spectrum, is seeking volunteers for its annual LSS BLOOMS Benefit. The event will be occuring at Tribeca Rooftop (2 Desbrosses Street) on Tuesday, March 14th. We need volunteers to help set up the day of the event and to help during the event ( 6 PM - 10 PM). Daytime shifts are from 10 AM to 2 PM (lunch will be provided) and 2 PM to 5:30 PM. Volunteer jobs include providing assistance setting up the Silent Auction Table, assembling centerpieces for the dinner tables, organizing table seating cards, etc. During the event ( 6 PM to 9:30 PM), we will need volunteers to help with check-in and raffle sales, watch over the Silent Auction table, help guests find their seats, collect pledge cards, etc. Dinner will be provided. Please note: All volunteers must be at least 21 years old.
10013.title: Event volunteer

10013.description: For many new immigrants, learning English is a first step to full participation in American society. Help them take that first step by becoming a volunteer teacher in English or Citizenship classes. English classes help students improve their communication skills. Citizenship classes help students prepare for the U.S. citizenship test. Volunteers work in teams to plan lessons and teach the class. This fun and rewarding experience gives you a chance to make a difference in the lives of others. Individuals with an interest in education careers are encouraged to apply. Requirements Must have good communication skills and a strong desire to help and work with new immigrants Prior teaching experience is preferred. Bilingual skills are a plus. We prefer volunteers who can commit to teaching at least two semesters Prospective volunteers must complete application and be interviewed. Volunteer Schedule: 9:30 am-11:30am (Tues or Thurs) 10:15am-12;15pm (Monday) 1pm to 4pm (Saturday) 6:30pm to 8:30 pm(Mon, Tues or Wed) Spring 2017 - Jan 33, 2017 to June 10, 2017 Summer 2017 - July 10, 2017 to August 19, 2017 Fall 2017 - September 19, 2017 to December 16, 2017 Prospective volunteers must complete application and will be interviewed. Please contact us at cpanyc@cpanyc.org for an application OR apply on-line here: http://bit.ly/volunteerteacherapp
10013.title: Teach English or Citizenship Class in Chinatown

10013.description: Planning Committee CMP is a long standing nonprofit located in lower Manhattan. By providing language classes, skill trainings, workshops, and other activities to new immigrants, Asian Americans, and low-income individuals, we aim to help people fulfill their potentials and become financially self-sufficient. We are now seeking planning committee members (February to April) for our 45 th Anniversary Gala at Capitale (130 Bowery Street) on Thursday, April 27 th. Possible duties include but not limited to event planning, sponsorship solicitation, silent auction solicitation, gift bag items solicitation, traditional & social media feed, event journal compilation. People with previous event planning, marketing, public relation experience would be a good fit for this opportunity. It would also be a good chance for people who are interested in these fields to get their hands dirty. Questions or applications can be directed to nadiakang@cmpny.org. Please also attach a most updated resume for application. Please note: Event day volunteers must be at least 21 years old with fluent English conversation skill.
10013.title: Planning Committee Member for 45th Anniversary Gala

10013.description: Special Events Director The Special Events Director will manage all special events and their budget, and will work with the other E-board members on their recruitment, sponsorship and promotion. At the moment, Shine Foundation’s main \"special event\" is our Financial Health Night, which introduces new clients to various financial resources, as well as vendors and new volunteers to Shine Foundation’s service. Set up in a fun, convention-style format, past Financial Health Nights have featured such booths as \"Fiscal Foodie,\" \"Money-Saving Mom\" and \"Resume Royalty,\" as well as included past assistance from Bank of America, Wells Fargo and Soma Intimates. Among his/her principal responsibilities, the Special Events Director will: ● Brainstorm event themes around the topic of financial and vocational development ● Plan event timelines and itineraries, as well as disseminate information to all stakeholders ● Calculate budgets and adjust as necessary ● Analyze and report on performance of events ● Prepare volunteers for events ● Perform other duties outside of this role, within his/her ability and as needed
10013.title: Shine NYC Chapter Special Events Director

10013.description: Shine Foundation, a nonprofit that provides free financial education to homeless abuse survivors in NYC and Baltiimore, is looking for a Digital Marketing Director to join its NYC Chapter-level Board! To apply, please send your cover letter and resume to general@shine-foundation.org, referencing this position in the subject line, by Friday, Jan 27. Description The Digital Marketing Director will shape all aspects of Shine’s digital strategy while working closely with the PR Director and volunteers across the organization. Among his/her principal responsibilities, the Digital Marketing Director will: ● Proactively update social media channels (Facebook, Twitter) ● Devise digital campaigns to build and engage an online community ● Establish metrics for measuring marketing performance ● Plan and manage budget for digital marketing initiatives ● Explore and suggest new digital strategies and channels ●Maintain and update Wordpress website ● Perform other duties outside of this role, within his/her ability and as needed
10013.title: Digital Marketing Director on nonprofit NYC board

10013.description: Community Partnership Director The Community Partnerships Director will be responsible for developing partnerships with community businesses and sponsors that support and/or align with Shine’s mission. Similar to the Site Director, the Community Partnership Director will also: ● Serve as the \"face\" of Shine Foundation to all community partners, current and potential ● Maintain a list of potential, current and former partners ● Reach out to partners to explore new or continued partnerships ● Evaluate partner relationships and implement ad-hoc improvements ● Perform other duties, within his/her ability and as needed
10013.title: Shine NYC Chapter Community Partnership Director

10013.description: Go the extra mile with Back on My Feet NYC! Dedicated teams of volunteers run 2-4 miles with our members who are transitioning out of homelessness. We encourage runners of all speeds (run/jog/walk) to become a part of our community! Team City Hall runs with the NYC Rescue Mission at the NW corner of Collect Pond Park every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 5:45-6:45AM. To find out more and sign up for an orientation, visit nyc.backonmyfeet.org/nyc-run-with-us
10013.title: Downtown Morning Runner

10013.description: Spare just half an hour to bring leftover food to the nearby Bowery Mission! The final destination will be the Bowery Mission at 227 Bowery. Middleweight: the average amount of food is 15-20 pounds. Sign up directly on our website: http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar
10013.title: Stop Food Waste & Feed The Hungry Every Monday & Tuesday in Soho 3:00-3:30pm

10013.description: Help your community to stop food waste and fight hunger by bringing excess food to homeless shelters. You will be taking bags of excess food, which would have been thrown out by the restaurant, to the nearest homeless shelter. This is a great opportunity to gain community service experience while helping others at the same time!!!! Please sign up for events directly on our website: http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar
10013.title: Stop Food Waste & Feed The Hungry In Just 30 Minutes!!!!

10013.description: Shine Foundation aims to help homeless survivors of abuse achieve financial independence through financial and vocational education. You can apply online at www.shine-foundation.org/join. Candidates must be in possession of the following: Fervent desire to help Shine Foundation’s clients: abuse survivors in domestic violence shelters Significant Leadership/Project Management experience Goal-oriented Excellent communication and organizational skills Flexible, resourceful approach Proven creativity and ability to think on the spot Sensitivity to survivors of abuse. Prior experience working with such individuals is a plus, but not required Introspective, empathetic and patient nature Team player Grace under pressure Must be available at least 10-15 hours/week for a min of 1-year Looking forward to hearing from you!
10013.title: Help Homeless Abuse Survivors Improve their Financial Literacy-NYC

10013.description: Taproot Account Directors lead teams of 5-6 pro bono consultants on pro bono projects for a nopnprofit. The Account Director’s role is to staff the team, manage relationships, and keep a bird’s-eye view of the project. The Account Director also works with a Taproot Program Manager to track progress, resolve challenges, and ensure the successful completion of each project. A successful Account Director: Has 10 years experience in corporate strategy management and/or financial analysis Has managed leadership teams Can negotiate executive or board-level relationships Has Director, VP, or partner-level experience A Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job. Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives. Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.
10013.title: Account Directors – Use Your Strategy Management Skills Pro Bono

08818.description: Under the guidance of JFK Johnson Rehabilitation leading facility, interns will take an active role on a research project in one of the following areas: subject consent process, database collection and input, follow-up subject contact for follow-up, and maintenance of research data. The internship program is designed for students who are considering a graduate or medical career. A 12 month commitment with 10 hours per week is highly suggested.
08818.title: Stroke Recovery Program Research Intern

08818.description: Sunday Social is a fun and fantastic project fit for the whole family. The New Jersey Veteran's Home in Menlo Park is filled with history from which we can all learn and grow. You have an opportunity to be the shining light in someone’s day. Volunteers are needed to socialize senior friends by playing games, reading a book, trivia, and exercise or playing an instrument. The options are numerous and great for anyone. Musicians: Musicians should notify Jersey Cares upon registration for further instruction at info@jerseycares.org. Animals: All animals need to be certified Pet Therapists, please email your certification to info@jerseycares.org . Youth: Youth volunteers (17 years and under) must be accompanied by an adult and a Youth Waiver must be completed by the guardian through Jersey Cares prior to arrival. Please email your Youth Waiver to info@jerseycares.org . Everyone: Please do not enter the facility if you have a cold/virus, the residents are very susceptible to contagion. NOTE: To participate in this project you must be a Jersey Cares volunteer. To sign up as a Jersey Cares volunteer: 1. Visit www.jerseycares.org 2. Click on \"Log-In\" 3. Click on \"Not a Member? Register\" 4. Fill out all necessary information. 5. Register for a project!
08818.title: Sunday Social in Menlo Park

08818.description: The Gift Shop Volunteer assists in providing a service for patients, visitors and hospital staff by offering for sale a variety of items which are appealing and often essential for the patient's comfort.
08818.title: Auxiliary Gift Shop Volunteer

08818.description: Information Desk volunteers are needed for nights (4pm-8:30pm), weekends (7:30am-8:30pm) and days (7:30am-3:30pm) to provide accurate information to visitors & patients, answer phone inquiries, deliver patient mail & flowers, problem solve patient & visitor inquiries. This is the spot to learn all about the hospital and what services it provides.
08818.title: Information Desk Volunteer

11231.description: Love food? Are you in food business, culinary arts or want to be? Help us build our SECOND Cobble Hil/Carroll Gardens Restaurant Crawl on Thursday, APRIL 27. HELP create a fabulous food event and also raise funds for underserved childrne in food deserts to open their own Hip2B Healthy farmstands. People buy tickets and walk around the historic neighborhoods and try different delicious dishes by restaurants. Here's what you can do. Before the event, you can help us: - create posters and graphic work (if that's your thing) - reach out by emails or phone calls or even walk to restaurants to ask them to join - help us mail invites to restaurants - spread the word on social media, and in food blogs and other media - Help put up flyers - talk to different restaurants to see what they need - sell tickets - help chefs prepare their dishes if they need help During event: - help chefs at their place of business and punch or cross off tickets - help set up (noon on....) - help any chefs breakdown - (8 pm - 9 pm) - Register and sell tickets - Help chefs, if they want, prepare their dishes that day This is a fun way to meet chefs and get to know restaurants in the neighborhood. If you're into food, the dishes should be awesome. If you want to work or intern in food industry, here's a chance to meet professionals in an enjoyable atmosphere. If you want more info, email tastesofbrooklyn@gmail.com Here's the event on FAcebook - https://www.facebook.com/events/174711446347173/ If you are an artist or artisan, and want to be matched with a restaurant, let us know. If you are a performer and want to sing or dance at the event.. Look forward to hearing from you.
11231.title: Chefs, foodies! Join, help create Brooklyn Restaurant Crawl April 27

07066.description: Deliver groceries and other material assistance to families of kids with cancer. We are in need of volunteers for the delivery of food and items to families in Bergen County area. The deliveries are made once a month from the Northern Regional Office located in Clark, NJ. The food is bagged and ready to go. Each volunteer would have the same family and route each month. Training will be provided. Climbing stairs may be involved. A backround check is required - we can get you one for $18 from the State of NJ if you can't provide your own. Spanish-speaking volunteers are a plus!
07066.title: Deliver items to bring comfort and cheer to help families of kids with cancer

07066.description: Homeside Hospice is looking for volunteers to provide Music Therapy to our patients in assisted living and in nursing homes in Union County. If you are a Music Therapist, you can provide a loving experience for patients in lifes final journey. As a volunteer you will provide essential, quality of life services to patients. Your efforts will provide the sort of care and help that a loving friend provides and help insure that the Hospice promise is fulfilled. Music Therapy Students Welcome!
07066.title: Music Therapy Volunteers needed in Union County

07066.description: Our Central Region is planning a Tricky Tray fundraiser. We are putting together a committee to help plan this event, from finding a location, soliciting donations, marketing, to getting people to attend.
07066.title: Do You Enjoy Tricky Trays? Join our Vibrant Committee!

07066.description: All four regions (Bergen county, Gloucester county, Monmouth county, and Union county) are seeking volunteers to help us launch some exciting new fundraisers! You will work either on your own or with a small team of other volunteers to coordinate these events under the guidance of the Regional Director. Even if you've never planned a fundraiser, If you've ever planned a wedding or other major party, this is an opportunity you can handle! It can even be accomplished using only your Facebook or email contacts!
07066.title: Fundraising Event Planner - All Regions NJ

07066.description: Homeside Hospice is looking for volunteers to provide companionship to patients in their home or nursing home in the Princeton and Mercerville Areas. As a companion you will provide a listening ear and a sharing spirit to enhance the patient's emotional and spiritual well-being. As a volunteer you will provide essential, quality of life services to patients. Your efforts will provide the sort of care and help that a loving friend provides and help insure that the Hospice promise is fulfilled. Some visits might include reading, watching TV, taking walks, playing music, talking about their life and their family, or shared silence.
07066.title: Volunteer companions needed for hospice patients in Union County

07066.description: Homeside Hospice is looking for volunteers to provide animal assisted activities in nursing homes in Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Ocean, Passic, Somerset, and Union counties. If you have a certified therapy pet, you and your pet can provide a loving experience for patients often isolated from nature. As a volunteer you will provide essential, quality of life services to patients. Your efforts will provide the sort of care and help that a loving friend provides and help insure that the Hospice promise is fulfilled.
07066.title: Volunteers and their pets needed for hospice patients

07066.description: Homeside Hospice is looking for volunteers to provide companionship to patients in their home or nursing home in Middlesex, Union , Somerset, Monmouth, Hudson and counties. As a companion you will provide a listening ear and a sharing spirit to enhance the patient's emotional and spiritual well-being. As a volunteer you will provide essential, quality of life services to patients. Your efforts will provide the sort of care and help that a loving friend provides and help insure that the Hospice promise is fulfilled. Some visits might include reading, watching TV, taking walks, playing music, talking about their life and their family, or shared silence.
07066.title: Volunteer companions needed for hospice patients

07065.description: Committed professionals in all disciplines are invited to join the inaugural Board of Directors for the 1City Academy Christian Schools, a part of the total ministry of Kingdom City Fellowship (www.kingdomcityfellowship.org). Students currently in college are welcomed to apply. Members of the Corporate Board are responsible for helping us plan every aspect of the schools' opening and once opened, the Board will assist with the ongoing governance of the schools. Each member of the Board will serve a three year term. Meetings are held in March, June, September and December and can be attended in-person or via conference call. Additionally, members are asked to participate in one committee, that will meet via conference call quarterly (or as needed). As of this date, a give/get requirement has not been established but we anticipate that one will be established eventually. Quarterly Board meetings will occur in the PENN STATION area of New York City. This is an excellent opportunity to be intimately involved in the opening and operation of a Christian school that aspires to provide education that exceeds the standards and outcomes of its public and charter counterparts. Church affiliation is not required for this opportunity and the Board has no input into the faith-based components of the school. Interested candidates are asked to send a resume and cover letter to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com. An application will be sent upon receipt of your interest, we well as an invitation to attend a brief board orientation in the RAHWAY office (an orientation can also occur by phone). Once your application is approved, you will receive information on your first committee meeting, as well as an invitation to attend the first NYC Board meeting on March 29th.
07065.title: Board of Directors- 1City Christian Academy

07065.description: Committed individuals (ages 18-over) are invited to pledge Nu Sigma Theta and help us develop a thriving chapter in New Jersey. For information, visit http://www.kingdomcityfellowship.org/nu-sigma-theta/ Even though Nu Sigma Theta is a partner with a church, it is formed for non-religious purposes and does not require its members to be affiliated with any church or faith. Members who join under this opportunity would NOT be subject to dues because they will be tasked with helping to establish the chapter in New Jersey - which includes the development and execution of service projects, fundraisers, charitable involvement, youth mentoring and members-only activities. The Chapter would meet quarterly at a time that works best for the majority and meetings will be held in Rahway, New Jersey. Our office is located directly across the street from the Rahway Train Station. The group might eventually venture together to do projects and activities with the New York Chapter. A working email address is a requirement as is a Facebook account (you may create a separate one just for this activity if you'd like). The Facebook account is critical as it allows you to participate in discussions and activities with members from all over the world. Interested candidates are asked to email kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com letting us know what city/township they reside in. We will then forward the membership application.
07065.title: Nu Sigma Theta- New Jersey

07065.description: We are looking for committed professionals to serve on the Marketing Committee of a newly forming Christian school that will serve students in grades 5 to 12 in New York and New Jersey. Although the committee serves as a function of our Board of Directors, its members are not members of the Board. Church affiliation or membership is not required for this opportunity. The Marketing Committee will be responsible for setting the vision for and managing the overall marketing strategy for the schools. They will also oversee the public relations, branding, social media, press and community relations activities for the schools. The Committee will take in ensuring that the schools’ marketing practices (service announcements, brochures, and other marketing materials) are governed by applicable laws and regulations, and standards of acceptable marketing, such as those promulgated by the Association of Fundraising Professionals. The Committee will meet primarily via conference call on a quarterly basis (more often as we get closer to the opening of the schools). Members close to the Rahway community can elect to meet in-person as well. Committee members will be asked to attend an in-person meeting in New York City in June (The Board’s Annual Meeting). Candidates with significant experience in school management, operations, and education, as well as other areas of human services are strongly encouraged to apply. The Committee will also consider applicants currently in undergraduate studies. It is anticipated that the first conference call for this committee will be held in February, 2017. It is respectfully requested that interested candidates apply by sending their resumes/cover letters to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com . A response containing more information about the school and the Committee’s function, as well as an application, will be sent. Candidates will be invited to attend a meet and greet at our office in Rahway on a Saturday afternoon (2/11 or 2/18). The general Board will vote on the application and then each approved candidate will be sent an invitation to participate on the first call.
07065.title: Marketing Committee- The 1City Academy

07065.description: We are looking for committed professionals to serve on the Operations Committee of a newly forming Christian school that will serve students in grades 5 to 12 in New York and New Jersey. Although the committee serves as a function of our Board of Directors, its members are not members of the Board. Church affiliation or membership is not required for this opportunity. The Operations Committee will be responsible for planning out the aspects of the school’s day-to-day operations and for developing policies and procedures to support those operations as appropriate. This includes, but is not limited to: enrollment/transfer/discharge processes; enrollment/attendance reporting; development of student policies/handbooks; establishment of calendar/activities; initial charting of supplies; lunch/transportation procedures; disciplinary processes, etc. The Committee will meet primarily via conference call on a quarterly basis (more often as we get closer to the opening of the schools). Members close to the Rahway community can elect to meet in-person as well. Committee members will be asked to attend an in-person meeting in New York City in June (The Board’s Annual Meeting). Candidates with significant experience in school management, operations, and education, as well as other areas of human services are strongly encouraged to apply. The Committee will also consider applicants currently in undergraduate studies. It is anticipated that the first conference call for this committee will be held in February, 2017. It is respectfully requested that interested candidates apply by sending their resumes/cover letters to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com . A response containing more information about the school and the Committee’s function, as well as an application, will be sent. Candidates will be invited to attend a meet and greet at our office in Rahway on a Saturday afternoon (2/11 or 2/18). The general Board will vote on the application and then each approved candidate will be sent an invitation to participate on the first call.
07065.title: Operations Committee- 1City Christian Academy

07065.description: We are looking for committed professionals to serve on the Development Committee of a newly forming Christian school that will serve students in grades 5 to 12 in New York and New Jersey. Although the committee serves as a function of our Board of Directors, its members are not members of the Board. Church affiliation or membership is not required for this opportunity. The Development Committee will work to maximize funding from individuals, foundations and corporations and to promote the name and programs of The 1City Academy Christian Schools. The Development Committee will also develop a fundraising plan, which will include annual activities for the Board/Committee Members, parents, students and the general community and will work closely with the Finance Committee to establish the annual budget. The Committee will also take the lead in implementing fundraising activities to support the initial and ongoing expenses of the schools. The Committee will meet primarily via conference call on a quarterly basis (more often as we get closer to the opening of the schools). Members close to the Rahway community can elect to meet in-person as well. Committee members will be asked to attend an in-person meeting in New York City in June (The Board’s Annual Meeting). Candidates with significant experience in development, fundraising and events planning, as well as other areas of human services are strongly encouraged to apply. The Committee will also consider applicants currently in undergraduate studies. It is anticipated that the first conference call for this committee will be held in February, 2017. It is respectfully requested that interested candidates apply by sending their resumes/cover letters to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com . A response containing more information about the school and the Committee’s function, as well as an application, will be sent. Candidates will be invited to attend a meet and greet at our office in Rahway on a Saturday afternoon (2/11 or 2/18). The general Board will vote on the application and then each approved candidate will be sent an invitation to participate on the first call.
07065.title: Development Committee- 1City Christian Academy

07065.description: We are looking for committed professionals to serve on the Education Committee of a newly forming Christian school that will serve students in grades 5 to 12 in New York and New Jersey. Although the committee serves as a function of our Board of Directors, its members are not members of the Board. Church affiliation or membership is not required for this opportunity. The Education Committee will be working closely with our Directors of Curriculum and Instruction on the established curriculum, offering critiques, recommendations and resources to ensure that students have the best academic experience. The Committee will also work to ensure that the Schools are in compliance with all applicable State/Federal guidelines and will work with the Evaluation Committee to determine curriculum effectiveness. The Committee will meet primarily via conference call on a quarterly basis (more often as we get closer to the opening of the schools). Members close to the Rahway community can elect to meet in-person as well. Committee members will be asked to attend an in-person meeting in New York City in June (The Board’s Annual Meeting). Candidates with significant experience in education, curriculum development, as well as other areas of human services are strongly encouraged to apply. The Committee will also consider applicants currently in undergraduate studies. It is anticipated that the first conference call for this committee will be held in February, 2017. It is respectfully requested that interested candidates apply by sending their resumes/cover letters to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com . A response containing more information about the school and the Committee’s function, as well as an application, will be sent. Candidates will be invited to attend a meet and greet at our office in Rahway on a Saturday afternoon (2/11 or 2/18). The general Board will vote on the application and then each approved candidate will be sent an invitation to participate on the first call.
07065.title: Education Committee- 1City Christian Academy

07065.description: We are looking for committed professionals to serve on the Technology Committee of a newly forming Christian school that will serve students in grades 5 to 12 in New York and New Jersey. Although the committee serves as a function of our Board of Directors, its members are not members of the Board. Church affiliation or membership is not required for this opportunity. The Technology Committee will be responsible for developing the technological needs of the school (security, administrative, academic) and for establishing and overseeing the initial budget for the identified needs; the Committee will also oversee the search and hire of a Technology Director for the Schools and will also periodically review the technological program to ensure that the School is operating with state of the art equipment as is practical and possible. The Committee will meet primarily via conference call on a quarterly basis (more often as we get closer to the opening of the schools). Members close to the Rahway community can elect to meet in-person as well. Committee members will be asked to attend an in-person meeting in New York City in June (The Board’s Annual Meeting). Candidates with significant experience in information technology, as well as other areas of human services are strongly encouraged to apply. The Committee will also consider applicants currently in undergraduate studies. It is anticipated that the first conference call for this committee will be held in February, 2017. It is respectfully requested that interested candidates apply by sending their resumes/cover letters to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com . A response containing more information about the school and the Committee’s function, as well as an application, will be sent. Candidates will be invited to attend a meet and greet at our office in Rahway on a Saturday afternoon (2/11 or 2/18). The general Board will vote on the application and then each approved candidate will be sent an invitation to participate on the first call.
07065.title: Technology Committee- 1City Christian Academy

07065.description: We are looking for committed professionals to serve on the Finance/Audit Committee of a newly forming Christian school that will serve students in grades 5 to 12 in New York and New Jersey. Although the committee serves as a function of our Board of Directors, its members are not members of the Board. Church affiliation or membership is not required for this opportunity. The Finance Committee will be responsible for establishing and overseeing the initial budget and investments and for approving subsequent years’ budgets. The Committee will also be responsible for the initial search, vetting and oversight of the school’s Finance Director, and will also work to identify and work with an independent auditor. The Committee will also develop the first policies and procedures for its operation that comply with all applicable local, state, federal standards. The Committee will meet primarily via conference call on a quarterly basis (more often as we get closer to the opening of the schools). Members close to the Rahway community can elect to meet in-person as well. Committee members will be asked to attend an in-person meeting in New York City in June (The Board’s Annual Meeting). Candidates with significant experience in finance, accounting, and business, as well as other areas of human services are strongly encouraged to apply. The Committee will also consider applicants currently in undergraduate studies. It is anticipated that the first conference call for this committee will be held in February, 2017. It is respectfully requested that interested candidates apply by sending their resumes/cover letters to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com . A response containing more information about the school and the Committee’s function, as well as an application, will be sent. Candidates will be invited to attend a meet and greet at our office in Rahway on a Saturday afternoon (2/11 or 2/18). The general Board will vote on the application and then each approved candidate will be sent an invitation to participate on the first call.
07065.title: Finance Committee- 1City Christian Academy

07065.description: We are looking for committed professionals to serve on the Human Resources Committee of a newly forming Christian school that will serve students in grades 5 to 12 in New York and New Jersey. Although the committee serves as a function of our Board of Directors, its members are not members of the Board. Church affiliation or membership is not required for this opportunity. The Human Resources Committee will be responsible for overseeing the initial search, hire and evaluation of the schools’ first principals and senior level staff; the Committee, working along with other Committees, will set salaries for senior level staff and review requests for increase as appropriate; the Committee will also develop the first policies and procedures for all staff and will ensure that the school is abiding by all appropriate labor laws. The Committee will meet primarily via conference call on a quarterly basis (more often as we get closer to the opening of the schools). Members close to the Rahway community can elect to meet in-person as well. Committee members will be asked to attend an in-person meeting in New York City in June (The Board’s Annual Meeting). Candidates with significant experience in human resources and staff supervision, as well as other areas of human services are strongly encouraged to apply. The Committee will also consider applicants currently in undergraduate studies. It is anticipated that the first conference call for this committee will be held in February, 2017. It is respectfully requested that interested candidates apply by sending their resumes/cover letters to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com . A response containing more information about the school and the Committee’s function, as well as an application, will be sent. Candidates will be invited to attend a meet and greet at our office in Rahway on a Saturday afternoon (2/11 or 2/18). The general Board will vote on the application and then each approved candidate will be sent an invitation to participate on the first call.
07065.title: Human Resources Committee- 1City Christian Academy

07065.description: We are looking for committed professionals to serve on the Program Committee of a newly forming Christian school that will serve students in grades 5 to 12 in New York and New Jersey. Although the committee serves as a function of our Board of Directors, its members are not members of the Board. Church affiliation or membership is not required for this opportunity. The Program Committee will be responsible for developing extra-curricular programming for students and parents of the school and for sourcing resources that can be leveraged to implement these programs. The Committee will also to review, monitor, and promote the use of data and evaluation techniques across all of the developed programs to ensure effectiveness. The Committee will work to ensure that all programs are utilizing best practices and following emerging trends. The Committee will meet primarily via conference call on a quarterly basis (more often as we get closer to the opening of the schools). Members close to the Rahway community can elect to meet in-person as well. C ommittee members will be asked to attend an in-person meeting in New York City in June (The Board’s Annual Meeting). Candidates with significant experience in education/youth program development; community services and other areas of human services are strongly encouraged to apply. The Committee will also consider applicants currently in undergraduate studies. It is anticipated that the first conference call for this committee will be held in February, 2017. It is respectfully requested that interested candidates apply by sending their resumes/cover letters to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com . A response containing more information about the school and the Committee’s function, as well as an application, will be sent. Candidates will be invited to attend a meet and greet at our office in Rahway on a Saturday afternoon (2/11 or 2/18). The general Board will vote on the application and then each approved candidate will be sent an invitation to participate on the first call.
07065.title: Program Committee- 1City Christian Academy

07065.description: We are looking for committed professionals to serve on the Compliance Committee of a newly forming Christian school that will serve students in grades 5 to 12 in New York and New Jersey. Although the committee serves as a function of our Board of Directors, its members are not members of the Board. Church affiliation or membership is not required for this opportunity. The Compliance Committee will be responsible for evaluating the schools’ exposure to risk and developing and implementing strategies to minimize and/or eliminate that risk. As we are in the foundational stages of the schools’ development, the Committee will also be responsible for researching, vetting and working with insurance and legal vendors and will be responsible for developing the schools’ initial risk management policies and for ensuring the schools’ compliance with all applicable legal, licensing and reporting requirements. The Committee will meet primarily via conference call on a quarterly basis (more often as we get closer to the opening of the schools). Members close to the Rahway community can elect to meet in-person as well. Committee members will be asked to attend an in-person meeting in New York City in June (The Board’s Annual Meeting). Candidates with significant experience in law, compliance, insurance or other areas of human services are strongly encouraged to apply. The Committee will also consider applicants currently in undergraduate studies. The first conference call for this committee will be held in February, 2017. Interested candidates must apply by sending their resumes/cover letters to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com . A response containing more information about the school and the Committee’s function, as well as an application, will be sent. Candidates will be invited to attend a meet and greet at our office in Rahway on a Saturday afternoon (2/11 or 2/18). The general Board will vote on the application and then each approved candidate will be sent an invitation to participate on the first call.
07065.title: Compliance Committee- 1City Christian Academy

07065.description: A patient with a terminal illness could benefit from compassionate visits from a Spanish speaking visitor. Visits can be scheduled according to your availabilty and are usually 1-2 hours in length once a week. Become a part of the Kindred Hospice team; a very special group of compassionate people who dedicate their time to a truly noble cause. Free training is provided. Contact Elaine.Carlsen@gentiva.com or call 888-556-8880 today.

07065.description: Are you looking for a new church home and a way to impact the world for Christ? Then we invite you to join the Kingdom City Fellowship (www.kingdomcityfellowship.org)! As we are just beginning, we currently operate small Bible Study groups - Victory Group David: Wednesdays from 7pm to 9pm Victory Group Gideon: Sundays from 11:30am to 1:00pm. We believe that EVERYONE deserves to experience the Love of God and that they deserve to have everything that He promised them in His Word. We also believe that EVERYONE has a gift to bring - whether it's their love for people, their desire to serve or some other talent or ability that can be used to build this community. We are a church that also believes in FAMILY! We celebrate holidays together, we laugh together, we watch sports together, we eat together, we shop together, we go to movies together, we have special events and barbecues. We also believe in SERVICE! We will support/mentor young people together, we will support seniors together, we will feed the homeless together, we will write to those who are forgotten and imprisoned together, we will advocate for our communities together! Most importantly, we believe in FAITH! We pray together, we learn together, we believe together and we achieve together. If you have ever wondered where your place is in this world, or if you have ever felt as though you didn't belong, then becoming a KINGDOM CITIZEN would be a great place to begin your journey! All you need is a Bible, a pen and some paper. If you don't have a Bible, no worries - we will gift you with one! You can dress how you want (jeans, sneakers, sweats or your Sunday best). Like we said before, we currently operate in small groups and meet in an office environment, so dress comfortably! When you respond to kingdomcityfellowship@gmail.com, please confirm that you understand the requirements of this opportunity and let us know which Victory Group you would be interested in attending. We are unable to respond to candidates who do not respond in this way.

07065.description: Art therapy; the psychological use of art media and the creative process, facilitated by an art therapist, to help foster self expression, create coping skills, and strengthen sense of self. Using the artistic process to help people explore different challenges and things they’re facing in their life. assess the needs of the client by listening and providing guidance; work creatively with various client groups in a therapeutic setting, ensuring a safe and secure environment; enable clients to explore their artwork and the process they used to create it; assess and understand the feelings or temperament of others; constructively challenge the behaviour and attitude of your clients; attend meetings and case conferences to share ideas, expertise and good practice; keep up to date with administration tasks; maintain art therapy space and materials; receive support and discuss ideas in individual supervision; explore opportunities for work where it may not currently exist; present a case to other professionals on reasons for employing an art therapist; keep up to date with developments in the profession by attending seminars, lectures, and workshops.

Members who join under this opportunity would NOT be subject to dues because they will be tasked with helping to establish the chapter in New York - which includes the development and execution of service projects, fundraisers, charitable involvement, youth mentoring and members-only activities. The Chapter would meet quarterly at a time that works best for the majority and meetings will be held in the Penn Station area of Manhattan. The group might eventually venture together to do projects and activities with the New Jersey Chapter. 11234.description: We are looking for young men and women, age 12 to 18 to join our Cadet Program. The program is partnered with the United States Air Force and its main goals are to promote leadership, good citizenship, aerospace education and staying free of drugs among today's youth. We are NOT a military program. Yes, we do instill discipline, integrity, and respect, but we do not bare arms or serve as a recruiting tool for the armed forces. The involvement of the USAF is limited. However, we do wear Air Force style uniforms, follow their customs and courtesies, drill and movements, attend events sponsored by the Air Force and promote their basic core values of Integrity, Service Before Self, and Excellence. We meet on 2nd, 3rd and 4th Saturdays of each month from 10:30am to 2:30pm.
11234.title: Cadets
11234.org: Civil Air Patrol - Floyd Bennett Composite Squadron

11234.description: We are seeking individuals to join our organization for the purpose of performing Search & Rescue and Disaster Relief. Civil Air Patrol is responsible for over 90% of all inland Search And Rescue in the United States as tasked by the US Air Force. We utilize air and ground teams as well as communications and mission base staff personnel to accomplish those missions. CAP is also tasked to provide Disaster Relief and were mobilized to assist in the wake of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita in 2005. Our airplane was the first non-military aircraft to take to the sky after 9/11 when we were tasked with photo reconnaisance of Ground Zero for FEMA and SEMO. If you are the type of person who wants a chance to save lives and make a difference in this world, We've Been Waiting for You! We meet every 2nd, 3rd and 4th Saturday of each month from 10:00am to 3:00pm. Majority of your training will be in the field and at mission bases and on various weekends. You will not have to attend every squadron meeting to be active in the program.
11234.title: Emergency Services
11234.org: Civil Air Patrol - Floyd Bennett Composite Squadron

11234.description: We are seeking members to join the Civil Air Patrol in the capacity of Cadet Program Officers. Our organization works with male and female cadets age 12 to 21 and focuses on developing them physically, mentally, and socially through a challenging leadership program. Military drill, customs and courtesies, summer programs, knowledge bowls, aerospace education, search and rescue, disaster relief and moral leadership are just a few of the programs our cadets participate in throughout their careers. Become a mentor to these overachievers! Become someone who's made a difference in a young man/woman's life. No experience in military or education is necessary. We train!
11234.title: Cadet Program Officers
11234.org: Civil Air Patrol - Floyd Bennett Composite Squadron

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2016, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2017, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. High School students, those receiving credit or fulfilling a requirement must attend the training sessions offered. (All other volunteers are encouraged to attend.) GO School Fall Session Dates 2016 October 15, 22, 29 November 5, 12, 19 December 3, 10, 17 GO School Spring Session Dates 2017 January 7, 21, 28 February 4, 11, 25 March 4, 11, 18, 25 April 1, 8, 22, 29 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 5 locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square (for GO Middle school placements ONLY) LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/m6zZKBbv7jo09vA62. The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Volunteer Opportunities\" tab, \"Get Involved\". If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.
10014.title: Help a Child Love to Learn! Tutor Students in Lower Manhattan

10014.description: Audubon New York’s For the Birds! Program is looking for volunteer teachers for all five boroughs of NYC. For the Birds! is an elementary education program that teaches environmental awareness and appreciation of nature through the study of birds. During a 4, 8 or 16-week session, public and private school students in grades 2 through 4 learn about their natural environment through classroom lessons, outdoor field trips, and a conservation project designed to improve bird habitat in the local community. For the Birds! exposes students, usually for the first time, to the idea that their own neighborhoods provide valuable habitat to birds and other urban wildlife. If you are interested in volunteering, please contact Rich Santangelo, For the Birds! Program Director: rsantangelo@audubon.org 212-979-3077.
10014.title: Audubon NY's For the Birds! Education Program

10014.description: St. Joseph’s Soup Kitchen (SJSK) is an all-volunteer, independent charity located in in the Greenwich Village neighborhood of New York City. We operate every Saturday, providing approximately 400 meals to those in need. In addition to provide great meals, we offer clothing distributions, and partner with another organization to provide healthcare and substance abuse assistance. While we have still maintained our original name so our guests know where to get some great grub, we are not religiously affiliated with church, and all folks of all beliefs are welcome to eat, volunteer, and contribute. In June 2015, our organization became an independent 501(c)3, and have made great strides to create a well-organized and well-run soup kitchen, while still maintaining our casual and fun environment. The most important question we ask new volunteers is \"Did you have fun?\" Often we get a positive response asking to come back. But we still have a long way to go. We’re hoping you can help. We need your help to build our development team back up. Pretty much most of the members from our past Development Team moved out of the NYC area for school, job prospects, or other opportunities. So we’re looking for ambitious folks like you to help us The SJSK development team has three core areas of concentration: Outreach to those in need, so they know where they can get a delicious meal in a warm & welcoming environment every Saturday Outreach and raising awareness amongst our neighbor, area business, and local startups so they can support our cause Fundraising for our organizations, from planning events to thinking of new ways to develop recurring and continuous sources of funds We’re looking for volunteers who want to help build a great team and system for all three of our efforts. There are no experience requirements for our team. We just ask that you be passionate and committed to helping us continue our great cause. If you have experience in event planning, fundraising, business development, marketing, web development, or community relations, please consider joining our team. We have some really fun folks. Your work would not only benefit our organization, but many other soup kitchens. SJSK is held up as a model for other soup kitchens to follow, and we hope what we develop here can be easily replicated elsewhere. We ask that you be in the New York City area and able to volunteer on-site. We’re looking for folks to help out for a couple hours on every other Saturday and also be willing to volunteer an 1-2 hours a week on their own for any initiatives. So, if you’re looking for a fun and creative volunteer opportunity that can have a tremendous impact, and are willing to take payment in smiles & Thank Yous, then press that pretty \"I want to help!\" button, and tell us a little about your background and how you think you can help.
10014.title: Join Our Development Team (Outreach & Fundraising)

10014.description: St. Joseph’s Soup Kitchen (SJSK) is an all-volunteer, independent charity located in in the Greenwich Village neighborhood of New York City. We operate every Saturday, providing approximately 400 meals to those in need. In addition to provide great meals, we offer clothing distributions, and partner with another organization to provide healthcare and substance abuse assistance. While we have still maintained our original name so our guests know where to get some great grub, we are not religiously affiliated with church, and all folks of all beliefs are welcome to eat, volunteer, and contribute. In June 2015, our organization became an independent 501(c)3, and have made great strides to create a well-organized and well-run soup kitchen, while still maintaining our casual and fun environment. The most important question we ask new volunteers is \"Did you have fun?\" Often we get a positive response asking to come back. But we still have a long way to go. We’re hoping you can help. We need your help to improve the finance operations of the organization. Our past \"finance guy\", Chris, has become our Executive Director, and needs folks to help develop a great finance function. We’re looking for professionals to help build the finance and accounting capabilities, research and understand our tax-reporting responsibilities, streamline our current reporting timelines, and just help with finance needs. Your work would not only benefit our organization, but many other soup kitchens. SJSK is held up as a model for other soup kitchens to follow, and we hope what we develop here can be easily replicated elsewhere. We’re looking for you to join a team of finance professionals that can help with the following areas: Help us develop an accounting system for the organization ( Currently everything is handled in MS Excel, but we’re investing in Quickbooks this fall) Develop financial reporting for various stakeholders (management, foundations, etc) Help with developing databases, primarily for donors Help with developing system to send tax-deduction letters to our donors IRS and New York State (Tax) Compliance and Reporting Requirements Inventory tracking & management Budgeting & forecasting Research non-profit accounting best-practices Possibly help with improving our \"office\" operations Most importantly: We want your ideas. What we create is all very fluid, and we’ll probably discover needs as we progress We’re looking for volunteers who not only can help develop the \"big picture\" capabilities, but also are willing to help with the \"less sexy\" needs such as data entry, database management, and other \"nuts & bolts\" needs. We require that you have an accounting or finance background with 3+ years experience. CPA, CFA, or other certifcations are a plus. Process development & improvement professionals with 5+ years are welcome. Non-profit background is not required. Unfortunately, we cannot take undergraduate or recent graduates. We need folks who can hit the ground running. We ask that you be in the New York City area and able to volunteer on-site. We’re looking for folks to help out for a couple hours on Saturdays to help building things up, and then (hopefully) have built something great it doesn’t take too much of a time commitment to maintain everything. Also, Chris may want to have Finance Team meeting 1-2 times a month to discuss initiatives. So, if you’re looking for a fun and creative volunteer opportunity that can have a tremendous impact, and are willing to take payment in smiles & Thank Yous, then press that pretty \"I want to help!\" button, and tell us a little about your background and how you think you can help. Also, please provide a resume or LinkedIn profile with your reply.

Volunteer Board Members REPORTS TO: Board President/Founder Qualifications & Skills: Knowledge and skills in one or more areas of board governance: policy, legal, financial management, program development, information technology, marketing, education, counseling volunteer management, grant writing, fundraising and/or human resources. Good communication and writing skills. Length of term: Board of Directors are elected by the membership at the Annual general meeting. Board of Directors serve for a two-year term. Board of Directors may be re-elected for two additional terms. Meetings and Time Commitment: The board of directors meets September through June on the second Thursday of the month, from 6pm to 8pm. Committees in the board meet an average of four times per year, pending their respective work agenda. Board members are asked to attend no less than two special events or meetings per year, as they are determined. Board members are required to donate a minimum of 10 hours per month (as necessary) to the agency. This includes meetings, events and workshops. Expectations of board members: To establish the organization's mission, vision, and direction. To ensure the financial health of the organization. To ensure the organization has sufficient and appropriate human resources. Secure adequate funding. Maintain & update long-range strategic plan. Represent the organization to the public, private and business sectors. Attend and participate in meetings on a regular basis, and special events as well. Be aware and abstain from any conflict of interest. Participate on a standing committee of the board, and serve on ad-hoc committees as necessary. Be alert to community concerns that can be addressed by PAC mission, objectives, and programs. Help communicate and promote PAC mission and programs to the community. Donate significant fiscal contribution to the agency, either through personal means, by hosting an event, or by soliciting contributions from other sources (i.e., friends, businesses, community organizations, foundations, corporations, banks, etc.) If interested, please submit your resume to Johanna DeJesus, Organizational Development Consultant via pac4success@outlook.com. 07201.description: Are you interested in helping a child have a voice? In becoming a CASA volunteer you will become the voice for a child in a court proceeding, which often overlooks the wants, needs and desires of the child. Every year more than half a million abused and neglected children are in need of safe, permanent, nurturing homes. Too many spend years moving from one temporary home to another. They are more likely than other children to face homelessness, unemployment, even prison as adults. That's why Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA) for children are important. CASA was created to make sure the abuse and neglect these children originally suffered at home doesn't continue as abuse and neglect at the hands of the system. As trained advocates, CASA volunteers are appointed by judges to be a voice for these children in court. The result is that a child is placed into a safe, loving home where he/she can thrive. CASA of Union County is currently recruiting for our Spring 2017 class of volunteer advocates. These volunteers will receive intensive training to equip them with the knowledge and skills necessary to navigate their way through the court and child welfare systems. They will learn how to advocate for the best interest of children and make sure that the children receive the services and assistance necessary to ensure that they move as quickly as possible toward safe and permanent homes. Please note: No legal or social service experience is required, but you must be 21 years of age. The CASA training is approximately thirty hours, and the volunteer is required to make an eighteen month commitment. By law, volunteers must have a full criminal background check and fingerprint check, as well as a screening interview before beginning training. We are especially in need of bilingual - particularly Spanish-speaking - volunteers as many of our children who are waiting for a CASA speak little to no English. Information about upcoming info sessions and the training schedule are available on our website: www.casaofunioncounty.org. If you would like more information about how to join our Fall class of volunteer advocates (or a future class) please contact Lisa Poris at lporis@casaofunioncounty.org. Make sure to reach out soon, training starts September 27!
07201.title: Spanish-speaking Volunteer Child Advocate

07201.description: Every year approximately 25,000 young people age of the foster care system with little or no adult support. Aging out of foster care without a life plan, without a permanent place to live, without a job places these young people at great risk. These risks include homelessness, unemployment, substance abuse, criminal involvement and Mental health issues. CASA of Union County is actively recruiting volunteers as part of our Fostering Futures project to become advocate/mentors for older foster youth. These volunteers will work with the young people and help them transition out of the system and ensure that they have the life skills and plans they need to have a safe, stable and successful future. As trained advocate/mentors, CASA volunteers are appointed by judges to be a voice for these children in court. As their advocate, you will be the voice for the young person in court, making sure that the judge knows what is in the young person's best interests. As their mentor you will work with the young person to help them make the best decisions and plans for their futures. The result is that the young person is more likely to achieve positive outcomes after they leave foster care. CASA of Union County is currently recruiting for our Spring 2017 class of volunteers. These volunteers will receive intensive training to equip them with the knowledge and skills necessary to navigate their way through the court and child welfare systems. They will learn how to advocate for the best interest of the young people they are working with and make sure that they receive the services and assistance necessary to lead successful adult lives. A CASA volunteer is paired with one child or sibling set and stays on the case until the young person leaves the system. Please note: No legal or social service experience is required, but you must be 21 years of age. The CASA training is approximately thirty hours, with an additional 8 hour training to work specifically with young people between the ages of 14 and 21. The volunteer is required to make an 18 month commitment. By law, volunteers must have a full criminal background check and fingerprint check, as well as a screening interview before beginning training. We are especially in need of bilingual - particularly Spanish-speaking - volunteers. Information about upcoming info sessions and the training schedule are available on our website: www.casaofunioncounty.org. Or you can reach out to Lisa at lporis@casaofunioncounty.org to find out how you can get involved.
07201.title: Volunteer Advocate for Teens in Foster Care

07201.description: Do you have wisdom to share? Are you 60 or better and enjoy offering guidance to younger generations? Members of the Elder Wisdom Circle are seniors who share their wisdom with young advice seekers from across the world. Via the Internet, Elders answer advice requests at their own convenience, offering young readers personalized and free advice on a wide range of topics - love and relationships, family and child-rearing, career and self-improvement, and more. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, the Elder Wisdom Circle has more than 600 Elders (aged 60 to 105) across North America. The EWC program and our Elders have been featured on ABC, BBC, CBS, FOX, NPR and in such publications as Glamour, the LA Times, Ladies Home Journal, Real Simple, Time & USA Today. We are one of the largest providers of personal advice, with hundreds of thousands of readers. We are looking for seniors in your area to help expand our national reach. Please visit our site at www.ElderWisdomCircle.org and then the 'Offer Advice' tab on the top of the homepage. All advice providers must be 60 or better, no exceptions. Volunteers must complete an application and screening process.

07206.description: NJPC is seeking a paralegal or pro bono attorney, and/or student of law to volunteer (Either in our office or virtual) to help us in reforming the Juvenile Justice System by ending the process of waiving youth 15-17 years of age to the adult prison system, ending solitary confinement for youth, ending the process of transering youth adjudicated delinquent to the adult system without due process and reducing racial and ethnic disparities in NJ's juvenile justice system. NJPC has recently published a data brief - The Incarceration of Children & Youth in New Jersey’s Adult Prison System: New Jersey Youth Justice Initiative - of 472 children and youth, ages 14 to 17, who were waived, sentenced and incarcerated in New Jersey’s adult prison system between 2007 - 2015. NJPC is also interested in having the volunteer help prepare litigations in reference to the brief. The Brief was published nationally and showed:  Gross racial and ethnic disparities: approximately 90% are youth of color; 72% are African American males.  Justice by geography: Rates of incarceration in the adult prison system vary significantly across counties in New Jersey, suggesting that justice depends on where one lives, not on the facts of a given case.  Youth are regularly deprived of due process: Approximately 30% of the 472 youth waived to adult court during the study period spent more than 2 years incarcerated, between their arrest date and their sentencing date, violating their right to a speedy trial.  Youth are regularly put in solitary confinement - especially youth with mental health disorders: Although solitary confinement is known to be psychologically damaging, especially to children, 53% of these youth spent a total of approximately 15,359 days (42 years) in solitary confinement between 2010 and 2015; 5 percent spend over a year there, and about 4 percent spent 2 years or more in solitary. Nearly 70 percent of those placed in solitary had a mental health disorder, with nearly 37% having two or more diagnoses.  Youth suffer abuse while in adult prison: once incarcerated in an adult prison, one in four youth surveyed reported physical abuse; 5% reported sexual abuse. NJPC has also published the first family guide to Navigating the Juvenile Justic: System in New Jersey: A Family GUide which was published nationally.
07206.title: NJPC Youth Justice Initiative: Legal Expertise Needed To Help Reform the Juvenile Justice System

07206.description: Have a blast while sharing your knowledge with eager and excited women! Volunteers will help women with typing, web-surfing, and word processing. It's a fun, relaxed and engaging atmosphere which makes the program great! The agency requests volunteers who are female only to help teach the women participating in the course.
