07206.description: NJPC is currently seeking a volunteer for the NJ Youth Justice Initiative which seeks to end the (1) practice of solitary confinement for juveniles (2) practice of trying, sentencing and incarcerating youth, as young as 14, in the adult prison system in the state of New Jersey (3) practice of sending juveniles who turn age 18 in a juvenile facility to the adult prison system without due process and (4) inability for children and youth with special emotional and behavioral challenges to receive appropriate educational supports under federal IDEA law which should be provided to those children who are part of the special education system and IEP process. Volunteer would be responsible for speaking to parents of children currently incarcerated in the adult prison system to collect further data on their children's demographics, system involvement, education, etc; correspond with incarcerated youth; attend monthly task force meetings; coordinate and attend legislative meetings; review correspondence with children currently incarcerated; correspond/speak with parents of children incarcerated; work with advisory committee to develop press releases, case studies and brochures, and research federal IDEA law for those who were involved in the special education system prior to incarceration.
07206.title: NJPC Youth Justice Initiative

07206.description: NJPC is in need of someone who can coordinate trainings for parents and family members throughout the state raising children with emotional and behavioral challenges who are involved in the mental health, juvenile justice, child welfare and special education systems. Specific help is needed for phone, fax and email registrations, and compiling training/curriculum binders.
07206.title: Training Coordinator Needed for Professional Parent Advocacy Training

07206.description: Volunteers are needed to assist our staff in our Long Term Care facility. Many of our residents find themselves alone and are in need of companionship. As a volunteer, you may assist with meals, chat and reminisce with our residents. You may also help with crafts and games, and help to transport our residents. Make a difference in someones life, VOLUNTEER.
07206.title: Long Term Care - TLC Volunteer

07207.description: We are looking for a media intern to do the following: Two Days a Week Only!!! Can work 5-6 hour shifts Socail Media News letters Email Blasts Photography videos Blogging We are non profit organization and we give out scholarships to high students who want to attend college. So if fit the criteria above is you then we want you on our team. All events are not located in ELizabeth, but you must be willing travel and to stay on board for at least 6 months. Schedule is flexible some nights and weekends for events only Join us and as we help our youth who are the future leaders of tomorrow www.uprisingstarsinc.org
07207.title: Media Intern

07207.description: We are looking for a dependadalbe and reliable individuals to asssit with the following. For TWO Days a Week!!! Only Can work 5-6 hour shifts. 1. Making phones calls 2. Sending emails 3. Powe Point Presentations 4. Ressearching 5. Following up 6. Asssinting with presentations for Career Day at high schools We are looking for people that want to gain more experince in working with a non profit organization and has great computer skills and who is a team player and loves helping youth. Serious inquiries only.
07207.title: Administrative Assistant Intern

07207.description: Serious inquirels only!! Must have 4- 6 hours max a week to give, be committed to our mission, and effiticely communitate witht the fournders!!!! Looking to make an impact on the world? Than join our team. Up Rising Stars Inc. is actively seeking interested and qualified individuals to join our Board of Directors. Board members advise, govern, oversee policy and direction, advocate and fundraise on behalf of us to support the organization’s mission and needs. Board members have a direct and significant impact in improving the lives of the people and families we assist. The mission is to assist young people by providing them resources that will contribute to a higher education so they can achieve success. General Expectations: board members are expected to meet certain standards of board behavior and conduct as outlined below. 1. Know the vision, mission, purposes, goals, policies, programs, services, strengths and needs. 2. Term: Minimum of two years 3. Attend board meetings 4. Keep abreast with trends in the charity sector and other factors that will affect the work us 5. Maintain independence and objectivity and exercise fairness, integrity and ethics in the execution of their duties. 6 Represent us publicly and seek to promote the image and interests whenever appropriate. 7. The board of directors meets bimonthly. Board members are expected to attend all meetings. 8. Read the minutes of meetings and supporting materials 9. Maintain confidentiality of the Board meeting sessions, and support the final majority decision on issues discussed Financial Responsibilities: * Be personally responsible for giving or getting at least $5,000 annually. This can be given personally or by getting others to give in a number of ways. All Board Members must pay dues of 250.00 annually. Qualifications: * Previous experience as a Board Member or a Board Advisor a plus. * Experience in Finance, Accounting, Fundraising, Non-Profit Management, Business Development or Management, Grant Writing, Law, or Marketing and Communications. Experience working internationally a plus. * Established professional and leader in given field of expertise with a network of contacts and ability and willingness to leverage them in support of Up Rising Stars Inc. * Passion for empowerment, entrepreneurship, education, and poverty alleviation. * Ability to attend monthly board meetings * Ability to think critically, plan strategically and remain mission-focused in all decision making processes. * Must maintain confidentiality. * Ability to execute assignments and meet deadlines. * Must have strong organizational, communication, networking, and follow-up skills.
07207.title: Board of Director

07207.description: This is your opportunity to help non-native English speaking citizens practice conversational English. Each week we will introduce a new topic that will help you make a connection and develop a conversation. Conversations and Connections! We are seeking native English speaking volunteers to spend 90 minutes with a non-native English speaking student. VOLUNTEER TIPS TO SUCCESS: As a conversation partner, your main role is to facilitate conversation practice. You are not expected to function as an ESL teacher. Your aim will be to give your student ample speaking practice. Help your student build confidence in expressing their thoughts. A flowing communication of ideas is more important than accurate English usage. Consider these tips to become an effective conversation partner. Speak at a natural pace Elaborate on topics Minimize error correction Include everyone Monitor native language use Have fun! The agency requests only female volunteers to help teach the women participating in the course. NOTE: To participate in this project you must be a Jersey Cares volunteer. To sign up as a Jersey Cares volunteer: 1. Visit www.jerseycares.org 2. Click on \"Log-In\" 3. Click on \"Not a Member? Register\" 4. Fill out all necessary information. 5. Register for a project!
07207.title: Conversations and Connections in Elizabeth

07207.description: The Patient Navigator serves as a contact person to those who have been recently diagnosed with cancer and is currently receiving treatment at a local hospital. The Patient Navigator is trained on how to guide the person through their cancer journey. The Patient Navigator ensures that the person’s needs are met through their initial contact, and provides additional support and information regarding community resources, programs, and services, basic cancer information. The Patient Navigator does not address the medical needs of the patient, rather they serve as a resource to guide them to the proper referral source. No medical advice is given to the patient and/or their caregiver.
07207.title: Patient Navigator

07207.description: Would you like to help ease a family members worry? Why not become an Operating Room Liaison in our new Ambulatory Surgery Center? You will be the person to relay information to family members regarding their loved ones who are undergoing a procedure at Trinitas Regional Medical Center. You will provide compassionate support, reading materials, coffee or tea. Requirements are limited to those who are compassionate.
07207.title: OR Liaison

07207.description: Hospitalization can be overwhelming. That's why we've created this new Volunteer Opportunity. Your responsibilities will include; visiting patients, orienting patients to their surroundings, troubleshooting minor issues, lending a supportive ear. Make a difference for our patients. Be a hero.
07207.title: Volunteer Patient Advocate

07207.description: Do you love to read? Would you like to make a difference in a child's life? Trinitas Hospital participates in the national literacy program - REACH OUT AND READ. The goal of the program is to promote literacy among children between the ages of 6 months and five years. Please, offer to make a difference in a child's life - offer to volunteer to host a story hour at our Pediatric Clinic. YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE.
07207.title: Readers Needed!

07207.description: Are you kind and compassionate? Do you have a great outlook on life? If so, we need you. Volunteers are needed to provide companionship to out-patients as they receive treatment in our brand new, state-of-the-art Cancer Center. You will lend an ear, offer refreshments and give patients hope for a positive outcome! Contact us today!
07207.title: Loving Volunteers Needed for Cancer Survivors

07207.description: The Supervised Visitation Program was established by legislation to provide a forum for children and non-custodial parents to develop or re-establish ongoing familial relationships in a safe environment. The program affords the non-custodial parent the opportunity to spend time with his/her child(ren) in a neutral setting without interference from the custodial parent or other interested parties. The program provides children the opportunity to establish a normal, healthy relationship with the non-custodial parent. Specially trained volunteers and student interns oversee the visits to observe interaction between the child(ren) and parent/guardian and to maintain a safe environment. Each volunteer is assigned a case that runs once a week for 12 week periods. Visits are held usually on a Thursday evenings at the Union County Courthouse Annex or on Saturday Mornings at a community site.
07207.title: Supervised Visitation Program

07207.description: The Juvenile Conference Committees (JCCs) serve under the authority of the Family Division of Superior Court. A JCC is a six to nine member citizen volunteer panel appointed by the Family Division Judge. In a confidential setting, JCC panels hear and decide matters involving alleged juvenile offenders. The juvenile, parent(s) and or guardian(s) and complainant are invited to discuss the offense and related matters with the Committee. The JCC considers the facts, and makes recommendations to the judge for a resolution that would aid in the juvenile's rehabilitation. The program is designed to divert juveniles charged with first or second degree minor offenses to their local JCC, which acts as a community-based arm of the Family Court. Charges that may be heard by the JCC include, but are not limited to: shoplifting, simple assault, attempted theft or theft, criminal mischief, criminal trespass, receiving stolen property and disorderly persons offenses. Program volunteers are required to complete mandatory program-specific training. Volunteers must live in the town in which they serve. High School Students are also sought for this program. We will be placing 1 high school student per town on each committee.
07207.title: Juvenile Conference Committee

07207.description: Child Placement Review (CPR) is a legislatively mandated judicial volunteer program in the Family Division. Boards are comprised of court-appointed citizen volunteers who monitor the cases of all children who are placed outside their homes by the Division of Youth and Family Services. Review Board members monitor the timeliness of case movement, examine case plans, and conduct in-person interviews of involved parties in order to provide judges with recommendations to assist in the critical decision-making process. (Boards are mandated to assess each case from the point of view of the best interest of the child.) The Board's recommendations embrace issues such as how the case is managed and how quickly the child achieves permanency. Review Board members are required to complete mandatory program-specific training.
07207.title: Child Placement Review Board

07205.description: Are you hard working, passionate, and love giving back? Maybe you just need to acquire community service hours and have no place to volunteer? Inda Cares is looking for volunteers to help us on a day to day basis & for volunteers who may be able to help us just for certain events. We have the following volunteer positions open: **Day of (special events) volunteers *Communications and social media manager *Journalist to assist with putting together our quarterly newsletter *Public Relations personnel *Special Events and Campaign manager *Translator/Assistant journalist (Must be fluent in Portuguese and English) Requirements for all with one * are to attend all events and monthly/quarterly volunteer meetings, ability to communicate effectively, and desire to make an impact on people's lives. All volunteer opportunities require a 1-2 hour orientation. We are very flexible, ability to do most work from home during your free time. If you are interested in helping make a difference in the world feel free to contact us.
07205.title: We love volunteers!

07205.description: Marketplace in Hillside is a project dedicated to battling hunger and poverty in our community. The Community FoodBank of New Jersey provides a meaningful volunteer experience in a positive, safe environment that is perfect for individuals, families, and groups of almost any size. Each year the FoodBank relies on more than 25,000 volunteers. Volunteer today and make a measurable difference in the lives of many by, helping sort and organize the food pantry, and package the items for distribution to needy families. NOTE: To participate in this project you must be a Jersey Cares volunteer. To sign up as a Jersey Cares volunteer: 1. Visit www.jerseycares.org 2. Click on \"Log-In\" 3. Click on \"Not a Member? Register\" 4. Fill out all necessary information. 5. Register for a project!
07205.title: Marketplace in Hillside

11021.description: The Village of Great Neck Plaza is seeking volunteers to assist on its Senior Span Program, which provides projects and programs for our senior citizens. We are looking for volunteers to \"Call a Friend,\" making contact with one of our shut in seniors for companionship and friendship. Other similar tasks need volunteers, such as helping a senior with an arts & craft project, reading poetry to seniors, assiting in errands, etc. There are also seminars held regularly at Village Hall. Each seminar is on a separate topic focusing on health, nutrition, aging issues, managing finances, and general senior education. Candidates must have professional expertise in an area and be comfortable with public speaking. For further information, please contact Mayor's Assistant, at (516) 482-4500, or mayorsassistant@greatneckplaza.net.
11021.title: Senior Span Volunteers

11023.description: Protect our environment and the special place in which we live! Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL) wants you! As a volunteer, you’ll be a member of the fastest growing and most effective climate advocacy group. You will work with concerned New York citizens to slow the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our beautiful ecosystems, livelihoods and way of life. Please respond to our posting for an invitation to learn more. You will: Meet with Congressional leaders. Write letters to the editors and op-eds. Meet with local media. Educate your community about global warming and legislative solutions. We provide: Monthly national conference calls with expert guest speakers. Weekly skill building sessions. On-line network with CCL volunteers across the U.S. National conference and lobby week in D.C. Volunteers commit to an average of 4-6 hours a month. Some of our volunteers dedicate more time than that. We hold no upper limit on your dedication to a stable climate and livable world. To learn more about us, please join an Introductory Conference Call. The next call is Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Pacific/6:00 p.m. Mountain/7:00 p.m. Central/8:00 p.m. Eastern. This is an opportunity to learn about CCL. It is one hour, and there will be opportunities to ask questions. The conference call number is 1-866-642-1665, passcode 440699#.
11023.title: Sustainable Climate Environment Advocate Great Neck NY

06820.description: An Hour a Week is Good for the Soul and that's all it takes to spread some good cheer. One hour of reading for this legally blind lady will make this lady's day special. If you are available between 10 and noon on Monday, Tuesday or Thursday, or Saturday/Sunday before 2 p.m., this is the spot for you. Requirements to be a good volunter: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance;
06820.title: An Hour a Week is Good for the Soul
06820.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

06820.description: P2P Darien has a team of \"van volunteers\" who expertly visit various organizations and stores to pick up and deliver donated merchandise. We are seeking people to join this great group of P2P ambassadors! Volunteers are needed Monday through Friday mornings from 9-12. Must be able to lift at least 50lbs! Our team meets up at P2P then heads out with an organized 'to-do' list. You'll visit local schools, stores, and community organizations. Make a difference - help us get valuable resources to those in need. No special driver's license required.
06820.title: Help us run errands -Join our Van Crew team!

06820.description: P2P Darien has a team of dedicated and savvy volunteers who visit the CT Food Bank in Stamford and Fairfield weekly to shop and supply our Food Pantry. Get ready to sort through an assortment of wonderful food (perishable and non-perishable) to find what we need to serve our clients. It takes about 2 hours to complete the shop and return to P2P in Darien where our team unloads and sorts. Volunteers are needed weekday mornings.
06820.title: Shop Weekly at the Connecticut Food Bank!

06820.description: Help your neighbors in need! Person-to-Person's reception volunteers work as a team of 4 from 9 a.m. - 12:30 p.m. or 12:30 - 4 p.m. on weekdays. P2P requires a weekly commitment to volunteer in Reception in order to best serve our clients. Reception volunteers will greet clients, donors and guests. Volunteers also assist social service agencies with requests and appointments. Exceptional customer service skills and computer literacy, a must! Ability to speak Spanish or Creole, a plus!
06820.title: Service with a Smile - Receptionist

06820.description: Person-to-Person is looking for high school age volunteers to join our Youth Group! High school students are welcome to join us weekly on Thursdays from 4 - 6 p.m. and Saturday mornings from 9 a.m. - 12 p.m. during the school year. Students may volunteer for all or part of the time. Students from many different local high schools make up our Youth Group. Volunteers will have the opportunity to assist in the clothing center, sort food in the pantry, make appointments for clients, and interact with donors. If you are interested, please contact Janet King at janetking@p2pHelps.org.
06820.title: High School Student Volunteer Opportunity!

06820.description: Provide companionship and support for Darien seniors who would like more socialization. Willingness to visit with senior and share activities such as: reading aloud, playing games, cards, watching television together, doing puzzles or simply having a conversation. Must have own transportation.
06820.title: Friendly Visitor

06820.description: Provide seniors who need help with small tasks in their home. Perform small chores around the house such as: changing a light bulb or battery, watering plants. Must have own transportation.
06820.title: Friendly Helper

06820.description: Help drive Darien seniors to appointments during hours and/or locations not covered by At Home In Darien service. Help seniors safely to and from the car. Clean and valid driver's license and personal vehicle needed as well as auto insurance with a minimum coverage of $500,000.
06820.title: Friendly Driver

06820.description: Help homebound seniors with grocery shopping. Volunteer will go to the senior's home according to agreed upon date and time, picks up grocery list and money. Volunteer will do shopping, return with groceries, receipt and any change and help put groceries away.
06820.title: Friendly Shopper

06820.description: Person-to-Person’s Food Pantry supplies families in need with emergency food. Our families are referred by over 20 social service agencies in the community or by one of our six social workers. Volunteers stock the shelves and pack food orders according to shopping lists, based on the Food Pyramid. Volunteers are also involved in organizing food drives at local schools, churches and synagogues and sorting the food received in bulk after delivery. Volunteers coordinate the delivery of bread, meat and produce from local suppliers. Volunteer hours vary, but are flexible.
06820.title: Food Pantry Volunteer

06820.description: Person-to-Person’s Clothing Center provides donated clothing and small household goods to clients. Six clients visit the clothing center every half hour to shop. Volunteers greet donors and clients, receive donations and give receipts to donors. Volunteers sort and hang clothing and maintain the organization and cleanliness of the Clothing Center. Volunteer hours vary, but are flexible.
06820.title: Clothing Center Volunteer

07924.description: Make new friends and do your part to help make NJ a better place for people and wildlife! Help lead nature hikes, enter critical database info, assist with mailings or grounds maintenance, welcome visitors to our festival booth, or help with our website... your special skill is just what we need to help us achieve our mission. The map shows our Bernardsville HQ but we need your help all over NJ at our statewide offices and nature centers! Please visit the volunteer page of our website and apply today at: http://www.njaudubon.org/SectionAboutNJAS/VolunteerOpportunities.aspx
07924.title: Help Keep NJ Green with NJ Audubon       Year-Round Opportunities!

06824.description: The primary responsibility of our museum attendants is to ensure the safety of the artwork. In addition, we ask that our attendants have some knowledge about the works on display in order to respond to visitors’ questions, be willing to enforce gallery policies and to follow necessary procedures in case of an emergency.
06824.title: Museum Attendent

06824.description: You and your sonorous voice are needed to read to the blind in your community! Six opportunities exist for readers, friendly visitors or mail assistants to help their neighbors. If you are available during the earlier part of the day, you could read the daily paper if not, perhaps you can be a friendly visitor after work hours or on the weekend. We can find the right fit for your schedule. Requirements to be a great volunteer include: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance; a minimum of $50/100k liability and $5,000 of property damage coverage.
06824.title: Read to the Blind in Your Community
06824.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

07928.description: JerseySTEM grows a garden to teach the kids about planting and gardening. We also use it to increase the kids sensitivity to environmental issues. The kids meet once a week and we need volunteers to tend to the garden in between - some light weeding and watering.
07928.title: Gardening with kids

07928.description: JerseySTEM is seeking the help of adults interested in gardening to teach kids grade 2-8 about the art of gardening. We will follow the 4H curriculum. Expect 2-3 hours of commitment per week.
07928.title: Gardening with Kids

07928.description: Help High School students master concepts of JAva programing larned in Class. Help them get familiar with Elicpse Java IDE. 2 hours per week during the Week-end of Evenings. NEed working knowledge of Java and preferebly working knowledge of Eclipse.
07928.title: Java / Eclipse Tutor for High School Students

07928.description: ChathamSTEM needs help for a small surveting job to support a request for a use variance for a warehouse that will be converted into an educaiton space. Time sensitive very simple job that requies a licensed surceyor so that the volunteer archotects can finish the plans.
07928.title: Land Surveyor

07928.description: ChathamSTEM/JerseySTEM , a local non profit prmoting Science and Technology educaiton, is engaged into a project to convert a fromer Machnine Tools shop into a maker space. We need the help of a Land Sureyor to submit the paperwork for the use variance to the Board of Adjustment of Chatham borough
07928.title: Land Surveyor

07928.description: ChathamSTEM is looking for educators, Graduate Students and college professors wiling to coach students taking AP Biology in 2015/2016. You will be assigned a group of 3 students that meet Saturdays afternoons and that you will be asked to mentor. The program will forllow the AP Biology Course curriculum. The commitment is for 8 weeks (starting September) renewable 4 times if available.
07928.title: Biology/AP Biology Coach for High school Girls

07928.description: ChathamSTEM's maker Club is starting a Controlled Environment Agriculuture program using Gardening/Horticuluture/Hydropononics/Aquaponics as a support for systems monitoring and control. Whether you want to contrinute with you knowledge, advice or time, please send us a message. thanks
07928.title: Horticuluture/Hydroponics/Aquaponics

07928.description: Help Middle and High School stidents prepare for the American Match Competitions 8, 10 and 12 MathCount is a Middle School math competition The AMC 10 is a 25-question, 75-minute, multiple choice examination in secondary school mathematics containing problems which can be understood and solved with algebra and geometry concepts. The AMC 12 is a 25-question, 75-minute, multiple choice examination in secondary school mathematics containing problems which can be understood and solved with pre-calculus concepts. Two different versions of the contests are given on two dates, about two weeks apart, in February. Each AMC 10 and AMC 12 contest contain about 12 of the same math problems.
07928.title: Mathematics coaching for AMC10-12

07928.description: Looking for a volunteer to coach a Maker Club on Arduino / Raspeberry Pi applications. Meets once a week on weekends.
07928.title: Arduino Club / Maker Club

07928.description: Help Coach a group of school-age girls in their journey to learn computer programing. Teach any language from Alice, to Java, Python,... Flexible schedule on an after-school basis.
07928.title: Girls Who Code in Chatham

07928.description: ChathamSTEM organizes free(*) afterschool Science, Math and Technology programs 3pm-5pm hours in the school buildings. The teachers are volunteer high schoolers. To be able to hold the classes we need to be able to have an Adult in charge in the classroom while the highschooler is teaching the kids grade K to 8. Weekdays 3pm-5pm (*) or nominal fee
07928.title: Chaperone K-8 students after school (3pm-5pm) in Chatham, NJ

07928.description: Do you like Making, Electronics, circuit boards,....familiar or want tolearn about Arduinos, Raspbery Pis,.. want to share with peer Makers and the new generation. Help us bring a maker space to Chatham by volunteering o Saturday afternoon an month...
07928.title: Maker Space in Chatham

07928.description: ChathamSTEM is seeking mentors/coaches to assist a Technology teacher in building a high school robotics team. Commitment involves once a week 6pm-8pm (Fridays) or 9am-12pm (Saturdays) chaperoning of students building Robots at the Chatham High School.
07928.title: Help Coach a Girls Robotics Team

07928.description: Work with staff from Great Swamp Outdoor Education Center or Pyramid Mountain on programs and events, leading hikes or operating the visitors centers.
07928.title: Outdoor Education

10532.description: Join The Jewish Board on January 12th and February 9th from 5:30 - 7pm for a series of 1:1 Resume Writing Workshops with the teen residents of our Westchester campus. You can help them organize their resumes as they prepare for their futures. THe Jewish Board's Westchester campus has three programs: Hawthorne Cedar Knolls Treatment Center, The Jerome M. Goldsmith Center for Adolescent Treatment (RTF) & The Sally & Anthony Mann Center (RTF). Each program provides residential treatment for adolescents and young adults, ages 12-22.
10532.title: Resume Writing Coach- Westchester
10532.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10532.description: Our Westchester campus has three programs: Hawthorne Cedar Knolls Treatment Center, The Jerome M. Goldsmith Center for Adolescent Treatment (RTF) & The Sally & Anthony Mann Center (RTF). Each program provides residential mental health treatment for adolescents and young adults, ages 12-22. We are looking for volunteers with licensed pet therapy animals to visit our campus to spend some quality time with our teen residents. Spending time with animals is an incredibly therapeutic activity for our residents, and rain or shine, it is always a great way to make them smile.
10532.title: Pet Therapist - Westchester (Hawthorne)
10532.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10532.description: Our Westchester campus has three programs: Hawthorne Cedar Knolls Treatment Center, The Jerome M. Goldsmith Center for Adolescent Treatment (RTF) & The Sally & Anthony Mann Center (RTF). Each program provides residential treatment for adolescents and young adults, ages 12-22. Adolescents participate in intensive milieu therapy, individual, family, and group psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, special education and vocational training, all in an open setting. We offer two vocational and life skill training volunteer opportunities at our Westchester campus programs. They are: 1. Volunteer Vocational Trainer As a volunteer vocational trainer, you can talk to our teens about your career path and help them gain life and job skills to be successful in the workforce. Potential Discussion Topics: -- What important decisions were made along the way? -- Professionally, how did you get to where you are? -- Were there important people that guided your career decision(s)? -- Required schooling/training for current position? -- What is interesting about your profession? Teachable Skills: -- Resume/CV writing -- How to interview, for example: Phone, email, written and in-person communication techniques, do's and don'ts of interviewing, or mock interview practice 2. Host a Bring-A-Student-To-Work Day As a Bring-A-Student-To-Work Day host, you can provide a fun, hands-on, interactive experience for our residents by hosting them at your office. The exposure to an exciting workplace is truly a once in a lifetime opportunity for our students. Some Ideas: -- Take a teen (or group of teens) on a tour of your office -- Introduce them to key people -- Have colleagues present a meaningful workshop (topics to vary) Currently residents have specifically expressed interest in the following job industries: Culinary, Music Recording and Production, Veterinary Studies, Arts, Technology, Finance, Athletics, Beautician and more!
10532.title: Vocational and Life Skill Trainer- Westchester
10532.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10532.description: Our Westchester campus has three programs: Hawthorne Cedar Knolls Treatment Center, The Jerome M. Goldsmith Center for Adolescent Treatment (RTF) & The Sally & Anthony Mann Center (RTF). Each program provides residential treatment for adolescents and young adults, ages 12-22. Adolescents participate in intensive milieu therapy, individual, family, and group psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, special education and vocational training, all in an open setting. As a GED Tutor, you will help our teens one-to-one or in a small group setting to assist them in passing the GED exam. Volunteers needed on Mondays from 5-6pm.
10532.title: GED Tutor- Westchester
10532.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10532.description: Our Westchester campus has three programs: Hawthorne Cedar Knolls Treatment Center, The Jerome M. Goldsmith Center for Adolescent Treatment (RTF) & The Sally & Anthony Mann Center (RTF). Each program provides residential treatment for adolescents and young adults, ages 12-22. Adolescents participate in intensive milieu therapy, individual, family, and group psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, special education and vocational training, all in an open setting. Do you do what you love? Do you have hobbies and passions that can translate into skills for our teens? As a Team Activity Leader, you will be able to turn a hobby or passion into a unique and rewarding volunteer opportunity. We are looking for volunteers (individual or group) that are interested in working with teens and teaching them that a passion such as music, cosmetology, dance, arts visual or performing arts, or cooking. These are valuable skills for our teen clients to develop, and you may even help one of our clients discover a new lifelong passion of their own.
10532.title: Team Activity Leader- Westchester
10532.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10532.description: Our Westchester campus has three programs: Hawthorne Cedar Knolls Treatment Center, The Jerome M. Goldsmith Center for Adolescent Treatment & The Sally & Anthony Mann Center. Each program provides residential treatment for adolescents and young adults, ages 12-22. Adolescents participate in intensive milieu therapy, individual, family, and group psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, special education and vocational training, all in an open setting. We are looking for volunteers to collaborate with us and run a donation drive for the adolescent and adult residents of our Westchester campus programs. They are always very grateful for new clothing, bedding and toiletries, as well as batteries, electronic devices, gift cards, ports/theater event tickets or museum passes. We will collaborate with you to create a timeline, goal, and techniques on how to reach out for donations. This is a one-time group opportunity that is great for families or community groups; schedule is dependent on the agreed-upon length of the donation drive. The donations will go towards our three Westchester campus programs, but the donation drive can occur anywhere in the five boroughs or Westchester.
10532.title: Run a Donation Drive- Westchester
10532.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10532.description: The Jewish Board's Westchester campus has three programs: Hawthorne Cedar Knolls Treatment Center, The Jerome M. Goldsmith Center for Adolescent Treatment & The Sally & Anthony Mann Center. Each program provides residential treatment for adolescents and young adults ages 12-22. Adolescents participate in intensive milieu therapy, individual, family, and group psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, special education and vocational training, all in an open setting. As a Holiday Party or Special Event host, you could invite your family, friends or coworkers to help throw a fun pizza party, game night or holiday party at our Westchester Campus. Or, perhaps you have a favorite movie you would like to watch with our students and facilitate a meaningful discussion group (about storyline, conflicts, characters, etc.). The possibilities are endless, and we will collaborate with you to assist with planning your event. 11803.description: AHRC Nassau is a non-profit agency which serves the developmentally and intellectually disabled. AHRC Nassau has existed for nearly 70 years and is a leader in the care and service of this population. Currently we are looking for volunteers to assist with our community based day habilitation program. We have 33 \"hubsites\" located throughout Nassau County and are looking for volunteers who would be available sometime Monday through Friday starting from 8am to 3pm. Day Habilitation Volunteers assist our program by engaging the people that we serve in meaningful activities. These activities could include arts & crafts, computer skills, reading groups, photography clubs, cooking lessons, yoga or light aerobics, music, pet therapy or any other passion that a volunteer may want to share with the people at one of our hubsites. The minimum age to volunteer at one of our hubsites is 16 years old and all volunteers are required to complete an application and meet with the volunteer coordinator for training and orientation. OPWDD (the Office of People with Developmental Disabilities) requires that all day habilitation volunteers be screened for tuberculosis and receive a full criminal background check. The cost for the screening and background check are covered by AHRC Nassau.
11803.title: Assist Day Habilitation Services

11803.description: Provide companionship to a homebound senior living in the Plainview-Old Bethpage community. Volunteers should be able to commit to a weekly hour-long visit for at least six months. Our Friendly Visiting Program gives our clients a chance to connect with a listener, and provides volunteers with a meaningful way to give back to their communities. Our social worker will match each volunteer and senior based on mutual interests. In most cases, long lasting and mutually rewarding relationships develop. Interview, training, references and background check are required.
11803.title: Friendly Visiting

11803.description: . Volunteer drivers are men and women willing to share their time and vehicle to help meet the transportation needs of seniors. Transport a senior living in the Plainview-Old Bethpage area to local medical appointments, food shopping or local errands. Qualifications include: a valid driver’s license, proof of insurance, a good driving record, and must be age 21 or over. All trips are within the local community. Interview, training, references and background check are required.
11803.title: Volunteer Drivers for Seniors

11801.description: Can your dog become a C.A.T.T.? We are looking for beloved pets, retirees from breeding or competition, released service dogs, registered therapy dogs and/or rescues. We welcome Puppies (beginning at 12 weeks) to Adults! Qualify your dog for our innovative canine-assisted activities program where children and adults come to interact with our certified dogs. You and your dog will engage with our participants (with and without special needs) who come to DogAbility Center by appointment. Our certified canine teams are taught to manage a small obstacle course, ride in a wagon, play tug games, run relay races, play \"find the ball\" and other assorted tricks, as well as assist in \"fear of dogs\" sessions. Very young puppies are introduced gradually in our supervised Puppy Pals activity. To become certified, all teams must pass an initial evaluation and then attend training sessions where our DogAbility Certified Training Staff will offer personal assistance. See website for fees ~ Fully insured

11801.description: Are you a professional who wants to give back? A retiree or stay-at-home parent looking to keep your skills fresh? A college student hoping to build your resume? DogAbility Center is looking for skilled volunteers and individuals with just the right expertise to join our team. We are looking for interested individuals with initiative to help steer the direction of our organization with your time and talents. Your skills will help form our team and will ensure that our organization remains effective and carries forward our mission of bettering the lives and well-being of children and adults of all abilities in our community. We are seeking volunteers for the following reasons: To increase awareness and understanding of our organization through the work that our volunteers do. To give our volunteer staff additional manpower to do more work and get as much done as possible within the confines of our budget. To act together to achieve a shared purpose.

11801.description: We are looking for special families to open their hearts and homes and join our family of puppy raisers. Four-month-old Bosley is a puppy with a special mission. One day, he will provide enhanced independence and mobility to a person with disabilities - whether they're blind or visually impaired, or have a disability other than blindness. But Bosley isn't growing up at the Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind. Each year, the Guide Dog Foundation breeds about 300 exceptional puppies, and it's vital that Bosley and other pups like him spend the first year of their lives with surrounded by the love and security of volunteer foster families called puppy walkers. Puppy walkers help Foundation puppies grow up to be confident dogs. What's involved in raising a Guide Dog Foundation puppy? Bosley went to live with his puppy walkers when he was about nine weeks old. He's learning basic obedience and social skills while being exposed to many different situations. People who raise Guide Dog Foundation puppies say it is the most rewarding thing they've ever done. Puppy raisers come from everywhere - stay-at-home moms or dads, teachers, college students, retirees, people with flexible work environments - and are crucial members of the Guide Dog Foundation family. By opening their hearts and homes to a puppy, a puppy raiser plays a crucial role in helping a person with disabilities live an independent life. Every puppy walker family works with a Guide Dog Foundation puppy adviser, who is available to answer questions and offer guidance and support. When he is about 14 months old, Bosley will return to the Guide Dog Foundation's Smithtown campus to begin his training as a guide or service dog. Puppy raisers will admit it's tough to say good-bye, but when they see the pup they raised take its place at the side of someone with disabilities, the ache they feel turns pride. There are puppies waiting now to join your loving home for a chance to start their careers. For more info, call or e-mail the Guide Dog Foundation's Puppy Department at 866-282-8046 or puppies@guidedog.org. Or visit www.GuideDog.org and click on the Puppy Program link. For over 60 years, the Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind has provided guide and service dogs and training free of charge to people with disabilities who seek the enhanced mobility, independence, and companionship only an assistance dog can provide.
11801.title: Must Love Dogs in Nassau County! Seeking volunteers to raise puppies!!
11801.org: Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind Inc. & America's VetDogs - the Veteran's K-9 Corps

11804.description: We need costumed volunteers to work in our living history museum to interpret life as it was in a nineteenth century farming community on Long Island. 11201.description: Love Yourself Project is looking a grant writer and some administration duties/social media, and volunteer coordinator and ambassadors. The Love Yourself Project is a 501(c)(3) non-profit arts and education organization providing community programs which promote self-awareness, self-acceptance, self-esteem and skill building. It is our belief that with a strong relationship to the self, every individual can contribute to a future with loving regard for all living beings and the environment. Beginning Nov 19, 2010, the Love Yourself team took to the streets and subways of New York City greeting people with messages of kindness and love, distributing over 500 \"Love Yourself\" stickers and hand-folded hearts, and encouraged people to engage in a conversation about self-love. Since then, similar events have been held in Pakistan, Paris, Luxembourg, West Africa, Florida, Netherlands, Massachusetts, Australia, Iceland, England and Stockholm. We currently have distributed over 750,000 stickers. In 2011, the Project began working with children at The Earth School in NYC. Team members helped youngsters (ages 5-12) make origami hearts and facilitated discussions about what it means to 'love yourself’. The origami hearts were featured in the \"1,000 Hearts\"Exhibition. To create the \"1,000 Hearts\"exhibition, the team collected 1,000 hand-folded origami hearts from people all around the world. Participants shared something they love about themselves and folded the paper into a heart shape. The hearts and messages were presented both visually and aurally. Messages from the hearts are continuously being posted via Twitter. We just celebrated our 5th year anniversary at BAM FISHER 2015 with 5,000 hearts of self love messages. Help us continue our campaign for 2020 with 10,000 Hearts. The Love Yourself Project has hosted: The Festival of New Ideas with The New Museum in NYC. Untapped Love (lower Manhattan business to find out how they give back to the community.) 2010-12, educational events with Rush Arts Educational Program, NYC, Slyfest - The Good Neighborhood Project, Hannah Senesh School, Carol Gardens Brooklyn , Safe Horizon Organization, NYC, Taap at Fashion Industry High School NY, Nest School East Village, 2012-13, Flow12- Randall’s Island Park, Governors Island- Figment , feeding the homeless, Teen Pregnancy Prevention Program Grand Street Settlement NYC, Interim House, Providence RI., 2014 Barnes and Noble, Coalition for Hispanic Family Health Fair, Brooklyn Museum, Academy of Young Writes East NY, Children’s Workshop School NYC, Women’s Wellness Day and Jackie Robinson / Central Park East Middle School. Isaac Center, Flushing Queens Library, Funny Faces at Brooklyn Promenade & Coney Island Brooklyn and VIBE Theater Brooklyn. Queens Art Intervention, Heath Gallery Harlem NY, The LGBT Center NY NY, 2015 Brooklyn Academy of Music 5,000 Hearts, BGSQD NY NY, Volunteers for the Arts, NY NY Sesame Sprouts, Queens NY, City Chemist, Trader Joe’s Brooklyn NY, Fabio Scalia Gallery, Brooklyn NY, St. Joseph’s High School Brooklyn NY, Medgar Evers college Prep. H.S. Brooklyn NY 2016 City Museum of New York, Jubilee Senior Center, FigmentNYC, LGBTQ Brooklyn, Poly Prep middle school, Brooklyn, Brownsville Creation Center, Union Arts Center With the help of others and our commitment to changing the way we think about ourselves, we invite you to create an event in your country, neighborhood and schools. We look forward to hearing from you. Thank you for your time and consideration.
11201.title: Are You A Grant Writer? Enjoy the Arts? Want to Help Us? Join the Love Yourself Project!

11201.description: *** Volunteers needed June 3 & 4 on Governors Island ** The Love Yourself Project (LYP) is a non-profit organization committed to utilizing the arts to celebrate and empower communities around the world, to spread a message of unconditional self-love, both domestically and internationally. We are currently seeking part-time and full-time dedicated volunteers to assist us in donor development, marketing, public relations, arts education and fundraising. We seek self-motivated, positive individuals with strong computer knowledge and effective communication talents to join our organizational culture and team-oriented environment. We offer volunteers the opportunity for hands-on experience within a start-up non-profit organization, where significant personal and professional growth and development is possible. LYP Volunteers are responsible, but not limited to the following: Provide program support for all LYP Programs by working alongside staff, teaching artists, classroom teachers and students. Research and develop educational and art-based materials to correspond with the LYP mission. Develop and promote the mission, vision and values of The Love Yourself Project. Develop themes, procure supplies and execute ideas related to the Love Yourself Project. Keep adequate supplies, brochures and other materials. Serve as the point of contact for the LYP team. LYP Volunteers are unique in every way! We are like minded and hold each other accountable for being their best. A good sense of humor, a strong back bone, curious, make things happen and respect for all living things. If you're interested in participating in the Love Yourself Project, please contact Michael Mut at michael@loveyourselfproject.org Thank you for your interest in the Love Yourself Project, we look forward to meeting you!
11201.title: Love Yourself Project (LYP) Volunteers

11201.description: The TalkOnDiabetes Foundation, a 501(c)3 tax-exempt organization, was created to encourage personal and positive development within the diabetic community. Our website was created to provide access to objective information and data reports about past and current trends relative to diabetes. We believe this is the most constructive way to show people with diabetes and diabetes-related conditions what is happening in today's ever-changing world. We are presently looking for individuals who would be interested in volunteering as Content Translators. Though our geographic location is in New York, part of our mission is to offer helpful information to all those who request and require for their own situations involving diabetes. Many people from many backgrounds need to learn about diabetes and how to live with it and learn from their own encounters, and the TalkOnDiabetes' website (www.talkondiabetes.org) gives people who may come across language barriers the possibility of gathering positive and insightful data for their own usage. This condition has reached pandemic levels, and we believe that anyone who wishes to know how to handle diabetes should have the option to do so, in their own native language if possible. Applicants must be able to translate to and from English with the following languages naturally and fluently: Italian, Spanish, Creole, Chinese, Russian, Japanese, French, and Arabic. All interested parties must be over 18, and possess at least a High School Diploma. College students are encouraged to apply. Good communication skills, and the ability to use Word and Acrobat to utilize for translated text. Content translators will provide accurate conversions of web content and marketing materials, and will be assisting our Program Development area with registration guidelines and some agenda information. There is a three month requirement, consisting of at least 10 hours per week. This is a volunteer (unpaid) position. Please send your resume to volunteers@talkondiabetes.org.
11201.title: Content Translator

11201.description: Since 1971, Heights and Hills has helped Brooklyn's older adults age successfully in their communities with independence, dignity and grace. Our Friendly Visiting program matches volunteers of all ages with home-bound and/or socially isolated seniors for weekly companionship - volunteers and clients go on walks, run errands, cook together, play cards, craft, talk about music, art, sports, politics or whatever else they find they have in common! Whenever possible Friendly Visitor volunteers are matched with seniors in their own neighborhood. Getting started is easy: fill out a short application and come into our office in downtown Brooklyn to speak with someone from the Volunteer Program. We look forward to hearing from you!

11201.description: Seniors in nursing facilities tend to have few visitors, but with a few hours of your time, you can provide the social interaction that is important to keeping their spirits soaring. There are a variety of projects with seniors such as knitting, gardening, and even teaching basic computer skills. Just a few hours of your time can help brighten up a senior’s week. 11205.description: Volunteer to make a difference in children's lives through the sport of tennis! We are looking for individuals 16+ to supervise and engage youngsters ages 5 through 15 in a brand new indoor Winter Tennis program at Pratt Institute. Tennis experience is helpful but not required. KCTL’s inaugural Winter Tennis Season begins Saturday, February 4, 2017. The season includes six classes and two field trips. We ask that all on-court volunteers: Take part in our January 26 training session/social event Commit to at least four Winter sessions. Classes will be held on February 4, February 11, February 25, March 11, and March 18 from 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM and on April 1 from 9:00 AM to 12:00 PM at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. Field Trips take place on March 4 and March 25. Locations and logistics TBA. Are comfortable with and enjoy working with groups of children Are excited to learn about being a role model Note: Previous tennis experience is helpful, but not required! TO REGISTER: Fill out the form at www.kingscountytennisleague.org/volunteer and specify that you are interested in the Winter Season.

11205.description: A Free Bird is a 501(C)(3)non-profit organization based in New York City. Our focus is to provide children, ages 6-18 who are patients or survivors of juvenile cancer, the opportunity to explore their artistic passions and give them the strength to fight their disease. We believe that artistic expression is critical for healing! A Free Bird supports children affected by cancer in their exploration of art, music, acting, poetry, writing, singing and any other artistic passion they may have. We are seeking a Marketing Intern who can commit 5-10 hours per week for minimum of 3 months (50 hours). Position is non-paid but can apply for school internship credit. This is not a filing and get coffee type internship. You will have REAL responsibilities and acquire marketable experience Responsibilities: Assist with daily project management of digital and traditional marketing, working with Marketing Coordinator on strategy, analytics and logistics Coordinate the working document to track projects cross-departmentally Assist in Managing timelines for e-appeals, campaigns, cultivations and optimizations (such as donor pages, homepage and confirmations); Assist with Managing timelines for vetting of direct mail pieces for six different appeals monthly; Assist with coordinating the Integrated Marketing Calendar of all fundraising and cultivation activities; Liaison with the Programs, Graphic Design/Web, Fundraising and PR departments Draft marketing copy for brochures, posters, presentations and other organizational collateral; Coordinate with the Graphic Design and Web department with copy for creative projects; Performing other responsibilities as may be required. Qualifications: Excellent writing and editing skills with ability to produce polished and compelling copy on tight deadlines Creativity in tapping and cultivating mainstream media and social networking communities A positive, energetic and proactive multi-tasker who can work independently or very collaboratively, as part of a team Ability to work effectively, efficiently, diplomatically and calmly in a high-pressure environment on issues that are often complex and politically sensitive Strong listener, with a high degree of professionalism and flexibility, including the ability to prioritize and effectively manage assignments in a timely fashion
11205.title: Marketing Volunteer

11207.description: You can empower a child to believe in themselves, and fulfill their potential. Genesis Homes is located at 330 Hinsdale Ave, East New York conveniently near the Subways L, 2,3,4,5. The mentoring program provides support to the residents children ages 8-14 through activities promoting healthy choices, leadership and building self-esteem. They will be meeting every other Saturday from 10:30 AM - 12:30 PM. Mentoring USA's mission is to create sustained and supportive mentor relationships for children in need ages 7-22. The program matches youth with trained adult mentors who can guide them in developing better self-esteem, creating healthy relationships, and making positive life choices. Mentors and mentees meet in a supervised environment at a set time and location. Mentoring USA partners with schools, community centers, foster care agencies, and other non-profits. All sites are supported by MUSA Program Managers who work directly with Site Supervisors at each location to ensure that the programs run smoothly. Contact: recruitment@mentoringusa.org 212-400-8290 All mentors must be 21 and older and willing to undergo a background check and screening. How to Apply: Complete the Mentor Application: http://www.mentoringusa.org/become_a_mentor/Mentor_Application
11207.title: You Matter! Mentor! in Brooklyn

11207.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
11207.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 158, Brooklyn)

11207.description: The community and Brooklyn Public Library needs you. If you are a leader, having leadership experience, and can work with minimal supervision, becoming an executive on our Friends Group Board will be excellent for you. We will be the backbone of Saratoga Branch Library AND Spring Creek Library ; position will last at least 1 year. STATUS Executives will work sporadically; a lot of work will be from home or via virtual teams. You must come to mandatory meeting, at least 6 per year. Position Description : Board needed includes: vice president, treasurer and secretary. * This description is general and more specific duties will be discussed * Data entry, volunteer hours tracking * Website content management and editing * Event planning and management , possibly * Event promotion * Grant writing and organization , depending on position * Strong communication skills (verbal and written). * Strong attention to detail. * Able to listen and communicate effectively with community members of diverse backgrounds. * Dependable and punctual. * Self-directed and willing to take initiative. * Computer literate (familiar with Microsoft Office suite). * Currently seeking volunteers at least 16 years of age. Volunteer Benefits * Training and experience with managerial, back-end, and administrative procedures. * Opportunity to meet new people and help enhance Brooklyn neighborhoods. * Networking and community building opportunities. * Gain an awesome reference working with the Brooklyn Public Library and BkMSCC. Location: Spring Creek Branch, Home based, & At office in Ocean Hill, Possible Event Outings
11207.title: LIBRARY FIENDS GROUP EXECUTIVE BOARD - Spring Creek

11206.description: In conjunction with a new awards program at Brighter Choice Community Elementary School in Brooklyn, the school would like a video to be shown of the awardees along with testimonials from teachers, staff and their parents. We need volunteer to film students, teachers, administrators and parents in an ongoing effort to collect footage for use on the website and in archives. Video production experience and equipment for pre and post production are required. This can be a recurring or one-time per production opportunity.
11206.title: Filmmaker for Video Project

11206.description: Educated Little Monsters: Dance Instructor Position ELM Dance includes a mix of ballet, lyrical/contemporary, and Hip Hop styles, in small classes with 3-8 students, ranging from 7-17 years old. The program is very youth-led, students are encouraged to choreograph their own pieces. Students have the opportunity to share their work at youth showcase events every few months. The ELM dancers are very creative and driven; what they need is an expert to guide their technique and push them towards excellence. As with all departments of ELM, culture and history is a big part of the dance program. The students are all Black and Brown, and it's very important that they can see the connections between their culture, their neighborhood, and the genres of dance they practice. Teachers would be invited to collaborate with the Program Director to infuse their class with cultural history. Classes take place on Tuesdays and alternating Thursdays and Fridays in the evenings. A volunteer instructor could teach regularly every week, or come once every few weeks for technique workshops. MORE ABOUT EDUCATED LITTLE MONSTERS: Educated Little Monsters is We Make Noise's community partner, offering arts and performance programming beyond our focus on music and instruments. We are supporting the ELM Dance Department in their search for volunteer dance instructors. IG: @educatedlittlemonsters Facebook.com/elmyouthgroup educatedlittlemonsters.weebly.com Educated Little Monsters is a full performing, visual arts program servicing youth from toddler age to 23 yrs old in under invested communities, starting in Bushwick, Brooklyn in 2013. Our program offers Dance, theater, art, Hip Hop, Music, photography, fashion and so much more. ELM is a very youth led program working in highly gentrified communities where natives are being displaced at an alarming rate. Our program is an artistic outlet for youth of color to become socially responsible and aware about the changes affecting them in their communities through all forms of art, and use it as a tool to tell their stories. The goal of our program is to create enough artistic resources for youth everywhere that will empower them to be the next leaders in their communities for the generations after. Its takes a village to raise a child as it takes a child to raise a village.
11206.title: Dance Instructor: Hip Hop, Ballet, Lyrical/Contemporary (Educated Little Monsters)

11206.description: Opportunity Share your talents with JASA seniors! JASA is looking for volunteers to lead groups of seniors in organized activities at Bushwick/Hylan NORC (Naturally Occurring Retirement Community). Activities may include singing or music groups, political or current event discussions, crossword or puzzle groups, arts and crafts projects, fitness classes or anything else that will bring the people of the center together in an active and social way. Skills * Experience with seniors * Experience/background in class topic required * Relevant exercise certification required Other * Flexible scheduling is available with a minimum commitment of one day a week * Ongoing opportunity * Maintain professional behavior at all times and adhere to JASA’s volunteer policies About JASA Founded in 1968, JASA's mission is to sustain and enrich the lives of the aging in the New York metropolitan area so that they can remain in the community with dignity and autonomy. JASA is one of New York's largest and most trusted agencies serving older adults in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, and Long Island.
11206.title: Activity Leader - JASA Bushwick/Hylan NORC

11206.description: Purpose The ability to understand English is an important skill at any age. It’s never too late to learn! Facilitate a class that allows seniors to practice speaking, reading and writing English. Responsibilities Lead a weekly class in ESL (English as a Second Language) Create lessons suitable for people with varying knowledge of English Communicate effectively and courteously with JASA seniors and staff Skills Experience teaching ESL Experience working with seniors is helpful, but not required Good organizational skills and the ability to prioritize and manage multiple tasks Strong communication skills Patience Knowledge of Spanish is helpful, but not required Comfort leading a group of varying levels Other Flexible scheduling is available with a minimum commitment of one day a week during business hours Ongoing opportunity Maintain professional behavior at all times and adhere to JASA’s volunteer policies About JASA Founded in 1968, JASA's mission is to sustain and enrich the lives of the aging in the New York metropolitan area so that they can remain in the community with dignity and autonomy. JASA is one of New York's largest and most trusted agencies serving older adults in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, and Long Island.
11206.title: ESL Instructor - JASA Williamsburg Senior Center

11209.description: Join New York Common Pantry's program Nourish in it's fight to end hunger in the senior community! Nourish is funded by New York State Department of Health for the Commodity Supplemental Food Program (CSFP) and helps provide over 14,000 seniors a month with supplemental food packages. To distribute these food packages to seniors, we need your help at our mobile site Shore Hill on February 16th and 17th only. The Nourish program at NYCP distributes groceries 1-2 times a month at over 90 mobile sites around NYC, if you are interested in volunteering on a different day or at a different location please email sgonzalez@nycommonpantry.org. Please note that we do not have any weekend opportunities currently available. WE ONLY DISTRIBUTE GROCERIES AT THIS SITE TWICE A MONTH
11209.title: Help Give Out Free Groceries at Shore Hill Senior Center!

11209.description: The social services intern is responsible for assisting clients with non-immigration social services paperwork including public benefits applications, signing up children for school, and Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)/ food stamps applications. This is an excellent opportunity for those interested in Social Work or those currently enrolled in social work programs. The ideal candidate will be able to compassionately and efficiently handle cases while strengthening and supporting the community. Fluent English and working Arabic is preferred for this position, and a strong desire to empower and support the Arab-American community is preferred. The Social Services intern is expected to commit at least 10-15 hours/week of work with the Association; hours and days are somewhat flexible. Responsibilities: Assist with completing social service and SNAP forms and applications Interpreting, translating for clients Provide individual case management related to SNAP and social services Make copies of, and file application forms for clients Maintain confidential client database and case work files for individual clients Requirements: Experience working with immigrant populations Some experience with customer service, completing social services paperwork College Student or Graduate, above 18 Able to work consistent weekly hours Ability to commit at least a 3 month cycle Proficient with Microsoft Office Suite
11209.title: Social Services Intern
11209.org: Arab American Association of New York

11209.description: The Arab Women Activists and Leaders (AWAL) Intern will be a part of the Advocacy and Civic Engagement (ACE) team. The AWAL Intern will focus on assisting the Lead Organizer in providing advocacy tools to immigrant Arab/or Muslim women. The AWAL Intern is expected to commit to at least 12 hours per week for 6 months Primary Duties: Working with the Lead Organizer and Trainer to facilitate AWAL classes Assistance with AWAL curriculum Referral and communication with women enrolled in the program Assist with social media management for events pertaining to AWAL Assist in identifying and inviting guest speakers to AWAL classes Requirements: Experience working with diverse and immigrant communities A strong and genuine desire to advocate for social justice Strong knowledge of spoken Arabic, written Arabic is a plus Proficient with Microsoft Office and Google Apps Excellent verbal, written, and interpersonal skils Open to constructive feedback within the organization Female identified bodies preferred The women’s advocacy assistant is expected to commit to coming in on Monday and Tuesday 9:30 am - 12:30 pm. Hours and days are somewhat flexible.
11209.title: Arab Women Activists & Leaders (AWAL) Intern
11209.org: Arab American Association of New York

11209.description: The AAANY is looking for enthusiastic volunteers to tutor clients that have their Naturalization Test in the near future. Tutors will help prepare clients for their Naturalization Test by teaching them American history and by helping to improve their reading and writing. The Volunteer Citizenship Instructor must have a desire to work with immigrant communities and assist clients in learning civics and understanding the various components of the naturalization exam. Instructors will mentor and guide students through the most difficult challenges of learning the reading, writing, and verbal portions of the exam. In this role, volunteer instructors will be able to create lesson plans, study groups, conversation lessons, and practice exams for our students. Furthermore, volunteer teachers will gain an understanding of the workings of a nonprofit organization, tutoring programs, and they will have the opportunity to familiarize themselves with the Arab American and immigrant community of Bay Ridge. This is an excellent opportunity for all individuals that want to gain experience in education and for those that want to help immigrants become American citizens! Responsibilities: Provide weekly hour-long tutorial sessions for clients on the speaking, civics, reading, and writing portions of the naturalization exam Take attendance of the students who are present for each citizenship tutoring session Conduct mock interview and practice exams with students Log and share planning with coordinator and other volunteers, including entering hand-written notes on planning document Measure students' performance and progress during tutoring sessions Provide timely survey feedback to Association staff regarding both volunteer and student satisfaction and performance Requirements: Basic knowledge and interest in American history and politics is helpful, but not required; Basic understanding of the naturalization process (training will be provided); Sensitivity to cultural differences Knowledge of Arabic, Spanish, or French is preferred but not required A strong and genuine desire to help a diverse immigrant community Professional, interpersonal skills as well as attention to details *Must be available during our open hours: Monday-Friday 10am-5pm.
11209.title: Citizenship Tutor
11209.org: Arab American Association of New York

10122.description: CFC Volunteer Description We are recruiting volunteers for the fall of 2016 for the Combined Federal Campaign (CFC) pledge season at CFC Charity Fairs. What is the CFC? The mission of the CFC is to promote and support philanthropy through a program that is employee focused, cost-efficient and effective in providing all federal employees the opportunity to improve the quality of life for all. CFC is the world's largest and most successful annual workplace charity campaign, with almost 200 CFC campaigns throughout the country and overseas raising millions of dollars each year. Pledges made by Federal civilian, postal and military donors during the campaign season (September 1st to December 15th) support eligible non-profit organizations that provide health and human service benefits throughout the world. There are also more than 150 state and local campaigns comprised of state, county, municipal, public schools and universities in 22 states. What is a CFC Charity Fair? A CFC Charity Fair is an event held at various departments and agencies of the Federal, State and Local Government and Private Companies in the NYC region and nationally for employees to come and learn more about the CFC and the different charities they could support with their workplace giving pledge. Charity Fairs are great opportunities for charities to gain visibility and talk with potential donors. The fairs are fun and often have music, food and keynote speakers. The duration of a charity fair can vary and last anywhere from two to six hours. Volunteer Description We are looking for a group of volunteers to work with on a rolling basis from August to December to attend the various CFC Charity Fairs on behalf of the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund Alliance. Invitations are sent on as an as needed basis and will be forwarded to the volunteer group. We try to give at least 1 week notice about a fair, but some invitations are sent only a few days before. Please note that the Charity Fairs are held for a minimum 2 hour period on a weekday between the hours of 8AM-6PM and are held at various locations. Volunteers will: Need to be friendly and upbeat while attending the fair Be able to talk and be as knowledgeable as possible about the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund Alliance to engage with potential donors. (Training and materials will be provided to help with this.) Attend, either in person or virtually, one of the training sessions held in September in preparation of the CFC season. Available for the duration of the charity fair signed up for. To Apply Please send a brief description of what makes you a great fit for this role and contact information to Catie Dugan at cdugan@ocrfa.org.
10122.title: Combined Federal Campaign Charity Fair Volunteer NYC

10121.description: This opportunity is available every Sunday-Friday from 9 PM-9:30 PM! Rescuing Leftover Cuisine is a nonprofit food rescue organization dedicated to reducing food waste and feeding the hungry. We are currently looking for Lead Rescuers to join our leadership team. A Lead Rescuer is a passionate and dedicated volunteer who commits to leading one event, once per week. Training is provided. Help rescue leftover food that would otherwise have been thrown away and bring it to those who need it the most! You will pick up food donations from multiple vendors in a popular Midtown food court and deliver it on-foot to a nearby homeless shelter. Mediumweight: the average amount of food is a total of 30 lbs.
10121.title: Weekly Volunteer Needed for 9PM-9:30PM Food Rescue Events!

10121.description: This opportunity is available every Saturday and Sunday! Rescuing Leftover Cuisine is a nonprofit food rescue organization dedicated to reducing food waste and getting food to those in need. We are currently looking to bring on Lead Rescuers to our leadership team. A lead rescuer is a passionate and dedicated volunteer who commits to leading one event, once per week. Training is provided. Help rescue bread, pastries, and other delicious food that would otherwise have been thrown out and help feed the hungry of NYC! You will pick up leftover food from two food vendors in a popular Midtown food court and deliver it to a nearby homeless shelter. This event lasts just 20 minutes, and will end at Antonio Olivieri Drop-In Center. Mediumweight: the average amount of food is a total of 30 lbs.
10121.title: Weekly Volunteer Needed for Weekend Midtown Food Rescue Events 9PM-9:30PM!

08816.description: Position Summary: The Disability Allies (DA) is dedicated to providing social opportunities to connect young adults and children with and without disabilities. The Volunteer Director of Social Worker is a part time position and will provide oversight to our social workers and mentors. Responsibilities: Coordinate, supervise and manage the fiscal, clinical and administrative functions for assigned departments. Develop and implement strategies that our mentors will use improve the social skills of our clients. Develop, implement and monitor compliance with departmental and organizational policies and procedures. Plan, organize and implement services to enhance patient care and/or improve fiscal and operational efficiency. Essential functions/working conditions: Ability to work in a team setting Strong social and interpersonal skills Comfortable with mentoring individuals with disabilities Able to effectively communicate both verbally and in writing Ability to connect with others and develop relationships Committed to the mission of serving young adults and children with disabilities Ability to perform several tasks concurrently Strong time management and organizational skills About the Disability Allies: The purpose of the Disability Allies is to plan team building activities that connect young adults and children with and without disabilities. At our events we pair each individual up with a mentor. The job of the mentor is to help the participants with their social skills and insure that everyone interacts with each other. Our events are open to any young adult that has a disability, knows someone with a disability or is supportive of people with disabilities. Please visit www.disabilityallies.com to learn more..
