10003.description: We are currently looking for Volunteer Office Assistants to work in the afternoon and/or the evening. Volunteer Office Assistants serve 4-6 hours per week for a prestigious downtown NYC community theater that produces 25-30 new plays and 3 free community events each year. Volunteer Office Assistants will answer phones, take reservations, file papers and occasionally assist Executive Director Crystal Field by writing letters or researching on the internet. Opportunities available specifically on weekdays in the Morning/Afternoons from 10am to 4pm, or in the evenings from 4pm to 10pm, or on weekends from 12pm to 8pm. Volunteers will receive FREE tickets to all TNC productions.
10003.title: Administrative Assistance

10003.description: Program Overview: Masa is a non-profit organization that partners with Mexican and Latino children, youth and families to develop strong learners and leaders who fully contribute to the broader community. Since 2013, we have run Alianza, a youth support program for recently arrived immigrant youth at International High School at Union Square. Students from Alianza come together for weekly support groups, as well as tutoring and other services. Our participants -- many of whom are unaccompanied minors and have job responsibilities -- are deeply committed to pursuing their education, and they need support in realizing their academic goals. The ideal Alianza Tutor is a dynamic and youth-friendly person who finds value in making a difference in the life of a student. He or She will provide structure tutoring, homework assistance, classroom assistance, and academic workshop facilitation for high school students all to support and encourage students’ academic improvement. Responsibilities We need tutors to commit to volunteering one shift per week in the following areas: High School Math High School English High School Science and/or History Regents preparation for Math and English Conversational and written English practice Completing any homework in various subject areas College preparation: Application preparation and support Time Commitment Willing to volunteer one consistent shift per week during the following times: Monday afternoon: 3:00 - 5:00 PM Willing to volunteer during in-school Study Halls and offer academic support, tutoring, and homework help during Alianza group time. Study Halls takes place on some Tuesdays from 1:00 - 2:00PM, three times per school semester. Detailed Study Hall schedule will be shared during interview. Requirements Passion for working with immigrant youth Experience tutoring adolescents: 1 year Knowledge of regents preparation for Math and English Knowledge of conversational and written English practice ESL Familiarity with college application process and support Attend periodic trainings and provide feedback on students’ progress Proficiency in Spanish extremely helpful
10003.title: Tutor High School Immigrant Youth!

10003.description: The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. Purpose GO Fundamentals, is a tutoring program for GO Project K-8 students who have been identified as \"promotion in doubt\" by their public schools. (Promotion in Doubt means a student may need to repeat their current grade). GO Fundamentals provides the students with additional academic time on literacy development. By working with the students on a more individualized basis, we will give them more opportunities to master the reading and writing skills needed to be promoted to the next grade in June. GO Fundamentals 2016 Schedule February 4, 11, 25 March 4, 11, 18, 25 April 1, 8, 22 Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive. Professional work habits. Responsibilities Tutor one-to-one or in small groups students who are in need of academic intervention. Punctual and consistent attendance; advanced notification of absences necessary. Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement. Help prepare, record, and put away classroom materials. Ongoing communication with the program staff regarding student’s progress &/or concerns, and overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment ¨ February-April, Saturdays from 12:30 PM - 2:30 PM. ¨ Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. Benefits Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development opportunities Joining a strong volunteer community Participating in volunteer social events and outings Location Grace Church School (86 Fourth Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets) LREI (272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street) Avenues (259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets) St. Luke’s (487 Hudson Street, on Christopher and Hudson Streets) Grace Church High School (46 Cooper Square) [FOR 6 th - 8 th GRADE TUTORING] If interested, please e-mail cover letter and resume to Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org. Indicate GO FUNDAMENTALS VOLUNTEER TUTOR in the subject line. Please also fill out the online application found here: https://goo.gl/forms/Rl9pYoTWE8NRX1vw1 .

10003.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Program: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, 1 st-8 th grade students are exposed to intensive academic support in a differentiated classroom setting led by a professional Head Teacher and 2-4 volunteers from 9:30 AM - 12:30 PM. Our GO Middle program specifically focuses on 6 th - 8 th grade students to support them with academic and social emotional learning from 9:30 AM - 1:00 PM. In order to ensure a smooth and effective program, the GO Middle Program & Administrative Assistant will assist the Community Engagement Team in critical programmatic and administrative tasks, such as (but not limited to): volunteer recruitment & management, family & student engagement, set up & arrival, snack distribution, supply management, data collection & management, and overall program support. Specific tasks include, but are not limited, to the following: GO School Saturday Program Support Set Up & Arrival Ensure all materials are ready for staff & students Set up the Community Engagement (CE) Table prior to volunteer arrival Greet volunteers, students, and GO Families at the CE Table upon arrival Direct late arrival students to their designated classrooms Volunteer Management & Support Support and answer volunteer inquiries during CE office hours from 8:45 AM - 9:00 AM Support One-Day Service groups with a brief orientation and transition into classrooms Strategically place Floater Volunteers in classrooms in order to fill the gaps of Committed Volunteer absences Observe classrooms to provide feedback on volunteer performance to the CE Team Snack Distribution & Supply Management Distribute and inventory snacks Manage all supply storage areas in an organized and efficient manner Administrative & Attendance Perform other supply requests/logistical responsibilities as requested by the GO staff & teachers Collect and enter student attendance into the database Clean Up & Dismissal Greet and direct families during dismissal Assist with the supervision of late pick-up students Clean up and organize all CE materials into designated storage areas Assist the Academic Team in overall building clean-up Overall A positive and engaged approach to all designated responsibilities Punctual and consistent attendance for GO School sessions Ongoing communication with the Community Engagement Team and Director of Curriculum and Instruction regarding overall recess activities and volunteer performance Time Commitment Commitment to the 2016-2017 Academic Year 8:30 AM - 1:30 PM (5 Hours) on the following Saturdays GO School Fall Session Dates 2016 October 15, 22, 29 November 5, 12, 19 December 3, 10, 17 GO School Spring Session Dates 2017 January 7, 21, 28 February 4, 11, 25 March 4, 11, 18, 25 April 1, 8, 22 Location and Placement Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, New York, NY 10003 Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners Ongoing professional development and training opportunities Being part of a vibrant and diverse GO Project community of students, teachers, volunteers, and staff College credit if applicable Qualifications Commitment to educational equity a must Background and/or experience in working with elementary and/or middle school students (ages 6-13) Flexibility and adaptability to meet the emerging needs of the program on a day-to-day basis Ability to manage relationships with a diverse set of community stakeholders Must be available on GO program days Professional work habits Bilingual (Spanish/Chinese) preferred How to Apply Cover Letter/Personal Statement Resume Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please e-mail cover letter and resume to Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org. 10003.description: We just received our tax exemption and will be holding our first fundraiser at Drama Book Shop on W. 40th St in Manhattan. We need inspiring public speakers who jive with our mission statement (www.BreakDiving.org) and who have a motivational or inspiring story to tell the audience. The best stories will probably be underdog stories, stories of great success (at whatever level), stories of perseverence, or something uniquely educational. Bottom line: if the audience leaves smarter, happier, more confident, or touched in some small way, that's the type of story we're looking for. While the position is voluntary, we will be using your name in publicity for the event, and also at the event too. So this could be a way to broaden the reach of your name, or brand, even in just a small way. If interested, please, don't hesitate to reach out! We'd love to hear from you.

10003.description: Volunteer Certified Long Term Care Ombudsmen are a vital link between residents of long term care facilities and the government resources able to investigate and resolve their problems. Ombudsmen are committed to advocating for these senior citizens and ensuring that residents' rights, unmet needs and complaints are handled and resolved effectively, while maintaining resident and complainant confidentiality. In this way, Ombudsmen protect and help improve the quality of life for the frailest of New York's senior population. Being an Ombudsman is an important responsibility that is taken on with great care and professionalism. In New York State, Ombudsmen are certified only after receiving extensive training. As Ombudsmen take on their duties in assigned facilities, they are supported by a network of fellow Ombudsmen, Coordinators, and the State Office. If you are interested in becoming an ombudsman please contact Mary Jane Wolper mwolper@cidny.org
10003.title: What is a Certified Long Term Care Ombudsman?
10003.org: CIDNY- Long Term Care Ombudsman Program

10003.description: The Bowery Arts Project is seeking volunteers to participate in our bi-weekly art classes. These classes serve a community of men (clients) seeking help with their drug and alcohol addiction. The clients are short-term residents of the non-medical detox floor at Project Renewal's 3rd street facility. Volunteers are encouraged to teach the classes as well, if interested, but that is not a requirement. Classes are held every Wednesday and Thursday from 9:15am to 11:15am. Participation is flexible. You can come every day, once a week, or every other Thursday...your commitment is up to you although we would love you to come regularly. The more volunteers we have each week, the better the class! Our volunteers have not been formally trained as art therapists and traditional art therapy techniques are not consciously employed. Our mission is to come together with an open mind, as equals, to sit together with the clients make art, listen to music, have something to eat and talk. We ask questions of each other, we collage or draw or write or build or sing but most importantly, we have a conversation....about anything. The heart of the program's success consists of nothing more than openly, and non-judgmentally, listening, sharing our time and emphasizing kindness. Volunteers and clients participate together in a brief Project Renewal morning meeting run by a Project Renewal staff member. The meetings are an opportunity to introduce ourselves to each other and start the morning off with positive conversation about the day. Following the meeting one of the volunteers teachers will introduce the project for the day. Supplies are then passed out, tables pushed together to encourage conversation and community, music is played, and then everyone starts to make their project. Towards the end of the class we collect the work, hang in on the wall, and then one by one we talk about what we did, why we made it, how we felt about the project, etc. Responsibilities include helping to set up for class, joining in making your own art work as you encouraging clients to make their own work, particapating in end-of-class conversations where we view and discuss the work everyone has produced in class, and putting supplies away. For more information about the Bowery Arts Project visit: Boweryartsproject.org
10003.title: Bowery Arts Project

10003.description: Samaritans of New York operates the city’s 24-hour suicide prevention hotline. Last year, we answered over 82,000 hotline calls. Samaritans is part of a well-established international network of 400 centers in 42 countries where over 20,000 volunteers provide crisis response and emotional support services to people who are in distress, depressed and suicidal. Samaritans is currently accepting applicants for the March Hotline Training Class. If you are interested in becoming a Samaritans volunteer, please contact us to attend one of the following orientations: Monday, February 13 Tuesday, February 21 Wednesday, March 1 To receive a Volunteer Information packet, please email samaritansnycvol@aol.com with the following information: -your full name -phone number -residential street address Or: - Inquire through our website: http://samaritansnyc.org/volunteer-2/ - Call 212-673-3041 to receive a Volunteer Information Packet by mail We look forward to hearing from you! Volunteer requirements: Must be at least 21 Good English speaking + written skills Willing to work as part of a collaborative team Available to donate: 1 weekday morning, afternoon, evening or weekend shift a week 1 overnight shift a month No experience necessary!

Must be proficient or knowledgeable in one of following subjects/topics listed below, or any alternative topics/event activities regarding aging, education, arts, culture, health, etc. We are very open to other subjects and new ideas! ESL Classes Language Classes (Chinese, French, Spanish, German, etc.) Musical Performances Music Therapy Aging-related Topics Acupunture Aromatherapy Bereavement Support Counseling Mental Health Massage Therapy Mental Health Nutrition Physical Therapy Spirtual Healing Crocheting Quilting Sewing Acting Storytelling Book Club Art History/Appreciation Broadway Building Confidence in Speaking in Public/Group Calligraphy Chinese Calligraphy Communication Computers Conversation Starters Culture Current Events Dance Drawing Emotional Health Family Tree Finance Health Education Healthy Living/Aging History Improve Memory Humor and Laughter Life Stories Writing Literature (Classical, Genre-specific) Living Will Martial Arts/Self-Defense Medication Awareness Meditation Mind/Brain and Body Music Instruments Natural History Live Performance (ie. Musical Instrument, Comedy, Dance, etc) Philosophy (Classical, Modern, Topic-specific) Poetry Writing Popular Culture Positivity/Happiness Relationships Sexuality Scrapbooking Sketching Social/Political Issues Sociology Tax Technology (Social Media, Internet, Computer Usage, Language, etc.) Theology/Religion Writing Great opportunity to engage with seniors, gain leadership skills, construct your own workshop, event or performance, and gain volunteer hours! If interested, please send a contact email with areas of expertise and how you would like to get involve with our center.
10003.title: Need Volunteers to Lead Workshop, Event, or Perform Arts for Seniors!

10003.description: Have Fun Running a Cafe Cart and Interacting with Students and Older Adults! Opportunity: Volunteer Program: Work with a multi-generational team of teens, college students, young adults, and senior adults who will grow and develop the Café program into your own! Come share your knowledge and experience with high school and college students and engage with your fellow peers. Meet new friends and make a lasting impact on the people you meet and the café program. Work at the café cart and facilitating activities as needed including event planning, marketing, design flyers, technology information, etc Opportunities to Volunteer Include: Cafe cart responsibilities: Setting up and closing the cafe Serving customers' orders Create smoothies, serve tea, coffee and cookies Offer board games, tablets, and technology instruction (cell phones, tablets, etc.) Interact and play games with Sirovich members and other volunteers Lead Classes of interest including Performing Arts, Crafts, etc. (optional; ie. Origami class, Acting workshop, Chinese class, Health workshop, etc.) Assist with developing and marketing new classes, programs and event planning (optional) Opportunity to enhance your skills and interests and share your knowledge to other volunteers and members! Assist with scheduled café activities including:  Game Night  Technology Night  Paint Night  Dance Party  Music Night  Monthly Events Participate in ongoing Meetings, Trainings, and Workshops: o Monthly Inter-generational Volunteer events o Monthly Cafe Advisory Committee Meetings Time Commitment: Volunteers serve flexible hours between Monday-Friday, 2:00pm-6:00pm On average, volunteers serve a minimum 2-7 of hours per week Minimum 1 day a week commitment required
10003.title: Cafe on the Mezz: Volunteer Program for Students and Older Adults!

10003.description: Girl Talk is a micro mentoring opportunity aimed towards PAL’s middle school girl s who exhibit a need to build their self-esteem and combat negative outside peer influences. Women professionals from a variety of backgrounds serve as guest speakers in workshops to impart wisdom and empower our girl s while modeling professionalism and self-respect. Topics covered throughout the program year include self-esteem and body image, leadership, civic engagement, career exploration, health and wellness, and education, among others. Currently, Girl Talk is held in PAL centers in Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island, and the Bronx.
10003.title: Girl Talk

10003.description: Samaritans of New York operates the city’s 24-hour suicide prevention hotline. Last year, we answered over 82,000 hotline calls. Samaritans is part of a well-established international network of 400 centers in 42 countries where over 20,000 volunteers provide crisis response and emotional support services to people who are in distress, depressed and suicidal. Samaritans is currently accepting applicants for the March Hotline Training Class. If you are interested in becoming a Samaritans volunteer, please contact us to attend one of the following orientations: Monday, February 13 Tuesday, February 21 Wednesday, March 1 To receive a Volunteer Information packet, please email samaritansnycvol@aol.com with the following information: -your full name -phone number -residential street address Or: - Inquire through our website: http://samaritansnyc.org/volunteer-2/ - Call 212-673-3041 to receive a Volunteer Information Packet by mail We look forward to hearing from you! Almost anyone who finds themselves facing some overwhelming obstacle or personal tragedy needs help getting through their moment of crisis. At Samaritans of NYC, our caring volunteers respond to people of all backgrounds: teenagers, the elderly, people dealing with chronic and terminal illnesses like cancer or AIDS; victims of violence, bullying and sexual abuse; the homeless, unemployed, veterans; those with sexual identity issues, who are trying to cope with stigma, who are hesitant to seek help. The work is challenging, the training intensive and the experience extremely rewarding! You must be focused, disciplined and keep the commitments you make. This is serious work; you’ll be joining a group of dedicated volunteers from NYC’s diverse communities who work together in a supportive environment in a convenient Village location. Volunteer requirements: Must be at least 21 Good English speaking + written skills Willing to work as part of a collaborative team Available to donate: 1 weekday morning, afternoon, evening or weekend shift a week 1 overnight shift a month No experience necessary!
10003.title: Peer Counselors Needed - Volunteer on Samaritans 24-Hour Crisis Hotline!

10003.description: Purpose Regular exercise is an essential part of a healthy lifestyle. Lead a weekly exercise class for seniors to help keep them in top shape. Responsibilities Lead a group of seniors in a lively exercise to music class on a weekly basis Create exercise routines suitable for varied physical abilities Communicate effectively and courteously with JASA seniors and staff Skills Exercise certification required Experience leading seniors in exercises Experience with group exercise classes Knowledge of several light exercise techniques Comfortable leading a group of varying skill levels. Other Flexible scheduling is available with a minimum commitment of one day a week Ongoing opportunity Maintain professional behavior at all times and adhere to JASA’s volunteer policies About JASA Founded in 1968, JASA's mission is to sustain and enrich the lives of the aging in the New York metropolitan area so that they can remain in the community with dignity and autonomy. JASA is one of New York's largest and most trusted agencies serving older adults in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, and Long Island.
10003.title: Exercise Instructor - JASA Cooper Square

10003.description: TASKS: Hetrick-Martin is seeking volunteers to assist us with our front desk/reception area. Tasks will include greeting clients & guests, directing phone calls, accepting deliveries, and assisting with maintaining youth safety, as needed. SCHEUDLE: Preferred availability is for a 6 hour shift at least one day a week between the hours of 9:00pm - 3pmPM, M-F. ADDITIONAL SKILLS: General knowledge of Microsoft Outlook and bi-lingual (Spanish-English) are a plus. PURPOSE: Volunteers will help ensure that all of Hetrick-Martin's young people are greeted by a friendly face, and that our reception area runs efficiently. This position is fun and allows for a great deal of interaction with Staff and youth.
10003.title: Reception Volunteer:

10003.description: Read about KittyKind at www.kittykind.org KittyKind is all-volunteer cat rescue and cat adoption group located in the Petco store on 17th Street and Broadway, in space that the Petco Corporation donates. KittyKind relies upon donations for all other expenses. It relies upon volunteers to care for the rescued cats. A Health-Maintenance volunteer helps to give nutritional supplements, eye cream, and veterinarian-prescribed medication to cats awaiting adoption at the KittyKind adoption center. Training and training materials will be given. The volunteer shift would be for a couple of hours, one day a week, throughout the year. After training, the day and the time are up to you. Preference is for a volunteer who has experience working with animals or who is a pre-vet, or a vet-tech student. However, all help is welcome. For Saturday or Sunday help, please be an \"early bird,\" able to start about 8 or 9, before the adoption center gets crowded. Must be over age 18. Active seniors very welcome! References preferred. To begin the application process, please do the following: Connect to kittykind.org Click on Volunteer Fill out an application, specifying Health Maintenance as your preference Then, someone will email you shortly after. Thanks.
10003.title: Health Care: Cats/Kittens

10003.description: We need a person(s) with a car to spend 1 hour (between 9:30 and 10:30am) on Saturdays to pick up donated food in the neighborhood from in-kind donors. We pick up from Au Bon Pain, Blimpies, Jon Vie Pasteries, Balducci's, D'Agostino's, etc. all in Soho and the Village.
10003.title: To pick up food with a car on Sat. mornings

10003.description: We feed 150 homeless and needy people every Saturday. Volunteers are invited to arrive about 9:00am until about 12:00pm to help in the preparation of food and soup by chopping vegatables, slicing bread, making sandwiches, arranging desserts, etc. No need to make a reservation - just show up and we'll put you to work although groups must be limited to 5 people please. A different group organized by NYCares serves the meals in the later afternoon. We are also in need of a person(s), with a car, to pick up food from in-kind donors in the neighborhood on Sat. mornings (ie. Sullivan Steet Bread, Knickeboker Restaurant, Chipolte, etc.) and bring the donated food to our Soup Kitchen so it can be prepared for serving. E-mail Dean directly if you can help in this endeavor.
10003.title: To help feed the needy

10166.description: We would love help developing our logo, look, and narritive to the public and on social media as well as develop more formal relationships with press. On our branding/media wish list: - Logo design - Writing copy for website and press releases - Developing image and presence on social media - Website update (both content and design) - Develop media relations and seek opportunties for exposure/interviews/reviews - Create and design newsletter for supporters to share work and fundraise
10166.title: Graphic design and media/branding expert needed for dance nonprofit

10166.description: We are expanding our board now that our tax exempt nonprofit organization is growing. We are looking in particular for board members with a strong background in fundraising, development, and/or (social) media/marketing/branding. We have meetings on an as-needed basis, about 3 or 4 times a year. Initial commitment is through the end of 2017. Serving on the board of our tax-exempt nonprofit means being part of the team that ensures the legal, administrative, financial, developent, and public relations run smoothly so the organization can carry out its mission. You'd be joining a high-energy diverse group of people with a can-do attitude and a great sense of humor and joy. Your service on the board would help make a powerful difference in the lives of children and teens with disabilties through dance and the related arts.
10166.title: Looking for committed board members for growing inclusive dance nonprofit

10008.description: The Youth Voices Network gives voice to survivors of dating abuse with the goal of helping youth build safe and healthy relationships. A group made up of young survivors, the Youth Voices Network aims to let other young people know that they are not alone, raise awareness about warning signs of abuse, and direct survivors to helpful resources. Sharing their stories offers the survivors an opportunity to heal and transform their experiences of pain into a powerful tool for change. The Youth Voices Network welcomes new members. Our members are survivors of youth dating violence, who have experienced intimate partner violence or dating abuse as a teen or young adult. The Youth Voices Network raises awareness in a variety of ways, including the following: Sharing personal stories of survival - anonymously or not - with: Youth/peers Parents Teachers Government officials Journalists and other media professionals Strategizing to raise awareness of relationship abuse among youth through: Public events Awareness projects Outreach to youth and youth-focused community organizations Local and national media attention Proving a safe space and building relationships of support between members. To apply for this program, please complete the Youth Voices Network Application Form online at http://www.dayoneny.org/join-the-youth-voices-network/ For more information, please email us at youthvoicesnetwork@dayoneny.org.
10008.title: Stop Dating Abuse Now and Join the Youth Voices Network!

10009.description: Volunteers will support P.S. 15 students from 4:00 pm to 6:00 pm in their Pathways to Leadership sponsored After School Program. Responsibilities include supervising snack distribution and helping with homework. After snack time, the students break off into separate groups and volunteers will then provide support during enrichment activities. Each volunteer will be paired with a Pathways to Leadership trainer, and accompanied by older PS 15 students and PS 15 alumni helpers.
10009.title: P.S. 15 After School Helper

10009.description: Go the extra mile with Back on My Feet NYC! Dedicated teams of volunteers run 2-4 miles with our members who are transitioning out of homelessness. We encourage runners of all speeds to become a part of our community! Team ABC runs/jogs/walks with Pride Site & The Bowery Mission every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 5:30-6:30AM. To find out more and sign up for an orientation, visit nyc.backonmyfeet.org/nyc-run-with-us
10009.title: Lower East Side Morning Runner

10009.description: CBSBB’s mentoring program enables young people to expand their horizons, their hopes and their dreams. It helps inspire them to improve academic performance and reduce risky behavior, which ultimately leads to stable health, strong personal relationships and gainful employment. You should know that research has proven that CBSBB’s integration of mentoring, family counseling and skill building ensures that our mentoring relationships are healthier and last longer than the national average. CBSBB’s target populations are children from first generation, low-income communities. Many of the families we work with are overwhelmed by multiple stressors. Poverty, a shortage of skills and a lack of exposure to opportunities are some of the issues our mentees face every day. These children are eager to expand their horizons and having a mentor can be the difference between their current reality and a successful future. You can be that difference! MENTOR ROLE: Maintain a one-to-one match relationship between yourself as the Big Sister/Brother (mentor) and your Little (mentee) while respecting the family system Serve as a positive role model and friend while helping your mentee to set and accomplish goals Build the match relationship by planning and participating in activities together PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS: Be at least 21 years of age Be interested in working with a young girl or boy between the ages of 10-18 Be willing to finance all match outings (outings need not be expensive) If child doesn’t travel alone, be responsible for picking up or dropping of your Little Sister/Brother TIME COMMITMENT: Mentors must meet fact-to-face with their mentees for 8 hours each month and go on outings with their mentee. Typically matches meet twice a month, for an average of 4 hours each, usually on weekends, for a minimum of one year Mentors are responsible for maintaining communication with their mentee in between outings by setting up a weekly call night to help build their match relationship Matches must attend at least one skill learning program workshop series per year TO APPLY: Visit www.cbsbb.org/volunteers or call us at 212 475-3291 x502.
10009.title: Change a Life.  Change Your Life.  Become a Mentor!

10009.description: Our Manhattan based organization is seeking a cohort of approximately 12 volunteers who would work with our homeless population on a scheduled rotating basis in teams of two or three workers weekly to assist us with intakes, assessments and referrals. Our hours of operation are every Saturday from 8 AM to 3:00PM and we are located at 137 East Second Street, (at Avenue A in Manhattan) at the Cardinal Spellman Center (lower level). 2nd Avenue stop on the F train. Our space is equipped with wireless Internet, computers and printers and a full supply of stationary for volunteers to assist our guests. All volunteers would have a tremendous amount of staff support. Please have the interested parties contact Joe Montano, Director at 347-534-7792 or through email at emailucss-ny@yahoo.com
10009.title: Volunteers needed to provide homeless with social services.

07438.description: Be a part of a club that helps men and women with developmental disabilites realize that they can give back to the community and make a difference! This club meets once a month on Wednesdays at 6:30 pm in Oak Ridge (Jefferson Township) NJ. The members decide on a cause they wish to support and devise a plan to get it done. This year they conducted a hugely succesful Mother's Day Gift Bag event which went to the young moms at Birth Haven in Newton, NJ, raised funds and collected food for the Jefferson Dog/Cat rescue organization and honored the Jefferson and Newton Police departments. It is an opportunity to help these men and women realize they are more than a charity themselves, but rather, have the right to give back and serve others as well.
07438.title: Fight for the Right" Club - Empowers people with developmental disabilities

08859.description: Reports to: Young Athletes program Coach Time Commitment & Training: This individual must be able to commit to the full duration of the event as scheduled. If unable to commit, please do not select this position. General Description Assist the Program Director in maintaining the flow and integrity of Young Athlete Program. Orientation will be provided on-site day of the event. Duties & Responsibilities Possible positions include: Serve as a Young Athlete escort through the various sport/motor stations Check in athletes and/or volunteers Work specifically with a sport/motor station as directed by Program Director Skills & Qualifications Excellent verbal communication is a must, as well as ensuring professional and friendly service, including the ability to multitask and respond quickly to changes in schedules and plans. Physical Requirements The usual and customary methods of performing the job's functions require the following physical demands: occasional lifting, carrying, pushing, and/or pulling. Generally the job requires 70% walking, 25% standing, and 5% sitting. Must be able to stand and walk the majority of the volunteer shift. Questions regarding this position should be directed to: Amy Simmons | Volunteer Director | volunteer@sonj.org
08859.title: Special Olympics New Jersey - Young Athlete Program Jersey Waves

08852.description: Volunteers needed to help at our distribution facility to assist with distribution to the participant families in our program. Volunteers also needed on Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday mornings to help with breaking down and sorting fresh food provisions and more that come into the distribution facility. Volunteer drivers needed to help pick up provisions in the local area from generous providers. We welcome hearing from you and look forward to speaking with you. Thank you for your interest in providing helping hands. Please contact us at 908-227-0684.
08852.title: Volunteers Needed

08852.description: Life Choice Hospice seeks volunteers in Monmouth Junction, NJ to participate in their volunteer program. As little as 1-2 hours per week makes a difference in someone's life. Life Choice Hospice serves patients in assisted livings, nursing homes, or in their own homes. Volunteers will learn about hospice services, and how to provide non-medical visits to people with a life limiting illness. They will also gain an understanding of the special needs of people with Alzheimer's and Dementia. Through your commitment to Life Choice Hospice, you can impact patients in extraordinary ways! What can volunteers do? Make friendly visits Provide caregiver relief and respite Complementary Therapy such as Reiki, Massage, and Pet Therapy Read Listen Share a special talent like music or art Administrative support What do we provide? An increase in your life satisfaction Free training at your convenience Free health evaluation and TB tests Free flu shots (during flu season) Ongoing educational opportunities Social activities and events
08852.title: Life Choice Hospice Seeks Volunteer Team Members in Monmouth Junction!

08852.description: Contact us for more information on working with hospice patients close to where you live. We provide FREE volunteer training for you along with free TB and Rubella/Rubeola testing. Your pet will need to be a certified pet therapy animal. You and your pet will bring joy and love to the lives of our patients and will receive so much love and joy in return!
08852.title: Share your pet's unconditional love with hospice patients!

08852.description: Pack meals for the Meals On Wheels Program and serve lunch to the seniors in the building. No cooking just dishing food from steam table. Hours one day week 8:30-12:30. Weekdays only.
08852.title: Kitchen Assistant

08852.description: Greet older adults coming to use gym in the senior center. Verify they are on approved list and have medical clearance to enter. Monitor seniors in gym. Shifts 8:30-12:30 and 12:30-3:00 at least one day per week. Weekdays only. High school students in July and August. Adults Sept-June.
08852.title: Gym Greeter

08852.description: Be the first point of contact for seniors entering the senior center. Check for membership. Help them scan in to our attendance computerized program. Answer simple questions. Direct members of the public to the offices. Shifts 8:30-12:00 and 12:00-3:00 weekdays only. No weekends Adults used Sept-June and High Shchool students in the summer
08852.title: Greeter

08850.description: We are a multi-service agency with opportunities for: -Hostessing senior socialization programs -Teaching seniors new skills -Training to be a Healthy Bones instructor to work with seniors to encourage healthy aging -Working as a Friendly Visitor brightening up a seniors' day -Running workshops for women in transition -Teaching computer classes in our Career Center -Training to be a fraud, waste and abuse volunteer for Senior Medicare Patrol -Delivering Kosher Meals on Wheels throughout Middlesex County -Helping in Food Pantries throughout Middlesex County -Researching and applying for grants -Working in our offices as administrative or clerical support
08850.title: RSVP (Retired and Senior Volunteer Program) for volunteers 55+
08850.org: Jewish Family Services of Middlesex County

08850.description: JFS is looking for current or retired multilingual ESL teachers to teach citizenship classes around Middlesex County to immigrants working toward citizenship. We are also in need of tutors for citizenship classes; test scorers; office administrative and clerical support; and grant writers to research and apply for grants.
08850.title: ESL Multilingual teachers needed to teach Citizenship classes
08850.org: Jewish Family Services of Middlesex County

08857.description: General assistance to Envionmental Services department. Volunteer should like working with their hands. General cleaning, windows, sweeping, walking the grounds for trash pickup, helping maintenance staff with preventative maintenance issues.
08857.title: Maintenance Support Volunteer

08857.description: To provide patients the opportunity to interact with trained and certified dogs during their hospitalization to improve thieir emotional and social status.
08857.title: Pet Therapy (Old Bridge)

08857.description: Catholic Charities Connections Program is actively recruiting volunteers to work as mentors with children ages 5-17. Mentors offer support, guidance, and education as a youth goes through a difficult time, faces new challenges or opportunities, or takes on an important task. A mentor is a person who is willing to share their life-long expertise to provide support to the youth. Mentors can play an important role as the youth develops mentally and emotionally to help a youth understand their goals and personal needs. Mentors must be a minimum of 18 years of age. Prospective mentors will undergo an intensive screening process consisting of: application and informal autobiography, personal interview, reference checks, criminal background check, driving record check and program orientation. The program serves youth in Middlesex County. Mentoring is the process of sharing personal knowledge and skills with a young person.
08857.title: Mentoring Youth

08854.description: Kindred Hospice’s supply of CD players is depleted! Donating an unused CD player would bring joy and comfort to those facing a life-limiting illness. Kindred Hospice provides compassionate health care to patients with terminal illness in the central Jersey area. Will pick up in Somerset, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris & Union county. If you have any questions, please contact Elaine Carlsen, Volunteer Coordinator, at elaine.carlsen@gentiva.com or call (732)-562-8800 today.
08854.title: CD Players Needed by Patients: Our Supply is Gone!

08854.description: Your certified pet can bring joy to patients facing life-limiting illnesses! Pet Therapists are needed in the central New Jersey area including Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Ocean, Somerset, and Union counties. This is an opportunity to help serve the underserved population; those patients who have chosen to stay in their own homes in their last days. Kindred Hospice will provide free training and support. Contact Elaine.Carlsen@gentiva.com or call 888-556-8880.
08854.title: Pet Therapists Needed

08854.description: Kindred Hospice, an organization that provides compassionate care to those with life-limiting illnesses, is in need of someone to help in our Piscataway office. Administrative Volunteers provide valuable office support including filing cards, mailings, computer work, and faxing. Volunteer work is flexible, and we are grateful for as much time as you can give even if for just a few hours a week. Work is done during office hours which is Mon - Fri, 9 am - 5 pm, and Wed until 7:00 pm. No previous experience is needed; free training is provided. Certification of service hours will be provided upon request. Contact Elaine Carlsen, Volunteer Coordinator, at Elaine.Carlsen@gentiva.com or 732-562-8800.
08854.title: Administrative Volunteer

08854.description: Gentiva Hospice, an organization that provides compassionate care to those with life-limiting illnesses, is in need of someone to answer phones. Volunteer work is flexible; we are grateful for as much time as you can give even if for just a few hours a week. Work is done during office hours which is Mon - Fri, 9 am - 5 pm. No previous experience is needed; free training is provided. Contact Elaine Carlsen, Volunteer Coordinator, at Elaine.Carlsen@gentiva.com or 732-562-8800 today.
08854.title: Receptionist - Medical

06906.description: Pet therapy volunteers for Caring Hospice of Connecticut in Fairfield County help by providing companionship and a social outlet to patients, who reside in private homes, nursing homes and assisted-living facilities throughout Fairfield County . We are looking for individuals who have an approved animal visitor (dog, cat, etc.) to visit terminally ill patients and their families to provide comfort, joy and companionship. Pet therapy handlers must produce documented evidence of annual reputable therapy pet organization membership(e.g. Pet Partners) and veterinary visits attesting to good behavior, good health and current vaccinations. Caring Hospice of Connecticut will find a way to share your talents and interests with the patients and their families. Individualized training is provided free of charge without the need to travel to the Stamford office. In keeping with Medicare requirements, background and medical checks are part of the training process.
06906.title: Pet Therapy to visit with patients at the end of life

06906.description: Telephone support volunteers assist staff with making phone calls to our patients and their families for follow up and offer emotional support. If you are a person who demonstrates the ability to communicate with people effectively, listens to others, has absolute integrity and the use of good judgment to handle the professional and confidential nature of assignments, then Caring Hospice of Connecticut located in Stamford, Connecticut is the right fit for you. Caring Hospice Services of Connecticut is a unique, holistic and cost effective service designed to meet the social, emotional, spiritual and physical needs of their patients and families in Fairfield county that reside in private homes, nursing homes and assisted-living facilities as they face terminal illness. We are looking for individuals who enjoy helping people, and willing to assist patients and their families with whatever the needs are after signing on to hospice care. Telephone support volunteers need to commit to a consistent schedule a few hours per week or every other week. Individualized training is provided free of charge. In keeping with Medicare requirements, background and medical checks are part of the training process. The Stamford office building is not handicap accessible or friendly at this time.
06906.title: Enjoy listening?  Become a telephone support volunteer!

06906.description: Caring Hospice Services of Connecticut is a unique, holistic and cost effective service designed to meet the social, emotional, spiritual and physical needs of their patients and families in Fairfield County who reside in private homes, nursing homes and assisted-living facilities as they face terminal illness. Data entry office support volunteers help staff with web research, data entry and working with spreadsheets. If you are a person who demonstrates the ability to communicate with people effectively, has absolute integrity and uses good judgment to handle the professional and confidential nature of assignments, Caring Hospice of Connecticut located in Stamford, Connecticut is the right fit for you. We are looking for individuals familiar and comfortable with the Microsoft Office Suite who are willing to commit to a consistent schedule a few hours per week or every other week. Individualized training is provided free of charge. In keeping with Medicare requirements, background and medical checks are part of the training process. The Stamford office building is not handicap accessible or friendly at this time.
06906.title: Enjoy data entry and computer work?  Become an office support volunteer!

06906.description: Caring Hospice Services of Connecticut is a unique, holistic and cost effective service designed to meet the social, emotional, spiritual and physical needs of their patients and families in Fairfield County who reside in private homes, nursing homes and assisted-living facilities as they face terminal illness. Office support volunteers help our staff with basic tasks such as answering the phone, copying and assembling packets, and helping with web research, and more. If you are a person who demonstrates the ability to communicate with people effectively, has absolute integrity and the use of good judgment to handle the professional and confidential nature of assignments, then Caring Hospice of Connecticut located in Stamford, Connecticut is the right fit for you. We are looking for individuals who are willing to commit to a consistent schedule a few hours per week or every other week. Individualized training is provided free of charge. In keeping with Medicare requirements, background and medical checks are part of the training process.
06906.title: Enjoy answering telephones? Become an office support volunteer!

06906.description: The mission of Camp AmeriKids is to enhance the lives of youth living with the challenges of HIV/AIDS and sickle cell disease by providing an enriching summer camp experience, year-round skill building and a supported transition to adulthood. We are looking for a volunteer who wants to make a real impact at a small organization by helping in the Development department. The volunteer would work directly with the Development Director and duties would include: Assisting in the update and maintenance of the organization’s automated donor files by generating reports, updating donor records and writing acknowledgement letters Assisting with the design and production of donor materials and ongoing correspondence Conducting prospect research and analysis to support solicitation strategies Providing special events and clerical support. Including, but not limited to: coordinating event logistics, assembling materials and follow-up information Assisting with data entry, mailings, and other correspondence, working with outside vendors and helping in all auction related tasks Development administrative work (copying, filing, and other support tasks) Please contact Erica Quiroz at info @campamerikids.org for more information about this volunteer opportunity.
06906.title: Development Volunteer Needed! Help us make camp happen for deserving kids!

06905.description: Stamford Dollars for Scholars is an all-volunteer nonprofit community organization whose mission is to provide scholarships to support local students in their pursuit of higher education. Since its inception in 2012, Stamford Dollars for Scholars awarded 107 scholarships to high school graduates, valued at $357,000. The Student Outreach Volunteer is an advocate for Stamford Dollars for Scholars, working as a team with the Student Outreach Coordinators to communicate with high school guidance counselors, provide scholarship application workshops to high school seniors, and to represent Stamford Dollars for Scholars at local events and college fairs. This position requires as-needed coordination by phone or in-person meetings; regularly, the Student Outreach Volunteer is expected to work independently. A minimum commitment of 4 hours per week between September and April is required. Qualifications Exceptional communication skills. Experience working with high school students or familiarity with scholarship or college application process. Demonstrated ability to work with computers. Self-directed, able to work autonomously, while understanding that collaboration will be essential. Must be able to schedule workshops during school hours. Must be available one to two evenings total to attend local college fairs. College or graduate students, entrepreneurs, retirees welcome.
06905.title: Student Outreach Volunteer

06905.description: Stamford Dollars for Scholars is an all-volunteer nonprofit community organization whose mission is to provide scholarships to support local students in their pursuit of higher education. Since its inception in 2012, Stamford Dollars for Scholars awarded 107 scholarships to high school graduates, valued at $357,000. The Social Media and Communications Specialist is an advocate for Stamford Dollars for Scholars, working with the Vice President of Student Affairs to create and curate visual and written content, update and monitor social media accounts on a regular basis, and to create reports for the Board of Directors. This position requires as-needed coordination by phone or in-person meetings; regularly, the Social Media and Communications Specialist is expected to work remotely and independently. A minimum commitment of 6 hours per week is required. Qualifications Experience managing a brand’s online presence as a community and/or social media manager or educational equivalent. Exceptional communication, writing and editing skills. Solid judgment as a brand’s primary social media ambassador; ability to exert discretion, professionalism, and maintain brand voice and values in all public forums at all times. Self-directed and the ability to work autonomously, while understanding that collaboration will be essential. An ability to think creatively about how to best represent the organization and its cause. Experience or education in digital marking or graphic design is preferred. College or graduate students pursuing a degree in digital media, digital marketing or communications welcome.
06905.title: Social Media and Communication Specialist

06902.description: We have a gentleman here who is a true veteran and would love to sit and have a conversation with another veteran. He waits weekly for others to join him however nobody does as they have other interests. He begins each meeting by putting his hat on and patiently waiting to see if anyone comes to join him. The \"meeting\" time is 11:00 on Thursday mornings here at Brighton Gardens. if you'd like to get to know him and share you story, please contact me. Thank you.
06902.title: Devoted Veteran Looking to Share his Story with another Vet.

06902.description: Do you love to knit or crochet? Would you like to share you talent with our seniors? We have many who love to knit and a few who would love to learn. If you can volunteer an hour per week of your time, we want you!!!!! Our goal is to donate completed projects to local shelters and those in need. Please call if you'd like to get involved. We have a great group of people who are currently knitting lap blankets, baby hats, mittens, and scarves. It's easy peazy, we supply everything. We meet Thursdays at 1:30 here at Brighton Gardens and that can be changed to accomodate you! Give me a call!
06902.title: KNIT ONE PURL TWO:  Our knitting group needs a leader!

06902.description: Administrative help needed one or two mornings per week to assist in data entry for free clinics program. Some office experience necessary and medical data base knowledge a plus.
06902.title: Administrative Help needed at Americares HQ

06902.description: We have a group of people here at Brighton Gardens that love to play Bridge however need someone to refresh their card playing and challenge them weekly. If you're a Bridge player and want to help out our card players, please contact me. We are looking for a once a week, your choice of day and time. Thank you!!!
06902.title: BRIDGE PLAYERS - WE WANT YOU!!!!!

06902.description: Are you available to offer administrative support an hour or two a week? I'm looking for a volunteer to help me with filing and file organizing. And if you know anything about converting documents to a useable online format (such as Google docs) you'd be my hero!
06902.title: Helping Dir. of Volunteers

06902.description: Family Centers’ Resident Services Program is seeking 2-4 volunteers to work one-on-one and in small groups with children in grades K-3 rd in a learning center setting. Volunteers will help children with their homework, provide assistance with the target lesson of the day, and help engage the children in the enrichment activity of the day by; talking to them, encouraging them, and modeling what is expected of the children. Other duties may include: setting up and cleaning up your workspace for homework and activities. Volunteers are needed: Monday and Wednesday between the hours of 4p.m.-5:30p.m. at the Lawn Hill and Oak Park community centers ( 32-34 Custer and 73 Dale Street in Stamford’s East Side). The minimum age to volunteer in this program is 16.
06902.title: East Side Learning Center Volunteer

06902.description: Literacy Volunteers at Family Centers is looking for volunteers to teach adults to read, write and speak the English language. Workshops teach a variety of techniques with emphasis on determining how the student learns best. Training includes practice and demonstration, lesson planning, and goal setting. Interested volunteers must be able to attend all sessions and previous teaching experience is not necessary. Please contact us for more information and join our dedicated group of dynamic tutors and make a difference in your community! Please check back for the next Literacy Volunteers Tutor Training, to be held late fall/early winter.
06902.title: Literacy Volunteers Tutors

06902.description: The Nurturing Families Network (NFN) is a statewide support program for first-time parents that provides a system of continuous care designed to promote positive parenting. The NFN program at Family Centers is offered to all new parents giving birth at Greenwich and Stamford hospitals. After completing their training, volunteers contact parents by phone and offer support, educational materials, group events and referral information to other community services. Information to parents may include topics such as newborn feeding, childcare, stress management, immunizations, and other critical information about the health and care of their new baby. Volunteers will be supervised by the program coordinator. Hours are flexible for this opportunity and volunteers may work out of our Stamford location (60 Palmer's Hill Road) or one of our Greenwich locations (40 Arch Street or 22 Bridge Street). In addition to the training a personal interview and background check is required. Spanish speaking volunteers are encouraged to apply.
06902.title: Nurturing Families Network Volunteer

06902.description: A local young adult needs a mentor for community inclusion activities. He loves music and adapted computers, but due to blindness he cannot drive so he has a difficult time accessing social activities and work opportunities. If you are interested, you will attend community events, concerts, attend movies, go on a short walk, or explore work opportunities by helping him obtain applications and returning them for consideration. This is a great opportunity to spend some time in your community while helping another person. Requirements to be a great volunteer include: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance; a minimum of $50/100k liability and $5,000 of property damage coverage.
06902.title: Mentor and Community Inclusion Buddy Needed for Local Fellow with Blindness
06902.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

06902.description: The mission of The ELM Project is to enhance the lives of youth living with HIV/AIDS and sickle cell disease by providing an enriching summer camp experience, year-round skill building and a supported transition to adulthood. An office assistant for The ELM Project would help the Executive Director, Program Coordinator, and Development Manager with tasks related to our summer camp and leadership programs such as a holiday toy drive, document filing, mailings, leadership opporunity research and more. Volunteers will get an in-person look at the day-to-day workings of a grassroots not for profit organization.
06902.title: Office Assistance for Children's Non-Profit

06902.description: BILINGUAL (SPANISH-ENGLISH) ADMINISTRATIVE VOLUNTEER needed for Stamford Americares Free Clinic. Need conversational Spanish. We need Friday volunteers to help with returning patient calls and make appointments, and on Tuesdays we can use help in the afternoons during clinic sessions. We are flexible and will work with your schedule! Come join our team of caring professionals.
06902.title: BILINGUAL ADMINISTRATIVE HELP  needed for Stamford AmeriCares Free Clinic

06902.description: Stigma leaves me stuck and I need to make a new good friend who will read to me and visit with me at my group home. If you like discussing current events, reading and visiting this is a perfect match for you. I like to learn grammar and vocabulary or read about minerals, food and nutrition or related topics. I might repeat myself so I just need you to be patient with me while we get to know each other. Requirements to be a great volunteer include: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance; a minimum of $50/100k liability and $5,000 of property damage coverage.
06902.title: Stigma Leaves Me Stuck - Will You Read to Me?
06902.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

06902.description: We are looking for English speaking professionals who are interested in donating their time and expertise to offer a parenting education class at Saint Joseph Parenting Center (SJPC) in Stamford, CT. Our English program aims to empower parents in our community to help them become the best advocates for their children as well as active citizens in the community so we can stop the cycle of child abuse and neglect. We offer every instructor, orientation and a detailed curriculum to follow, as well as supporting materials for class. We would love your time if you have any of the following backgrounds: Teacher, pediatrician, nurse, dental hygienist, therapist, social worker, parent or family educator, community outrach, special educator, lawyer, banker. The English class is every Monday, 10am-12pm and Wednesday Evening 6pm-8pm. Opportunity offers plenty of flexibility; you can chose to commit as little as once or twice a year to teach a class.
06902.title: English Speaking Professionals to Teach a Parenting Education Class

06902.description: We are looking for Spanish speaking professionals who are interested in donating their time and expertise to lead a parenting education class at Saint Joseph Parenting Center (SJPC) in Stamford, CT. Our Spanish program aims to empower the Spanish speaking parents in our community to help them become the best advocates for theri children as well as active citizens in the community so we can stop the cycle of child abuse and neglect. We offer every instructor with orientation and a detailed curriculum, as well as supporting materials for each class. We would love your time if you have any of the following backgrounds: Teacher, nurse, pediatrician, dental hygienist, therapist, social worker, parent or family educator, community outreacher, special educator, lawyer or banker. Our class runs every Tuesday morning (10am-12pm) and Wednesday evening (6pm-8pm).
06902.title: Spanish Speaking Professionals to Teach Parenting Education Class

06902.description: SPANISH/ ENGLISH INTERPRETERS are needed for the AmeriCares clinic in Stamford CT. Clinic sessions are on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday afternoons from noon to 5:00. Volunteers can work a four hour shift. We are very flexible and will work with your schedule. Must be fluent in Spanish and English. Our interpreters translate the needs of our patients to our medical staff. Besides your language skills, your professional and compassionate presence is needed. Volunteers are asked to work one or two clinic sessions per month. Come join our team of committed and compassionate professionals. Please also see our website for more information. AmeriCaresFreeClinics.org PLEASE NOTE: Thursday clinic is especially in need of interpreters.
06902.title: SPANISH/ ENGLISH INTERPRETERS NEEDED for Stamford AmeriCares Free Clinic

06902.description: VOLUNTEER Medical Assistants or EMTs are needed for our very busy AmeriCares mobile clinic located in Stamford CT. If you are an experienced medical assistant or EMT, we can use your help. Our free clinic treats low income, uninsured residents of Stamford. The clinic sessions are: Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday afternoons from noon to 5:00. Volunteers can work a 4 hour shift that works with their schedule. Come join our team of committed and compassionate professionals! You can volunteer once a week or once a month. We are flexible and will work with your schedule. Please see our website for more information about our program, AmericaresFreeClinics.org or email Lorraine Larkin at llarkin@americares.org
06902.title: EMT or Medical Assistants needed at Stamford AmeriCares Free Clinic

06902.description: VOLUNTEER NURSES are needed for our busy AmeriCares free clinic located in Stamford CT. Our clinic has recently been relocated to a beautiful and spacious location at 401 Shippan Avenue. Our free clinic treats low income, uninsured residents of Stamford. Volunteers’ shifts are 12:30 to 4:30 pm on Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursdays. We are flexible and will work with your schedule. Come join our team of committed and compassionate professionals! You can volunteer once a week or once a month. It is up to you. Please see our website for more information about our program, AmericaresFreeClinics.org or email Lorraine Larkin at llarkin@americares.org
06902.title: Volunteer Nurses needed at Stamford americares free clinic

06902.description: Love to cook? Purchase and prepare a healthy, homecooked, delicious, and complete meal in your kitchen or the commercial kitchen in our school, and deliver it to 10 hungry teenage boys - once, once-a-month, or when it's convenient. Your help is budget relieving, and lets staff spend more one-on-one time with our group home boys who would be homeless except for Domus. To know more, write me and I'll provide additional details.
06902.title: Meal Preparation for our Group Home Boys

06902.description: Do you have a curiosity about global affairs? Lead a U.S. foreign policy discussion group today! For over 55 years, the Foreign Policy Association's Great Decisions program has brought together people and communities to encourage individuals to engage in the world around them and to think critically about the global issues facing policymakers. Each year, FPA produces the Great Decisions briefing book, examining eight U.S. foreign policy and global affairs topics. All across the U.S., discussion groups meet to consider and discuss these topics, constituting the largest civil-education network in the country. Discussion group leaders organize and lead these meetings in their communities. Become a group leader now!
06902.title: Lead a global affairs discussion in the Stamford area today!!

06903.description: EVENT PLANNERS NEEDED Looking for an outlet for your creative ideas? Then this is the volunteer job for you. The Stamford History Center (also known as the Historical Society) is recruiting interested individuals to help plan our events each year. We need dedicated, organized people to help with hospitality, marketing and communication, ad and donation solicitation, finding sponsors, finding event locations, decorations, set up/break down, check in, support for regular events (such as our annual gala), and help in the creation of new events at our History Center. Contact Pam Coleman to express your interest: info@stamfordhistory.org. We have not yet established a regular meeting day and time, but will do so around the schedule of interested volunteers.
06903.title: Event Planner

06903.description: Help Wanted:Dynamic Education Program Docents! The Stamford Historical Society is looking for energetic individuals to staff its new education programs. If you enjoy working with children, want to share your enthusiasm for history, or are looking to broaden your own experience, becoming an Education Docent for the Stamford History Center is an excellent opportunity. Teaching experience is helpful, but not required. Docents will bring one program into elementary school classrooms during February and host onsite programs at the Stamford History Center during May and June. All docents will be trained to lead our hands-on programs in a series of workshops. Programs take place between 9 am and 3 pm on weekdays. In-school programs will be run from 1 - 5 hours of paid work in a day. The onsite programs are generally 4-5 paid work hours/day. The specific dayes and dates and hours will be confirmed with the participants. Contact Pam Coleman, info@stamfordhistory.org or 203-329-1183 , for more information.
06903.title: Docents for Dynamic Education Program

06901.description: Seeking volunteer transport drivers with reliable vehicles to help us move dogs along our transport route between these towns: Hagerstown MD, Mechanicsburg PA, Hamburg PA, Phillipsburg NJ, Haskell NJ (northern NJ), Stamford CT, E Hartford CT. Transports are on Saturdays and we move through these towns during afternoon/evening hours. MUST LOVE DOGS. Must be comfortable handling strange dogs that may or may not be stressed by transport. Attention to detail important. Not above cleaning up stinky messes to help our furry friends get to safety. Crates are required but not provided. On occasion we are able to get some crates donated. Please submit a driver application: http://form.jotform.us/form/50214993744156
06901.title: Saturday transport driver near Stamford CT

06901.description: Stamford Academy, our alternative high school, has about 140 students. Most of the kids have been unsuccessful in their traditional high school. The staff is highly motivated and dedicated to providing the instruction, support, and attention needed to ensure the students successfully matriculate and graduate. If there ever was a program that lives the Domus vision, this is it! The principal is seeking a volunteer who says, \"What do you need?\" Examples of activities include: keeping the bulletin boards current, light data entry or other administrative functions, and general organizing. Once you're comfortable, there is also ample opportunity to get the know the students. If you love Domus, you'll love Stamford Academy.
06901.title: Weekday Helper

06901.description: In collaboration with the Connecticut Food Bank (Commodity Supplemental Food Program) and Charter Oak Communities, Family Centers is looking for volunteers to assist with the unloading and distribution of food boxes at four residential senior locations in Stamford. Volunteers are needed the second Thursday of the month from approximately 9:00-12:30. The delivery schedule will begin at 9:00am and unfold as follows: Stamford Manor (26 Main Street): 50 boxes, Post House (40 Clinton Avenue): 25 boxes, Quintard Manor (18 Quintard Terrace): 15 boxes and lastly Rippowam Manor (11 North Street): 30 boxes. Each stop will take about 30 minutes with the unloading and delivering into the building. Volunteers should be able to lift up to 25lbs. and must provide their own transportation from site to site.
06901.title: Food Delivery Volunteers

06901.description: Domestic Violence Crisis Center (DVCC) is committed to promoting the fundamental right of all individuals to be safe in their personal relationships. The EparanzaCT program is an arm of the DVCC that serves the Latino population in the Fairfield County area. We serve six towns in CT: Stamford, Norwalk, Darien, New Canaan, Westport & Wilton. There is an immediate need for volunteers who speak Spanish. We have opportunities in In-take (Health centers & ER), Hotline, Medical Advocacy Program, Sustainability program (ESL classes, computer instruction, financial planning, Tax help etc.)
06901.title: Bilingual Volunteers

06901.description: Similar to the book cart program in front of our Lockwood Avenue campus, we'd like to start a neighborhood give-away book cart in front of Stamford Academy, our high school on North Street. The come from the community, your friends shelves, and local libraries. If you have 2 hours a week, a flexible schedule, your own transportation, love books, are community minded, and like a little physical activity, this is the volunteer opportunity for you!
06901.title: Become a Book Cart Champion

06901.description: Protect our environment and the special world in which we live. Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL) wants you! As a volunteer, you’ll be a member of the fastest growing and most effective climate advocacy group. You will work with concerned Connecticut citizens to slow the effects of climate change. Together we can protect our beautiful ecosystems, livelihoods and way of life. Please respond to our posting for an invitation to learn more. You will: Meet with Congressional leaders. Write letters to the editors and op-eds. Meet with local media. Educate your community about global warming and legislative solutions. We provide: Monthly national conference calls with expert guest speakers. Weekly skill building sessions. On-line network with CCL volunteers across the U.S. National conference and lobby week in D.C. Volunteers commit to an average of 4-6 hours a month. Some of our volunteers dedicate more time than that. We hold no upper limit on your dedication to a stable climate and livable world. Want to know more? Please join our weekly Introductory Conference Call. The next one is on Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Pacific/6:00 p.m. Mountain/7:00 p.m. Central/8:00 p.m. Eastern. It is a live call, about an hour long, and there will be opportunities to ask questions. Please register for the call at this link so that we can follow up with you: https://citizensclimatelobby.org/join-weekly-intro-call/ We look forward to working with you!
06901.title: Sustainable Climate Environment Advocate Stamford CT

06901.description: This Stamford lady needs a volunteer driver for local trips to area medical offices while she waits for training with her new guide dog. Volunteer in your community with this high impact but easy way to make a huge difference. Requirements to be a great volunteer include: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance; a minimum of $50/100k liability and $5,000 of property damage coverage.
06901.title: Driver or Bus Companion Needed for Stamford Lady and Her Guide Dog
06901.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

06901.description: Do you have wisdom to share? Are you 60 or better and enjoy offering guidance to younger generations? Members of the Elder Wisdom Circle are seniors who share their wisdom with young advice seekers from across the world. Via the Internet, Elders answer advice requests at their own convenience, offering young readers personalized and free advice on a wide range of topics - love and relationships, family and child-rearing, career and self-improvement, and more. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, the Elder Wisdom Circle has more than 600 Elders (aged 60 to 105) across North America. The EWC program and our Elders have been featured on ABC, BBC, CBS, FOX, NPR and in such publications as Glamour, the LA Times, Ladies Home Journal, Real Simple, Time & USA Today. We are one of the largest providers of personal advice, with hundreds of thousands of readers. We are looking for seniors in your area to help expand our national reach. Please visit our site at www.ElderWisdomCircle.org and then the 'Offer Advice' tab on the top of the homepage. All advice providers must be 60 or better, no exceptions. Volunteers must complete an application and screening process.
06901.title: Stamford Area>>>Advice Counselor

06901.description: DVCC's PeaceWorks programs brings awareness and education to the schools in the seven towns that we serve. In our K-5 grade programs focus on anger management and conflict resolution. Our healthy families programs are presented to middle school and high school children. Our healthy relationship workshops are presented in 8th grade and high school. We also do various workshops on the topic of domestic violence to civic groups, professionals, and faith based communities.
06901.title: PeaceWorks Volunteer

06901.description: Office helpers are asked to commit to a four hour shift helping with copying, filing, answering hotline and business phones, computer work, greeting clients, and processing mailings.
06901.title: Office Helpers

10268.description: Sanctuary for Families is New York’s leading service provider and advocate for survivors of domestic violence, sex trafficking, and related forms of gender violence. Every year, Sanctuary empowers thousands of adults and children to move from fear and abuse to safety and stability, transforming lives through a comprehensive range of services. Sanctuary for Families is currently seeking volunteers to assist with the Children's Program at Sarah Burke House (SBH), Sanctuary’s state-of-the-art transitional shelter in the Bronx. SBH provides safe and comfortable housing for a maximum of 58 families each night, as well as an array of comprehensive social services to survivors of domestic violence and their children. The Children’s Program at SBH is currently seeking an energetic student intern who is interested in working with children. This position is available immediately, through the end of December on Monday-Friday afternoons between the hours of 3-6pm. There is an option of continuing into the spring and summer if interested. This internship would be appropriate for an undergraduate college student with an interest in early childhood education, elementary education, or social work. Responsibilities: Assist with the after-school program geared for children in grades K-8 Create and facilitate activities for children Provide support with homework assignments and help improve skills in identified areas of need Qualifications: Intern must be available 3 or 4 days a week, Monday through Friday from 3-6pm Experience working with children Respect for confidentiality Creativity Patience and understanding How to Apply: To apply for this internship, please e-mail Leon Jones, Coordinator of Volunteer Relations at ljones@sffny.org with the subject title \"Children's Program Intern\".
10268.title: Children's Program Intern - Bronx

10466.description: MJHS Hospice provides a specialized program of care and services for end-of-life patients. MJHS Hospice provides care for pediatric and adult patients in homes, nursing homes, assisted living communities, inpatient facilities and hospitals.
