07111.description: Do you have wisdom to share? Are you 60 or better and enjoy offering guidance to younger generations? Members of the Elder Wisdom Circle are seniors who share their wisdom with young advice seekers from across the world. Via the Internet, Elders answer advice requests at their own convenience, offering young readers personalized and free advice on a wide range of topics - love and relationships, family and child-rearing, career and self-improvement, and more. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, the Elder Wisdom Circle has more than 600 Elders (aged 60 to 105) across North America. The EWC program and our Elders have been featured on ABC, BBC, CBS, FOX, NPR and in such publications as Glamour, the LA Times, Ladies Home Journal, Real Simple, Time & USA Today. We are one of the largest providers of personal advice, with hundreds of thousands of readers. We are looking for seniors in your area to help expand our national reach. Please visit our site at www.ElderWisdomCircle.org and then the 'Offer Advice' tab on the top of the homepage. All advice providers must be 60 or better, no exceptions. Volunteers must complete an application and screening process.
07111.title: Irvington>>>Advice Counselor

07114.description: We're looking for some dedicated volunteers with a van willing to donate some of their time to picking up leftover food in Newark, New Jersey. Help us reduce food waste, and get food to those in need. Time: 2:00 AM
07114.title: Stop Food Waste and Feed the Hungry in Newark, New Jersey (Volunteer with a Truck Needed)

07114.description: Travelers Aid Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR) is a nonprofit organization whose staff and volunteers work together to assist passengers from around the world. Travelers Aid EWR seeks to support airport passengers in a variety of capacities. In more complex cases, Travelers Aid staff is prepared to assist with social service referrals, resources and/or connecting individuals with support systems. Volunteers are the core resource of the Travelers Aid program. They lend their knowledge and experience to passengers by suggesting tourist information, giving maps/brochures and offering guidance on how to navigate the airport and the transit systems of New Jersey & New York. Travelers Aid volunteers receive a uniform, complimentary parking, food voucher and (in some cases) public transportation reimbursement. Available shifts are 11:00am to 4:00pm or 4:00pm to 9:00pm, 7 days a week. *At this time we look are looking for volunteers for both shifts on: Monday,Thursday, Fridayand Sunday. For Wednesday And Saturday we are look for volunteers from 4 pm - 9 pm.
07114.title: Meet and help people from ALL OVER THE WORLD!
07114.org: Travelers Aid at Newark Liberty International Airport

07834.description: Are You a caring person looking for a meaningful experience? Do You think you could provide companionship for a patient, such as reading, journaling, playing cards, sharing hobbies, or providing caregiver relief for family members? Do You have a special skill that can be used to provide comfort such as Pet Therapist, Massage Therapist, Beautician, or do you play a Musical Instrument? Kindred Hospice provides specialized healthcare that allows patients with life-limiting illnesses to live out their days as fully and as comfortably as possible wherever they call home. Volunteer work is flexible and based on your availability. We are grateful for as much time as you can give! Free training provided. Contact Elaine Carlsen, Volunteer Coordinator at Elaine.Carlsen@gentiva.com or call 888-556-8880!
07834.title: Friendly Visitor Needed in Morris County!

07834.description: Do you have a curiosity about global affairs? Lead a U.S. foreign policy discussion group today! For over 55 years, the Foreign Policy Association's Great Decisions program has brought together people and communities to encourage individuals to engage in the world around them and to think critically about the global issues facing policymakers. Each year, FPA produces the Great Decisions briefing book, examining eight U.S. foreign policy and global affairs topics. All across the U.S., discussion groups meet to consider and discuss these topics, constituting the largest civil-education network in the country. Discussion group leaders organize and lead these meetings in their communities. Become a group leader now!
07834.title: Lead a global affairs discussion in the Denville area today!!

07059.description: The Growing to Give Program (GGP), Wagner Farm Arboretum (WFA) Education Committee, and Warren Township schools collaborate to produce vegetables for donation, educate students in organic gardening skills, encourage student awareness of local poverty, and offer them the opportunity to serve through volunteerism. WFA supply training and publicity materials and teachers incorporate nature lessons in the classroom. Elementary students will grow 4 seedlings of selected vegetables in the classroom and at planting time will go to the Giving Garden and plant their seedlings with advice of teachers and experienced gardeners The children will experience an educational/service field trip day to WFAF where they will learn about bee keeping, the story of Wagner Farm Arboretum, as well as perform volunteer service for Giving Garden, Children’s Garden, and the Growing to Give program. Responsibilities and schedule 32 hours - Flexible schedule during end of March, Prepare for program working with school representative and arboretum personnel. Enlist 4 to 6 gardeners to volunteer as advisors on seed planting day. 8 hour day - One day in early April - Planting at school, Include a short informative presentation for each group. Oversee volunteers supervising the planting, labeling, and watering. Each class takes its plant trays to classroom. 12 hours - Periodically check in with classes as to progress of the seedlings. 8 hours - Prepare for school field trip. Identify and schedule presentations and work assignments. Collaborate with school officials and Arboretum leaders. 8 hour day - One day(mid May) during Implement the field trip plan. 6 hours - Pick up and transfer the seedlings from the school to the cold frame in Giving Garden area. 16 hours - Maintain and improve the seedling quality and verify plots are ready for planting. 6 hours - Insure that volunteer gardeners are available to supervise on planting day. 8 hour day - one day(last week of May or first week of June). Oversee the planting. Approximately 16 classes will participate arriving by bus trips of 4 classes per trip.
07059.title: Growing to Give Program Facilitator

07059.description: Planning Provide ideas & goals for upcoming season (plantings, projects, plans, ideas for corporate volunteers and plans) Create a plan on how to accomplish goals for the year (corporations volunteers, budget money, projects) Compile a budget for upcoming year to present to Board of Trustees. Pull together an annual report including budget for last season to close out year. Budget & Reporting NOTE: Budgets from previous years are available to use as a template Contact potential volunteers. Manage volunteer activities for individuals and groups. Volunteers NOTE: Plans from previous years are available on how to organize corporate events Garden Management (includes area in front of Office) Put out decorations and signs in garden for new season (letters for ABC garden, fairy garden decorations, sings for fairy garden and ABC garden) Prepare beds with mulch, begin planting annuals Water areas where sprinklers have not been installed. Maintain overall Children’s Garden appearance and front of office. Includes weeding and deadheading. Management of perennials by ensuring the growth and spread is maintained. Fall cleanup. Remove annuals. Cut back perennials. Store signs and decorations in the shed.
07059.title: Children’s Garden Administrator

07059.description: Assists therapists with variety of non-therapeutic duties. Acts as an opportunity for volunteers to observe actual therapy treatment sessions. Excellent area for volunteers looking to explore potential career choice in therapy related fields. Responsibilities include organizing/straightening closets/shelves in treatment rooms. Clean/returns toys to proper locations. Assists therapists with set-up/clean-up of activities. Performs necessary office/clerical tasks including copying, filing and organizational tasks. Assists therapist with engaging patients in play activities.
07059.title: Therapy Gym Assistant

07052.description: A Jersey Cares Project Coordinator will assist volunteers in mentoring students by leading book discussions, assisting students in studying for exams, helping in creative arts or just by talking about the everyday challenges of life. Volunteers are needed to help highly motivated, academically qualified, yet economically disadvantaged eighth grade students with their math and writing. The program’s goal is to develop future leaders through education. Students participate in a rigorous 14-month preparatory program that places them in competitive, primarily independent, secondary schools. NOTE: To participate in this project you must be a Jersey Cares volunteer. To sign up as a Jersey Cares volunteer: 1. Visit www.jerseycares.org 2. Click on \"Log-In\" 3. Click on \"Not a Member? Register\" 4. Fill out all necessary information. 5. Register for a project!
07052.title: Tutor and Mentor in West Orange

07052.description: Reading Buddies, a program of the RSVP Center of Essex and Hudson Counties at Jewish Family Service MetroWest, engages older adult volunteers in promoting childhood literacy in public schools. Volunteers age 55+ read to the same small group of students each week throughout the school year using a read-aloud format that supplements the school’s regular reading curriculum. Reading Buddies is a one of a kind program that uses volunteers to support children grades k-2 and educators in the classroom. This program is a one hour commitment once a week. All volunteers must submit to a background check. If you are interested in signing up to read to children or would like to know what schools we currently need volunteers in, please contact Rebecca Silverstein at rsilverstein@jfsmetrowest.org or 793-637-1761.
07052.title: Reading Buddies (Essex County)

07052.description: Serenity Hospice Care has patients in facilities all over NJ. We need your help to increase their quality of life in a positive way. We work around your schedule, time and location preferences. You do not need any experience, we will teach you everything you need to know. We need volunteers to give companionship, read, watch TV, Talk, Listen, it all makes a difference. If you have special talents such as Pet Therapy, Music, Art, Knitting that is always appreciated as well!!! We will work together to make the most out of the time you have to offer. No amount of time is too little...We appreciate anything you can offer. There are Two different types of volunteers: Administrative Volunteers: Various Office Duties including filing, phone work, supply organization etc...(Located at 52 Georgetown Road Bordentown, NJ 08505) Direct Patient Volunteers: (Various Locations throughout NJ) Visit patient in facility or home. Offer companionship by simply listening, talking, reading or watching TV. If you would like to share your special talents such as Pet Therapy, Music, Art, Knitting that would be greatly appreciated as well!!! We reimburse you for all travel time!! Our Volunteers are part of our family! We will be there for you every step of the way to support you and assist you. We want you to be happy and successful! Volunteering with Serenity Hospice Care will sure to be equally as rewarding for you as it will be for the patient!!! To learn more about our volunteer program please call AJ Blair at 609-227-2400 or email at ablair@serenityhospicenj.com I truly look forward to hearing from you!!! Thank you for your time and consideration!!
07052.title: Make a difference! Looking for caring people to make a hospice patient smile! Locations all over NJ

07055.description: Hello! Our organization is seeking volunteers during the week between the hours of 8am to 1pm to assist with stocking our food pantry. We order our pantry items from the Community Food Bank of NJ in Hillside and we need volunteers to help with picking up the order and delivering the order to us at our locating in Passaic. The drive from the Food Bank to our pantry is about 30 minutes, so overall it would require about an hour And is flexible between 8am to 1pm These orders are placed every other week and we are in need of volunteers to assist in pick up. Our pantry is growing, we serve over 60 clients during our pantry hours and we appreciate any help we can get with getting our orders to our pantry! Our organization is https://www.smileforcharity.org Check us out and please contact us if you can spare some free time!
07055.title: Food pantry order pick-up volunteers

07055.description: Our Food Pantry Opens the first and third Saturday of every month from 3pm to 7pm. We are looking for a variety of volunteers to help stock our shelves, facilitate greeting clients, and helping our clients with their pantry choices. Volunteer shift are flexible from 2-3 hours from 12 noon to 7:30pm. We welcome volunteers of all ages and backgrounds with a willingness to serve our community. Our food pantry is there to supplement their current food supply and help ensure that they don’t have to make tough choices that the rest of us have the luxury of not worrying about like choosing between buying diapers or buying baby food. High school volunteers seeking volunteer hours are welcome! We would love to have Corporate Volunteers as well seeking team-building opportnities for their employees! JOIN OUT FACEBOOK PAGE FOR MORE VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES WITH OUR FOOD PANTRY! https://www.facebook.com/groups/SmileForCharity/
07055.title: Food Pantry Volunteers

07055.description: Assist in many ways to make the lives of seniors living in the community more satisfying. You can drive, deliver meals, visit at home, escort to Doctors appointments, help plan recreational activities
07055.title: senior companion

07055.description: There are a number of ways in which one can relate to senior citizens, reading to those who are visually impaired, driving for meals on wheels, joing our aging in place program and assisting in program planning and on site visits, serving lunch once a week, or newly added to our program, teaching and playing wii!
07055.title: Senior relationship volunteer

07054.description: Seeking a volunteer or student looking for experience to serve as a Class Aide within our community diabetes education classes. Our foundation offers interactive, educational classes (along with free healthy dinner) to the community, and an Aide is needed to help participants complete paperwork, help nurses get health screenings completed, help serve meals, and assist with general handouts. You will work directly with dietitians and the class moderator. This is a great opportunity to be involved directly with public health and community education, including gaining nutrition and nursing information that could be valuable for you. This is also a great opportunity for someone with diabetes who wants to help others! We only ask that you assist one evening per month, from 5:30pm until a little after 7pm (last Wednesday of each month) from April until November 2017. Must commit to entire block of classes for continuity. Please apply asap if interested!
07054.title: Student or Volunteer To Serve as Aide in Monthly Diabetes Classes

11102.description: Pianist Needed for Senior Chorus in Astoria HANAC Innovative SS Choral group \"The HANAC Harmonizers\" is seeking a volunteer accompanist for weekly rehearsals and semi-annual performances. We currently use karaoke tracks and would like to begin working with live accompaniment. We sing popular music, jazz standards, Broadway, 50’s and Motown. We meet on Tuesdays from 10:30-11:30am. 11102.description: NEWS RELEASE - GOODGUIDES(tm) January 20, 2010 GOODWILL (r) TO HELP MENTOR TEENS Justice Department Grant to Fight Juvenile Delinquency Astoria, New York -- Goodwill Industries of Greater NY and Northern NJ is proud to launch a new program in Astoria, New York designed to assist youth in overcoming disadvantages and avoiding delinquency. The effort is part of a national mentoring program known as Goodwill(r) GoodGuides(tm) that helps teens finish school and transition into productive careers through the guidance of trusted adults. \"Goodwill has a long history of helping people find work,\" said Mrs. Karen Means , Senior Vice President of Youth Services \"A crucial part of that history is making sure that families are strong. Goodwill GoodGuides(tm) can help keep youth who are at-risk get on the right path, away from trouble and toward a better future. That's good for everyone involved.\" The Goodwill GoodGuides(tm) program in Astoria, New York is made possible through a two-year, $299,723 grant to Goodwill Industries of Greater NY and Northern NJ The donation is part of a $19.1 million award to Goodwill Industries International from the U.S. Department of Justice and dispersed to 56 independent Goodwill agencies around the country. The overall goal of the Goodwill GoodGuides(tm) program is to help youth build career plans and skills, and prepare for school completion, post-secondary training and productive work by providing structured and supportive relationships with trusted adult mentors. It targets youths between the ages of 12 and 17 who are at-risk for dropping out of school, facing legal troubles, or are at risk for delinquency due to issues such as abuse, disability, drug or alcohol dependence, or gang membership. \"With Goodwill GoodGuides(tm), we will be able to offer expanded mentoring services to the youth of our community,\" said Mrs. Karen Means, Senior Vice President of Youth Services, Goodwill Industries of Greater NY and Northern NJ . \"Goodwill will recruit, train and support volunteer mentors to engage youth in promoting their career development and life skills.\" The Goodwill GoodGuides(tm) program will launch on January 11 in Astoria, New York If you're interested in becoming a volunteer mentor or know of a youth who would benefit from this program, please call 718 777 6443 Contact: Mr. Anthony Whittaker, 718 777 6443 Goodwill Industries of Greater NY and Northern NJ 4 - 21 27 th Avenue Astoria, NY 11102 Click on the link below and visit the WONDERFUL world of Astoria GoodGuides Mentoring. http://www.wix.com/goodguidesmentoring/goodguides
11102.title: GoodGuides Mentoring Program Queens, New York
11102.org: Goodwill Industries of Greater NY & Northern NJ, Inc.

11101.description: Welcome to our ESL Practice Program at The English Language Center! Many of our students live with family or friends and don't get to practice these skills outside of class. Writing Partners, on the other hand, help individual students with homework from their writing and grammar classes as well as help students improve their overall writing skills. Volunteers are asked to commit only one hour per week, though we are happy to have you more often if you like. Our students are very motivated and fun to work with, and they are very appreciative of any help you can give. Please contact Marek Pena at marpena@lagcc.cuny.edu for more information.

We have spots on our board for 2-3 volunteers with legal/business experience. Please contact us with your resume.

11101.description: Protect our environment and the special place in which we live! Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL) wants you! As a volunteer, you’ll be a member of the fastest growing and most effective climate advocacy group. You will work with concerned New York citizens to slow the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our beautiful ecosystems, livelihoods and way of life. Please respond to our posting for an invitation to learn more. You will: Meet with Congressional leaders. Write letters to the editors and op-eds. Meet with local media. Educate your community about global warming and legislative solutions. We provide: Monthly national conference calls with expert guest speakers. Weekly skill building sessions. On-line network with CCL volunteers across the U.S. National conference and lobby week in D.C. Volunteers commit to an average of 4-6 hours a month. Some of our volunteers dedicate more time than that. We hold no upper limit on your dedication to a stable climate and livable world. To learn more about us, please join an Introductory Conference Call. The next call is Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Pacific/6:00 p.m. Mountain/7:00 p.m. Central/8:00 p.m. Eastern. This is an opportunity to learn about CCL. It is one hour, and there will be opportunities to ask questions. The conference call number is 1-866-642-1665, passcode 440699#.

11101.org: Citizens' Climate Lobby

11101.description: Tax Preparation Volunteers , Urban Upbound, formerly known as ERDA. Urban Upbound provides residents of public housing neighborhoods and other moderate, low- and very-low income New Yorkers with the tools and resources needed to achieve self-sufficiency and economic mobility, and to break intergenerational cycles of poverty. The target area we serve includes the 30,000 residents of five public housing neighborhoods in Western Queens: Queensbridge (the largest public housing community in the nation), Ravenswood, Astoria, Woodside, and Pomonok. The neighborhoods where these communities are located include Long Island City, Woodside, Astoria, and Flushing. One of Urban Upbound's most successful initiatives is our Free Tax Preparation Campaign, where we help low-income filers access the tax credits for which they are eligible - saving working families hundreds of dollars in unnecessary tax preparation fees. Additionally, tax filers have the opportunity to: enroll in Urban Upbound's workforce development program to receive assistance finding work; sign up for one-on-one financial counseling; get pre-screened for food stamps, public assistance and low or no cost health insurance; and, open a bank account. We are currently recruiting volunteers to help make this year's tax prep season another success! As a volunteer you will have the unique opportunity to work in a dynamic, high impact, results oriented community based organization. Qualified candidates will utilize their accounting and financial skills while giving back to the community. All volunteer tax preparers are asked to successfully complete the IRS online Link & Learn course. Long Island City does free taxes all year round! Skills and Qualifications Ability to work with diverse populations Commitment to social and economic justice Excellent time-management and organizational skills Independent self-starter Strong teamwork abilities Bilingual (Spanish; Mandarin, Korean) a plus Facility with numbers and commitment to learning tax law and Tax Wise software
11101.title: Tax Preparation Volunteers
11101.org: Urban Upbound

11101.description: Rehabilitation and Evaluation Services - The Afghanistan Blind Women and Children Foundation will provide the rehabilitation services for women and children who are blind. The rehabilitation department offers services for blind children helping them acquire the physical and mental skills necessary for education, social development, and helping them prepare for entering the workforce. We are looking for volunteers that have past experience in rehabilitation and evaluation services on a professional or personal level. Your task is to supervise your department in: Managing all members of your team and being creative in ways of attracting additional volunteers and employees to your department. Rehabilitation should be able to address the student's physical, psychological, and environmental needs. It is achieved by restoring the student's physical functions and/or modifying the student's physical and social environment. In the field of education, the ABWC Rehabilitation and Evaluation Department is responsible to provide the following services: Improve understanding of CNS structure and function, neural plasticity, and the performance of everyday educational tasks so that the perceptual processing capabilities of students with low vision or blindness can be optimized. Develop assistive devices, environmental modifications, and rehabilitation strategies to minimize the impact of visual impairment in everyday life and reduce disability and societal limitations in visually impaired persons. Create a network for the dissemination of research findings to rehabilitation specialists, educators, clinicians, and technology developers. Establish the means and avenues for adapting research for use in clinical and rehabilitation settings. Build an infrastructure for developing future generations of researchers who are concerned with a broad range of topics in visual impairment and rehabilitation. Encourage the multidisciplinary collaboration and training of researchers from other areas about issues pertinent to visual impairment. 11106.description: Our client choice, supermarket-style food pantry runs three distributions per week for two hours each. Our distribution hours are Mondays, 2:00 - 4:00; Tuesdays, 10:30 - 12:30; and Thursdays, 3:00 - 5:00. We seek volunteers for all three shifts, but especially Mondays and Thursdays! Your time commitment will involve arriving at least one hour prior to the start of distribution, and staying through the entire two hour shift. Responsibilities include stocking shelves, sorting and storing produce, helping clients shop, breaking down boxes, and routine clean up. We are also seeking a dedicated desk volunteer who is responsible for checking in clients when they arrive. This is energetic, fast-paced work with a lovely group of core volunteers from the community! We strive to provide food to those in need in the most welcoming, warm way possible. Bring your customer service skills! Bilingual abilities are definitely a plus as well. Please apply ONLY if you will be committing to volunteer with us at least once per week for at least one month. We are unable to train volunteers for a one-time shift.

11104.description: Sunnyside Community Services, based in Queens, New York, offers a range of life-enhancing programs that benefit approximately 14,000 individuals per year. From Early Childhood Education to Senior Services, we provide programs for all ages. Our services include: pre-kindergarten and after school programs; college prep and career programs for teens and young adults; Our after-school programs provide fun and challenging enrichment activities for your children. We provide after-school programs at P.S. 150 and P.S. 199 in Sunnyside for elementary school students (grades K - 5). Programs for middle school students (grades 6 - 8) are available at SCS’ main site and at the Boulevard Family Residence in Elmhurst. The Sunnyside Cornerstone Program at Woodside Houses provides opportunities for children, teenagers, and adults to participate in structured after-school programs and drop-in activities including performing arts and music, athletics, computers, reading, chess, and more. Our Needs: Volunteer Tutors What We’re Looking For Volunteers to do Lead tutoring sessions while supported by staff Support participants with homework completion and a subject of your choice, including: English, Math, Science, and Social Studies; Serve as a role model and build positive relationships with youth; Strong background in one or more of the following academic subjects: English, Math, Science, and/or Social Studies Previous experience working with youth; Posses enthusiasm and patience Strong oral communication skills Ability to make weekly commitments Previous tutoring experience (a plus) At least one 2 hour to 2.5 hour session per week, Monday-Thursday. 11104.description: I have a Polish-speaking woman in Astoria, Queens who needs someone to visit her. The volunteer must also speak enough English to communicate with the Program Coordinator. If you have an hour a week you could dedicate to this lonely senior, please contact me! Friendly visiting is an easy, fun, rewarding way to become involved in your community. The Friendly Visitor Program at Sunnyside Community Services covers areas of Queens, including Astoria, Elmhurst, East Elmhurst, Jackson Heights, Corona, Forest Hills, Rego Park, Flushing, Maspeth, Middle Village, Long Island City, Ridgewood, Sunnyside, Woodside and more. Friendly Visitors are volunteers who visit homebound seniors for about an hour each week in their homes. Volunteers reduce feelings of isolation, and help improve seniors' mental and physical health. Seniors are able to stay in their homes and communities longer. Volunteers can dramatically improve the quality of a seniors' life. The Friendly Visitor Program is funded by grants from CityMeals-on-Wheels and serves homebound seniors who receive meal deliveries. Clients receiving visitors are often unable to go outside on their own and depend on visitors for social interaction. 11104.title: Help Serve Lunch to Seniors at Sunnyside!

11104.description: PURPOSE: Provide case assistance, information and referral for seniors. Help seniors acquire benefits and entitlements so they can remain in and continue their involvement in the community. RESPONSIBILITIES: Be the first face of the senior center’s service area, welcoming seniors, and encouraging their participation Conduct intakes to determine eligibility and assist seniors in accessing benefits and entitlements Work as a liaison in connecting seniors to other agency and community programs Assist with information and referral regarding services Maintain strict confidentiality for both client and personnel files Conduct ongoing support group sessions in English and Spanish Conduct follow up via telephone with senior center members Maintain detailed logs of services rendered Assist in other areas of the senior center as needed VOLUNTEER QUALITIES: Excellent interpersonal and communication skills Analytical and able to make decisions with limited information Able to adjust to a fast pace environment Ability to work independently and in a team environment Self-motivated Availabile anytime between Monday - Friday 9am-5pm TECHNICAL & SKILLS REQUIREMENTS: Comfortable using a computer Ability to develop and maintain effective working relationships with staff, volunteers, and clients Ability to communicate effectively both orally and in writing Bilingual English/Spanish
11104.title: Help Seniors Get Access to Benefits!

11104.description: Purpose: Provide administrative support in one or more of SCS’s administrative offices including our Home Care division, Home Health Aide program, Human Resources department, Compliance, Fiscal, Office Management, etc. Activities: Depending on Department needs, preferences, skills and availability you may be assisting with: Filing Answering Phones Administering Surveys Inputing Data Updating / Maintaining Logs Updating Client Folders Updating Personnel Records Assisting In Classes Telephone Followups Assisting In Other Needed Areas Desirable Skills Attention To Details Excellent Interpersonal and Communication Skills Consistent Able to Develop Effective Working Relationships Work well with Others Bilingual English/ Spanish a Plus Computer Literacy - Microsoft Office: Word, Excel
11104.title: Sunnyside Community Services - Administrative Volunteer

11104.description: About: For many families, the Social Adult Day Program offers a welcome alternative to a nursing home. Seniors can remain living in their homes, and caregivers can make time for their careers, for other family members, or for themselves. As a volunteer, under the direction of program staff you will be assisting with seniors activities and meal times. The welcoming and home-like center includes a kitchen, a dining area, and activity room. Our highly qualified staff can assist with medication reminders, personal care, and grooming. A low staff-to-participant ratio enables us to offer each senior individualized assistance as needed. Activities include: Therapeutic music, art, and dance sessions Sensory activities Storytelling Gentle exercises Reminiscence groups Arts and crafts The program serves a hot, nutritious lunch each day. We also offer door-to-door transportation in a van that is accessible to people in wheelchairs and people with limited mobility. Requirements: Make at least a 3-month commitment Must have a medical clearance and an up-to-date (within 2 years) PPD test Choose you day/s, Mondays through Fridays; hours are set, 10am to 3pm Qualities: Ability to develop and maintain effective working relationships with staff, volunteers, and clients Ability to communicate effectively Sensitivity to diverse cultures Be caring, considerate, compassionate, patient
11104.title: Adult Day Services for Seniors Volunteer

Volunteers must initially meet with me at my office in Sunnyside Queens and commit to calling someone once per week for at least 6 months! The Friendly Visitor Program is run by Sunnyside Community Services and covers all areas of Queens including Astoria, Elmhurst, East Elmhurst, Jackson Heights, Corona, Forest Hills, Flushing, Maspeth, Middle Village, Long Island City, Ridgewood, Sunnyside, Woodside, Rego Park and more. 11771.description: CCH’s Afterschool Enrichment Program is a program that helps support students from grades K - 6th. The majority of these students come from homes where English is not the first language spoken, and as a result parents often do not understand English sufficiently to help them with their homework and other academic activities. Through the program we hope to develop responsible youths for the community, and help foster the skills necessary for them to succeed in school, participate in extra-curricular activities, and increase their chances to attend a college or university. Since we are a non-profit, we ask for the help of those in our community to achieve this goal. We need volunteers/mentors to donate their time to help these students. The program is held Monday through Friday (school calendar) from 3:00PM to 5:30Pm in Oyster Bay. We are also looking for volunteers to help tutor the 7th-12th grade ESL students in our program that could use the extra study time and regents prep. That would take place in our office in Oyster Bay and could be done any weekday after 6pm. THIS IS A GREAT OPPORTUNITY FOR A HIGH SCHOOL STUDENT LOOKING TO VOLUNTEER!
11771.title: Volunteers Needed for Homework Help and Tutoring at After School Program
11771.org: CENTRO CULTURAL HISPANO DE OYSTER BAY EAST NORWICH

11553.description: RotaCare is a 5013(c) not for profit organization who facilitates the provision of free healthcare for the uninsured who do not qualify for any federal, state or local programs. Presently we are seeking a Treasurer for our organization. The Treasurer is an Officer & member of the Board of Directors, attends all scheduled meetings and actively seeks to maintain current knowledge of the organization, it's programs, bylaws and articles of incorporation. The Treasurer is required to have a working knowledge of nonprofit accounting practices, nonprofit tax laws and fiscal record-keeping. Provides financial leadership to the organization. This position requires 5 hours per month with a maximum of 20 hours per month related to the organization’s annual fundraiser and annual yearly audit preparation. Interested individuals should contact the organization for full position description.
11553.title: Treasurer

11553.description: Registered Nurses needed to assist Pharmacists in our Medication Room. Rotacare is a non-profit primary care health care clinic serving Long Island's most needy. The Prescription Program for Indigent Patients (PPIP) obtains free medication from pharmaceutical companies for our patients. The program is invaluable for RotaCare, but the application process is labor intensive. We need assistance completing the applications; tracking the applications and the shipments of medicine; contacting the drug manufacturers; and assuring the patients receive the correct medicine. Without this program RotaCare could not provide free medication for our patients and the patients would not get their vital medications because they could not afford them. Additional volunteers assisting in this department would help us ensure that our patients get the medicine they need. 11553.title: Help Our Patients Obtain Free Medications

11553.description: RotaCare is a free health center run by volunteers to provide health care to those who are without health insurance and are unable to afford care. Physicians are needed to provide primary care for our patients. RotaCare is not a Walk-in clinic. It operates as a doctor's office and doctors are responsible for the overall management of the patients, many of whom have chronic conditions such as diabetes and hypertension. Doctors also make referrals to specialists who have a relationship with RotaCare and have agreed to see our patients free of charge. A small time commitment can help individuals who would otherwise go without medical care, keeping them out of the hospital, at work and caring for their family. Since 1992, RotaCare has been providing free primary care to people who are uninsured and financially eligible. A rotating staff of about 100 volunteers includes doctors, nurse practitioners, pharmacists, nurses, and non-medical support staff. The health center is open every Monday, the first and third Thursday of the month and the second and fourth Tuesday of the month. Please leave the best phone number for us to reach you. Mon: 12:30-5:30pm, Tues: 1:30-5:30pm, Thurs: 3:30-7:00pm
11553.title: Physicians

11553.description: RotaCare is a free health center run by volunteers to provide health care to those who are without health insurance and are unable to afford care. Nurse practitioners are needed to provide primary care for our patients. RotaCare is not a walk-in clinic. It operates as a doctor's office and the NPs are responsible for the overall management of the patients, including prescribing medication which is provided to the patients at no cost. The NPs also make referrals to specialists who have a relationship with RotaCare if the necessary care cannot be provided on-site. Since 1992, RotaCare has been providing free primary care to people who are uninsured and financially eligible. A rotating staff of about 100 volunteers includes doctors, nurse practitioners, pharmacists, nurses, and non-medical support staff. The health center is open every Monday, the first and third Thursday of the month and the second and fourth Tuesday of the month. Please leave the best phone number for us to reach you. Mon: 12:30-5:30pm, Tues: 1:30-5:30pm, Thurs: 3:30-7:00pm
11553.title: Nurse Practitioner

06883.description: We are looking for teenagers who share our passion for addressing children's physical and emotional health issues. Through our Teen Council, you can be part of a group of teens who create initiatives that make a difference in improving the lives of children - from medical conditions, to bullying, to economic disparity. Each month, we focus on a particular children's issue - such as pediatric cancer, type 1 diabetes, autism, cystic fibrosis, and bullying. We also promote healthy living by providing nutrition lessons, cooking, and fitness activities for children. If you are interested in learning more, please contact us at info@kidsheartfelthealth.com.
06883.title: Teens with a Heart

11229.description: The main function of an office volunteer is to provide the office with assistance and support. This includes but is not limited to the following: Tasks include filing, mailings, making copies, compiling admission packets, other packets used by hospice field staff and other staff assistance depending on the individual expertise and qualifications.
11229.title: Office Volunteer
11229.org: Caring Hospice Services of New York

11229.description: Hospice volunteers: Visit patients in their homes and in facilities offering companionship and a chance to reminisce Read books, newspapers and other favorites to people when they aren’t able themselves Assist with small errands for the patient and family. Share their talents and gifts... Play Music, sing, draw at bedside of patient, create photo albums, knitt blankets and more. Provide patient the opportunity to tell his/her life story through the use of video, (if patient or caregiver has one available), audio and/or the written word. Office Volunteers assist office staff with basic tasks such as copying and filing, helping with web research, spreadsheets and more. Contribute to volunteer newsletter keeping volunteers and staff in tune with the Hospice Volunteer Program’s activities.
11229.title: Hospice Field Volunteer
11229.org: Caring Hospice Services of New York

06880.description: CAG is seeking an individual to serve as a Board member who has background in strategic marketing, which ideally includes a blend of marketing planning and execution, with direct experience at an advertising agency or on the client side, with branding, advertising and communications experience. Advocacy experience is also highly regarded. CAG desires assistance to expand its reach, awareness and membership statewide - including further penetration into underserved communities. Also important will be cultivating and maintaining relationships with funders, members, collaborating organizations and legislators as well as the ability to work at a quick pace, flexibly and nimbly. Excellent written and verbal skills are a must. Responsibilities to include the following: Collaborating with the Executive Director and Board leadership to develop and execute a comprehensive marketing and communications plan employing strategies that will broaden programmatic reach and deepen impact, including hands-on experience with all appropriate aspects of social media Managing the ongoing promotion of major programs and developing and executing messaging for new initiatives Identifying and crafting stories that communicate the essence of the organization’s mission and successes Working with the technology-development team to identify a set of meaningful touchpoints with our targets - new member joining, annual pledging - and creating an array of appropriate communications to be automated and sent, in order to stay current and ensure maximum engagement and support from our stakeholders. Working with all CAG committees, specifically including Development and Programming, to assist with execution of their annual plans and to help further corporate engagement efforts Identifying significant media and public policy issues that can be leveraged to support CAG’s work, and creating and implementing plans to exploit them
06880.title: Connecticut Association for the Gifted - BOD Opening in Marketing/Advertising

06880.description: The Connecticut Association for the Gifted (CAG), founded in 1969, is the pre-eminent parent, teacher and school resource, and legislative advocate forConnecticut’s talented and high-ability students. CAG provides families with information, resources and programs to benefit their gifted and talented children; educators with high-quality professional development; and Boards of Education with the tools to support talented students. CAG is seeking an individual to serve as a Board member who has a hands-on background in public relations, including firsthand social media experience. The ideal candidate would possess a working knowledge of strategic marketing that includes a blend of media relations, marketing planning and advocacy. CAG desires assistance to expand its reach, awareness and membership statewide -- including further penetration into underserved communities. Also important will be cultivating and maintaining relationships with funders, legislators and collaborating organizations, as well as the ability to work at a quick pace, flexibly and nimbly. Must also possess excellent written and verbal skills. Responsibilities to include the following: Identifying and crafting stories that communicate the essence of an organization’s mission and successes Collaborating with the Executive Director and Board leadership to develop and execute a comprehensive communications plan employing strategies that will broaden programmatic reach and deepen impact Developing and refining \"core\" organizational messages to ensure consistency across all platforms Identifying significant media and public policy issues that can be leveraged to support CAG’s work, and creating and implementing plans to exploit them Managing messaging for ongoing promotion of major programs and developing messaging for new initiatives Along with ED and officers, representing organization at public events, conferences, workshops, networking groups and media events Developing and supporting relationships with CT media Working with all appropriate committees including Development and Partnership, to assist with corporate/small business/like-minded organization engagement efforts Serving as Executive Editor for the organization's website Along with Program Coordinator, overseeing organizational response to inquiries about CAG Coaching and supporting all staff and board members as spokespersons Previous experience on a non-profit board is helpful This is an unpaid (volunteer) position. To apply or for further information contact Lisa Garner at execdirector@ctgifted.org.
06880.title: Connecticut Association for the Gifted - Board of Directors Member Experienced in Public Relations

06880.description: The Westport Mentor Program is a school-based program where individuals from the community meet for 45 minutes per week, on school grounds, during the school year, to offer friendship, support-and a non-judgmental ear. Mentors are matched to students grade K-12. A mentor establishes a one-on-one relationship with the student by acting as a friend, guide and role model. The goal of the program is to build a child's self-esteem and develop positive relationships in school, at home, and in the community. If you are interested or would like more information, please contact Lauren Rosenkranz, Westport Mentor Program Coordinator, 203.341.1183 or lrosenkranz@westportct.gov
06880.title: Make a Difference in the life of a child...Be a Mentor

10044.description: Objective Be The Match Board of Ambassadors (BoA) is an integral part of our fundraising efforts, serving as representatives of Be The Match within the community to identify, engage and build relationships with individuals and corporations in support of the Be The Match Soiree event to advance our lifesaving mission. Attributes * Individuals of affluence and/or influence in the community * Strong interest in fundraising and charitable giving * Well respected in the community and/or their individual networks * Goal oriented * Has an affinity for Be The Match mission Responsibilities** ** in collaboration with Development Manager and Be The Match Foundation * Actively engage in raising $5,000 in sponsorship, attendees and/or contributions * Collaborate with BoA to identify and coordinate fundraising asks * Support the mission and activities of Be The Match Foundation as a representative, relationship builder and recognition provider * Promote Soiree event through personal and professional network * Identify additional leaders to join BoA * Attend monthly BoA meetings * Provide input and ownership in the Be The Match Soiree development plan Our Board of Ambassadors will be recognized at the Be The Match Soiree, on our Be The Match Soiree materials program and the Be The Match Annual Report.
10044.title: Be The Match New York Soiree Board of Ambassadors

07751.description: Welcome to the ASD Climber Foundation! ASD stands for Autism Spectrum Disorders. We are working with a family in your area with a child on the autism spectrum. The family wants to train volunteers to help them run a home based social skills program called the Son-Rise Program. No experience necessary. Free training provided. Time commitment is 2-4 hours a week for 6 months or more. PLEASE READ: After completing the \"I want to help\" page, you will immediately receive an auto reply email with our Volunteer Profile. Please fill this out, and we will forward it directly to the family in your area that requires help. ***please add asdclimberfoundation@me.com to your safe list and check your junk mail if you do not see an immediate response in your inbox*** Thank you for your time!
07751.title: Morganville, NJ: Autism Volunteer

11226.description: Work with Adult Literacy Students at one of the five Brooklyn Public Library Learning Centers. Help them reach their personal goals. Lead reading and writing activities for small groups of adult learners who read below the fifth grade level. Assist them in using technology. We provide a 20 hour Volunteer Tutor Training where you will learn the BPL’s Literacy Program’s philosophy, how to use the library’s resources for instruction, and how to create effective lesson plans. Professional staff will encourage your development in this richly rewarding field. Volunteers must have a high school diploma or equivalent and a love of reading and writing. Volunteers are asked for a one year commitment to tutoring either 2 - 2 hours sessions, or 1 - 3-hour session per week. To learn more about the Brooklyn Public Library Learning Centers, please visit the BPL website at http://www.bklynpubliclibrary.org/support/volunteer/adult-literacy-volunteer-tutor.
11226.title: Literacy Volunteer Information Session
11226.org: The Learning Centers @ Brooklyn Public Library

11226.description: Position Description: Maa Sa Akhi Performing Arts Academy seeks a Development Assistant to provide administrative support for the Director in all aspects of Maa Sa Akhi development. This role requires solid people management expertise. The Development Assistant must be a flexible and engaging individual who can analyze and prioritize tasks and build trusting relationships for the effective achievement of results. This person will report to and get approval from the Director before implementing any new procedure or changing any policy. As a member of Maa Sa Akhi’s development team, the Development Assistant will work closely with the Director, as well as other Maa Sa Akhi staff, faculty, and Board members to assist in the administration, coordination and implementation of all development activities. The ideal candidate will be interested in nonprofit arts administration and fundraising, and be passionate about the mission of Maa Sa Akhi Performing Arts Academy : to help each student realize their innate excellence through the performing arts toward success in their every endeavor.
11226.title: Development Assistant, Part-Time
11226.org: Maa Sa Akhi Performing Arts Academy

11226.description: Wishgranting volunteers work directly with wish children and their families to live out the mission of Make-A-Wish through granting wishes! You will work with a volunteer partner, and meet with your wish child and their family. You will then have the magical conversation about your wish kid’s wish! Volunteers work with each child to determine his or her heartfelt wish and complete the granting of the wish with Program staff. Following your initial interview with a wish child, you and your volunteer partner maintain communication with the family and Make-A-Wish staff about the status of the wish. This helps build excitement and anticipation for the wish experience until the day the wish comes true! Wish granters are required to be a minimum age of 21, interview the wish child at their home or in the hospital, work collaboratively, and have excellent communications skills. This role does not require a specific number of volunteer hours per week but requires each volunteer to see the experience through from start to finish. Interviews with wish children are scheduled at the convenience of the volunteers and wish families. The wish process, from start to finish, can take anywhere between six months to two and a half years to reach completion.
11226.title: Wishgranting Volunteers
11226.org: Make-A-Wish Metro New York and Western New York

11226.description: If you could go anywhere, meet anyone, be anything, or have anything you most wanted . . . what would it be? Become a Wishgranting Volunteer and help create moments of hope, strength, and joy for children in Metro New York. As a Wishgranting Volunteer, you will be paired up in teams of two to interview children with life-threatening illnesses to determine their heartfelt wish. You will assist in the granting of each wish with Make-A-Wish staff and your volunteer partner.
11226.title: Help make wishes come true!
11226.org: Make-A-Wish Metro New York and Western New York

07607.description: If you have an hour or more per week to give, Ascend Hospice welcomes your gifts of time and compassion. Whether you choose to work directly with patients and families or to volunteer in one of many other ways, you can make a profound difference in someone's life, including your own. Volunteers are an integral part of the hospice team. Volunteer Opportunities: Companionship Volunteers work directly with patients providing companionship, offering friendly visits, reading to patients, writing letters, offering a gentle touch or sharing a quiet moment. Complementary Volunteers are certified/trained professionals who can provide complementary modalities of reflexologly, music, Reiki, & massage. Pet Therapy Volunteers provide companionship from our certified therapy dogs. Administrative Volunteers provide help in our Cranford office by assisting with typing, addressing cards, organizing newsletters, creating packets, collating manuals and other varied clerical duties Craft Volunteers consist of individuals or groups who touch patients in a special way by making lap blankets, shawls, memory bears and other articles for patients to enjoy. Bereavement Volunteers offer support to the families of patients who have passed. During the grieving process the bereavement volunteer can be a valuable resource, especially for those who lack a solid support network. They often make phone calls to check up on family members and also send cards of comfort and care. Ascend Hospice serves counties throughout New Jersey. Areas where you are needed include: Atlantic County, Bergen County, Cape May County, Essex County, Hudson County, Mercer County, Middlesex County, Monmouth County, Morris County, North Passaic County, Ocean County, Somerset County, South Passaic County, Burlington County, Camden County and Union County. For more information about our free volunteer training and available opportunities, call our Volunteer Department or visit our website at Ascendhospice.com! We look forward to hearing from you! do NOT contact me with unsolicited services or offers
07607.title: Companionship Volunteer for Hospice

07607.description: Are you looking for something to do ? How about volunteering for MDA? (The Muscular Dystrophy Association) We are seeking people to volunteer their time to help out in our office in Maywood, NJ , anyday, Monday through Friday, between 9am and 5pm. We are looking for people to stuff envelopes and pack materials for various fundraising programs. If you or someone you know would like to be a volunteer for a renowned non-profit organization and help out with our very important fundraising efforts, please contact the Maywood MDA office at 201-843-4452 , or email Connie at cdeering@mdausa.org
07607.title: Looking to Make A Difference Helping Out?

07607.description: Ascend Hospice is seeking Reiki practitioners to volunteer their time to those in their community. Reiki can assist with pain management, anxiety, emotional release and much more and is a wonderfil modality to use during end of life care. Hospice training is provided.
07607.title: Reiki Volunteer for Hospice

07607.description: Patients on Hospice really appreciate music! Won't you share you gifts and talents with others? Music therapy is beneficial to all persons who have functional deficits in physical, psychological, cognitive or social functioning. Research results and clinical experiences attest to the viability of music therapy even in those who are resistive to other treatment approaches. Music is a form of sensory stimulation, which provokes responses due to the familiarity, predictability, and feelings of security associated with it.
07607.title: Music Therapy for Hospice

07607.description: Ascend Hospice is seeking Pet Therapy for our hospice patients. Pet therapy provides numerous benefits like encouraging movement and physical stimulation. And mental benefits like socialization, mental stimulation, companionship, and unconditional love. Please consider sharing your loving pet with us and bring some well needed smiles.
07607.title: Pet Therapy for Hospice

11225.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. Through our innovative programs, accomplished authors lead workshops in high-needs classrooms, where they guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. No experience or training is necessary to work with pre-K-12 students. As a writing, research or art coach, you'll engage and encourage their progress on a project. This workshop needs your support at an elementary school in Crown Heights: Program 241KCL-C Wednesday, March 1st, 2017 9:00 - 10:00 AM Writing Coach A kindergarten class read Stuck with the Blooz by Caron Levis, a picture book that helps children talk about emotions by depicting them as friendly monsters. Students will meet with the author to explore ways to handle their feelings, then choose an emotion to write about. Writing coaches will help small groups stay focused, provide supoort and encouragement, and answer their questions about spelling and grammar. For details about other Behind the Book programs around the city, visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/. To join our team and receive announcements of new volunteer opportunities, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
11225.title: Inspire Crown Heights, Brooklyn public school students to love reading

11225.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. Through our innovative programs, accomplished authors lead workshops in high-needs classrooms, where they guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. No experience or training is necessary to work with pre-K-12 students. As a writing, research or art coach, you'll engage and encourage their progress on a project. This workshop needs your support at an elementary school in Crown Heights: Program 241KCL-C Wednesday, March 8th, 2017 9:00 - 10:00 AM Art Coach A kindergarten class read Stuck with the Blooz by Caron Levis, a picture book that helps children talk about emotions by depicting them as friendly monsters. Students will meet with the author to explore ways to handle their feelings, then choose an emotion to write about and illustrate. Art coaches will help small groups stay focused, provide support and encouragement, and oversee clean-up by students. For details about other Behind the Book programs around the city, visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new volunteer opportunities, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
11225.title: Inspire Crown Heights, Brooklyn public school students to love reading

11225.description: The Foundation for Letters promotes improved college access through engagement with writing by providing urban schools with a range of literary-focused academic and enrichment programs. We also provide schools with assistance in the development of their own external support organizations, which build networks of donors, volunteers and partners that support literacy-focused education at their schools. The Foundation is the official charity for the Brooklyn 5K/10k/15k in Prospect Park. We will be helping to administer the race, as well as raising funds to support our writing programs and partner schools. We are also getting kids into the action! Not only will students be running the race, but as a new journalism program at FFL, we will have students covering the action as journalists, photographers, bloggers, interviewers, and live social media correspondents. We are inviting folks to help us as race day volunteers to help out on the course, as volunteers with the kids, or to run or walk one of the distances (you can either run 5k, 10k, 15k or with a kid in the 2k kids race). The race will work just like a typical \"fun run\" for charity, but in the context of a large race. FFL's partners in organizing the Brooklyn 15k (Pacific Sports and Active Network), have given us a guaranteed number of entries into the race at all of the distances (so we're protected against a sell-out). To volunteer or to run to support the Foundation for Letters, reply to this opportunity! For more information, please contact Mike Jackson - mike.jackson@foundationforletters.org www.foundationforletters.org
11225.title: Volunteer on 4/16 at Bklyn 5k: Have fun as a race volunteer & help students learn to be journalists!

11225.description: Trail Blazers' summer and after-school programs support youth development in academic as well as social-emotional skills. To ensure our programs deliver the results for which we are known, we implement a robust evaluation system. Volunteers will assist the Program team in the data entry needed to evaluate program results.
11225.title: Data Entry and Office Support Needed

08890.description: Do you have wisdom to share? Are you 60 or better and enjoy offering guidance to younger generations? Members of the Elder Wisdom Circle are seniors who share their wisdom with young advice seekers from across the world. Via the Internet, Elders answer advice requests at their own convenience, offering young readers personalized and free advice on a wide range of topics - love and relationships, family and child-rearing, career and self-improvement, and more. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, the Elder Wisdom Circle has more than 600 Elders (aged 60 to 105) across North America. The EWC program and our Elders have been featured on ABC, BBC, CBS, FOX, NPR and in such publications as Glamour, the LA Times, Ladies Home Journal, Real Simple, Time & USA Today. We are one of the largest providers of personal advice, with hundreds of thousands of readers. We are looking for seniors in your area to help expand our national reach. Please visit our site at www.ElderWisdomCircle.org and then the 'Offer Advice' tab on the top of the homepage. All advice providers must be 60 or better, no exceptions. Volunteers must complete an application and screening process.
08890.title: Middlesex Area>>>>>Advice Counselor

07601.description: Job Description: Organize activities to raise funds or otherwise solicit and gather monetary donations or other gifts for an organization. May design and produce promotional materials. May also raise awareness of the organization's work, goals, and financial needs. Job Duties and Tasks 1) Develop corporate fundraising programs, such as employer gift-matching. 2) Monitor progress of fundraising drives. 3) Compile or develop materials to submit to granting or other funding organizations. 4) Develop and maintain media contact lists. 5) Develop strategies to encourage new or increased contributions. 6) Recruit sponsors, participants, or volunteers for fundraising events. 7) Direct or supervise fundraising staff, including volunteer staff members. 8) Secure commitments of participation or donation from individuals or corporate donors. 9) Prepare materials for charitable events, such as fundraising envelopes, bid sheets, or gift bags.
07601.title: Fundraiser Coordinator for Youth Non Profit Events

Administrative Volunteers provide help in our Cranford office by assisting with typing, addressing cards, organizing newsletters, creating packets, collating manuals and other varied clerical duties Craft Volunteers consist of individuals or groups who touch patients in a special way by making lap blankets, shawls, memory bears and other articles for patients to enjoy. Bereavement Volunteers offer support to the families of patients who have passed. During the grieving process the bereavement volunteer can be a valuable resource, especially for those who lack a solid support network. They often make phone calls to check up on family members and also send cards of comfort and care. Ascend Hospice serves counties throughout New Jersey. Areas where you are needed include: Atlantic County, Bergen County, Cape May County, Essex County, Hudson County, Mercer County, Middlesex County, Monmouth County, Morris County, North Passaic County, Ocean County, Somerset County, South Passaic County, Burlington County, Camden County and Union County. For more information about our free volunteer training and available opportunities, call our Volunteer Department or visit our website at Ascendhospice.com! We look forward to hearing from you! do NOT contact me with unsolicited services or offers
07601.title: Hospice Volunteer

07601.description: BVMI utilizes 110 clinical and lay volunteers to help provide care for patients and carry out administrative and fundraising tasks to keep BVMI running smoothly. We are seeking a volunteer coordinator who can help us manage these volunteers, including: Determine, with staff, agency needs which can be met by volunteers Recruit volunteers Respond to inquiries from prospective volunteers Interview prospective volunteers Oversee credentialing process for clinical volunteers Train and onboard new volunteers Schedule volunteers Assign tasks/projects to volunteers The coordinator will work with the administrative director.

07601.description: BVMI is seeking individuals to conduct financial screening of new and existing patients to determine qualification according to established eligibility criteria. Screeners collect required financial records and other documents, and utilize a custom spreadsheet as well as BVMI's medical record software during the interview process. Interviews are done by appointment. There is a need for interviewers who speak English, Spanish and/or Korean.
07601.title: Eligibility Evaluator

07601.description: BVMI is looking for special volunteers to help interpret for patients and practitioners. Spanish speakers are in high demand, especially those with a medical background. Other languages, including Korean, are also needed.
07601.title: Interpreter

07601.description: BVMI is looking for volunteers to assist with administrative tasks that keep the healthcare center running! If you are good with the computer, like to make phone calls, love helping with special events or just like to stuff envelopes, we can put you to work. We have a special need for individuals who are bilingual Spanish.

07601.description: BVMI is looking for volunteer doctors, nurses, nurse practitioners, physician assistants, dietitians, social workers and other healthcare professionals to treat patients. BVMI provides primary care, so PCPs and internists are always welcome, but specialists are also needed to either practice at BVMI or provide free service in their own practice. Volunteers who provide care to patients at BVMI receive free malpractice insurance. Must have valid license to practice in NJ.
07601.title: Clinical Volunteer

07601.description: CASA Volunteers are appointed by family court judges to advocate for the best interest of an abused or neglected child during their time in the child welfare system. They are in essence, the voice of the child, in court. CASA Volunteers interview parents, doctors, educators, foster parents, therapists, and anyone else involved in the life of the child they are assigned. Their goal is to provide child-focused reports to the court, which will lead to a speedy, safe, and permanent placement for the child. This is why it is imperative for these volunteers to go through extensive training. All Volunteers are screened closely for objectivity, competence, and commitment. You can become a CASA volunteer if: You have never been convicted of a crime and can pass a criminal background check. You are not personally involved with DCP&P (the state child welfare agency). Your job (and your life) is flexible. You are at least 21 years old. You are willing to make a one-year commitment. You pass CASA’s screening process. Typically, a CASA volunteer will spend an average 10-20 hours per month working with their assigned case. Each case is different, so the amount of time required to get the job done varies significantly. We do require the volunteer to visit the child once every two weeks and be in court once every three months. CASA for Children of Bergen County asks that you make a one-year commitment. We prefer that a volunteer continue with their assigned case until it is permanently resolved which typically involves an 18 months - two year commitment. One of the primary benefits of the CASA program is that, unlike many caseworkers, most CASA volunteers remain a consistent figure during the course of case proceedings. This provides important continuity for children. Potential CASA volunteers must attend an Information Session, be interviewed and be accepted into training. CASA provides extensive training for our volunteers so that they are prepared to provide children with the support they desperately need. CASA volunteers undergo a thorough 36-hour training course. They learn about courtroom procedure, effective advocacy techniques for children, and specific topics ranging from child abuse to early childhood development and adolescent behavior. In addtion, trainees must attend 3 hours of court observation before being sworn-in by the presiding Family Court judge. Volunteers are required to attend 12 hours of continued training for each year of service. Our training course is offered several times a year and will prepare you for your volunteer experience. Information Sessions: January 18th at 10am or 5:30pm Next Training: Winter Daytime Training: 9:30am-2pm January 30, 2017 (Monday) February 1, 2017 (Wednesday) February 6, 2017 (Monday) February 8, 2017 (Wednesday) February 13, 2017 (Monday) February 15, 2017 (Wednesday) February 22, 2017 (Wednesday) There are information session EVERY third Wednesday of the month! Please fill out our Registration form to come to our next informtaion seesion! https://form.jotform.com/BergenCASA/info-session-sign-up
07601.title: Become a Child Advocate!
07601.org: CASA for Children of Bergen County

07601.description: HELP SMALL BUSINESS GROW IN YOUR LOCAL COMMUNITY; BECOME A MEMBER of SCORE. DO YOU HAVE BUSINESS EXPERTISE IN ADMINISTRATION? SCORE, a resource partner with the Small Business Administration (SBA), offers confidential, free, real world mentoring to local entrepreneurs as they navigate the process to success. Join like-minded individuals who are committed to the development of our community. With your help we can see the dreams of others become reality - our greatest reward. Primarily work from home with occasional meetings at our chapter offices. Manage assignment of new clients requesting support with mentors Manage requests from those interested in volunteering with the chapter Work to improve client engagement processes to make them easy for both clients and counselors Assist Chapter Administrative Chairman with operational tasks and programs

All volunteers/interns are supervised under my senior postdoctoral fellows (PhDs). This program is not paid position, so no salary or compensation of any kind involved. Must publish papers as coauthors with us If wish to stay with the lab and funding is available, we will consider hiring (you must show high productivity via publication records) Will get some junior student supervision experience Most of my trainees get trained while they prepare for industry jobs, PhD program, medical school or MD residency. I do need to evaluate CV for qualification and interview them.

11224.description: Visit a homebound senior in your area! Not only will you make a difference in their lives but you will learn so much form them! Feelings of loneliness and isolation can lead to serious consequences for senior health. Understanding the causes and risk factors for senior isolation can help us prevent it. Nobody relishes the prospect of aging without a spouse or family member at their side, without friends to help them laugh at the ridiculous parts and support them through the difficult times. Yet that is just what many seniors face. Many of our aging loved ones are feeling alone but you can change that by committing yourself to visit them for one hour a week! Learn more by visiting us at www.friendlyvisitingny.org and register online or call us at 718-449-5000 ext. 2212.

11224.description: Volunteer with Habitat for Humanity in Brooklyn! Over three years ago, Superstorm Sandy flooded parts of coastal Brooklyn. Habitat for Humanity NYC's Critical Home Repair program has been helping families rebuild, but many Brooklyn homes are still in dire need of repair before their owners can return home. Our volunteers are at the heart of everything we do and we need YOU to help us continue making an impact throughout NYC! As a volunteer you will have the opportunity to: Make your own schedule - volunteer as little or as much as you would like Receive on-site training in construction - learn new skills or enhance the ones you already have Meet other volunteers committed to affordable housing Give back to your community in an amazing way Make a positive difference in the lives of others No construction experience is necessary -- just enthusiasm! _______________________________________________________________ How to Sign Up: Learn more before signing up by visiting our website (habitatnyc.org) OR create a profile on volunteerhub and sign up for a volunteer orientation (see instructions below). Please note: orientations are optional and are not required for Construction volunteers. If you are ready to start making a difference, follow the steps below to create your volunteerhub account: 1. Log on to habitatnyc.volunteerhub.com 2. Click the \"Register\" button to create a new profile Choose a username and password Leave the Join Code field blank and click \"Next\" Input your full name, contact information, date of birth, and emergency contact's information 3. Select \"Construction\" and click on the event that interests you 4. Click on the \"Sign Up\" button and follow the directions to register for the event 5. You will receive a confirmation email letting you know you successfully signed up for a volunteer day! Please email volunteer@habitatnyc.org with any questions We hope to see you soon!

11224.description: If you live in Brooklyn or travel to Brooklyn on a weekly basis and can commit to one hour a week for at least 6 months, this is the program to be part of! You won’t regret it! Almost every one of our seniors don't interact with anyone - ever - except the person who we match to visit them. Our Friendly Visiting program provides much-needed companionship for these homebound elderly in Brooklyn... but we need you! Visit us at www.friendlyvisitingny.org and find out more or simply enter your info on our site to be contacted. We will meet with you and match you with the senior that is right for you!

Compassionate, detail-oriented volunteers, using their every-day life skills, are needed to visit seniors and help with the timely payment of monthly bills.
