10035.title: Chef Assistant Soup Kitchen

10035.description: Without the dedication and tireless enthusiasm of our volunteers, BHCCC could not provide services to the community. Volunteers are an integral part of our organization, and their contributions are invaluable and much appreciated. BHCCC offers a variety of volunteer opportunities for individuals, groups, companies, religious organizations, etc. On-Site Opportunities Unload & shelve food from the delivery trucks Pre-pack produce bags for pantry distribution Distribute grocery packages during our food pantry Serve lunch during our Soup Kitchen. Help with tasks such as mailings, data entry, filing and other clerical tasks.
10035.title: Help Us Help Those In Need

10035.description: Protect our environment and the special place in which we live! Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL) wants you! As a volunteer, you’ll be a member of the fastest growing and most effective climate advocacy group. You will work with concerned New York citizens to slow the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our beautiful ecosystems, livelihoods and way of life. Please respond to our posting for an invitation to learn more. You will: Meet with Congressional leaders. Write letters to the editors and op-eds. Meet with local media. Educate your community about global warming and legislative solutions. We provide: Monthly national conference calls with expert guest speakers. Weekly skill building sessions. On-line network with CCL volunteers across the U.S. National conference and lobby week in D.C. Volunteers commit to an average of 4-6 hours a month. Some of our volunteers dedicate more time than that. We hold no upper limit on your dedication to a stable climate and livable world. To learn more about us, please join an Introductory Conference Call. The next call is Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Pacific/6:00 p.m. Mountain/7:00 p.m. Central/8:00 p.m. Eastern. This is an opportunity to learn about CCL. It is one hour, and there will be opportunities to ask questions. The conference call number is 1-866-642-1665, passcode 440699#.
10035.title: Sustainable Climate Environment Advocate New York City NY

10034.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. Through our innovative programs, accomplished authors lead workshops in high-needs classrooms, where they guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. No experience or training is necessary to work with pre-K-12 students. As a writing, research or art coach, you'll engage and encourage their progress on a project. This workshop needs your support at an elementary school in Inwood: Program 985GC-M Friday, February 17th, 2017 2 consecutive classes: 9:00 - 10:00 AM & 10:15 - 11:15 AM (Please choose one or both) Writing Coach Fifth-graders in two back-to-back classes read What’s Up in the Amazon Rainforest by Ginjer Clarke to learn about the region’s indigenous animals. With a focus on endangered species, they'll describe an animal, report how it has adapted to its environment, and tell a story about it. Writing coaches will help small groups of students stay focused, provide support and encouragement, and answer their questions about spelling and grammar. For details about other Behind the Book programs around the city, visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new volunteer opportunities, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10034.title: Inspire Inwood public school students to love reading

11218.description: The Foundation for Letters promotes improved college access through engagement with writing by providing urban schools with a range of literary-focused academic and enrichment programs. We also provide schools with assistance in the development of their own external support organizations, which build networks of donors, volunteers and partners that support literacy-focused education at their schools. The Foundation is the official charity for the Brooklyn 5K/10k/15k in Prospect Park. We will be helping to administer the race, as well as raising funds to support our writing programs and partner schools. We are also getting kids into the action! Not only will students be running the race, but as a new journalism program at FFL, we will have students covering the action as journalists, photographers, bloggers, interviewers, and live social media correspondents. We are inviting folks to help us as race day volunteers to help out on the course, as volunteers with the kids, or to run or walk one of the distances (you can either run 5k, 10k, 15k or with a kid in the 2k kids race). The race will work just like a typical \"fun run\" for charity, but in the context of a large race. FFL's partners in organizing the Brooklyn 15k (Pacific Sports and Active Network), have given us a guaranteed number of entries into the race at all of the distances (so we're protected against a sell-out). To volunteer or to run to support the Foundation for Letters, reply to this opportunity! For more information, please contact Mike Jackson - mike.jackson@foundationforletters.org www.foundationforletters.org
11218.title: Volunteer on 4/16 @ Bklyn 5k: Have fun as a race volunteer & help students learn to be journalists!

11218.description: Russian-speaking Holocaust survivors need friendly visitors to come to their homes to share memories, go for a walk, play chess, the sky's the limit.
11218.title: Speak Russian - visit a  Holocaust Survivor

11218.description: Visit Holocaust survivor in his/her home and brush up on your Yiddish skills! Our visitors form very meaningful relationships with their seniors. Our clients love their visitors. The clients are throughly screened - they live all over Brooklyn, NY
11218.title: Speak Yiddish? visit a senior

11218.description: GallopNYC uses therapeutic horsemanship to help riders walk, talk, connect, focus, behave and learn, inspiring each one to live life as fully, productively and independently as possible. Volunteers are needed to assist our riders on horse back. Volunteers lead horses or walk alongside them during lessons. Classes are conducted by a trained instructor. We have a great team of volunteers and we really love what we do. One of our riders said \"When I ride my horse I feel free.\" We love making that free feeling possible -- plus we see very concrete achievements in our riders' abilities. Our riders have a wide range of disabilities, but all of them enjoy riding and are a joy to to work with. The horses are nice too! We conduct lessons seven days a week at four different locations and could use your help! Email us today and we will provide you with the dates of upcoming orientation sessions for new volunteers.. Experience with horses is helpful but not at all necessary. Please contact us for more info on how to become a volunteer at: volunteer@gallopnyc.org Or visit our website at: http://gallopnyc.org/how-to-help/volunteer/
11218.title: Volunteer With a Therapeutic Horsemanship Program in Brooklyn

11218.description: Volunteers needed to visit holocaust survivors in their homes once a week to sit and chat, play cards, bake cookies, share stories, listen to music, take a walk, whatever you two decide. An ability to speak Russian or Yiddish is a bonus. This is a great opportunity to make a difference in someone's life - our clients love their visitors.
11218.title: Friendly Visitor

11219.description: MJHS Hospice provides a specialized program of care and services for end-of-life patients. MJHS Hospice provides care for pediatric and adult patients in homes, nursing homes, assisted living communities, inpatient facilities and hospitals. MJHS Hospice Volunteer opportunities include: Providing support and companionship to patients and their families Participating in leisure activities such as reading, listening to music, playing games with patients Supporting or organizing group activities for patients Listening compassionately to patients and their families Providing office or clerical support for our hospice team Complementary therapies Requirements for all categories of volunteers: 18 years or older 15 hours of training (4 hours training for clerical/office volunteers) Background Check (no charge to applicant) Medical Clearance (no charge to applicant) 3-4 hours per week 1 year commitment Required skills for patient visits: discretion, patience, compassion and dedication Preferred clerical and office support skills include: receptionist skills, computer skills, organizational skills and filing For more information on how to become a MJHS Hospice Volunteer please call: Brooklyn: Denise Jones, Coordinator of Volunteer Services; 347-633-3421 or dejones@mjhs.org
11219.title: Be Part of Someone's Legacy--Become a Hospice Volunteer in Brooklyn!

11219.description: We need musicians, Singers, Vocalist and Instrumentalist of all kinds and Languages to come help lift up the spirit of the helpless members of our community.
11219.title: Help Uplift The Helpless Through Music

11219.description: Sometimes a friendly face is all it takes to make someone's day, and Mishkon's Companion Program brings new friendly faces to the individuals in our program! The Companion Program matches individuals in Brooklyn with a companion; volunteers who will make a short visit, just to say hi. As a companion you can play a game, listen to some music simply have a short conversation with your new Mishkon friend. For individuals who have a developmental disability, your friendship can decrease a sense of isolation and provide a welcome change from day-to-day activities. We will match you with one of our program's individuals based on your mutual interests and availability. Time commitment and hours are flexible.
11219.title: Companion Program- Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: The Kaplan Center for Community Services helps people who are struggling with a range of emotional and social problems. The Kaplan Center also provides psychiatric and social services to Jewish emigres from the former Soviet Union and elsewhere, and counseling services for senior citizens and their families. As a Client Companion for the Kaplan Center, you will assist one of the clients using their mental health services. This client lives independently in Boro Park, is in his mid to late 50s, and is looking for someone to accompany him to the grocery store as well as expose him to exercise, which can be as simple as going for a walk around the neighborhood. This opportunity is available Monday Friday in Boro Park. Volunteer is needed 1x/week in the afternoon for at least 6 months.
11219.title: Client Companion- Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: The Mishkon Division services the needs of people with developmental disabilities via their residences, Medicaid Waiver program, respite program, and summer sleepaway camp. As a Weekly Host, you will lead a Shabbat party in a group home or apartment of our Mishkon clients choosing. Games, snacks, and activities will be included. To register for our volunteer website, please visit www.jewishboard.org/volunteer.
11219.title: Weekly Shabbat Party Host- Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: The Mishkon Division services the needs of people with developmental disabilities via their residences, Medicaid Waiver program, respite program, and summer sleepaway camp. As a Team Activity Leader at Mishkon you will be responsible for leading activities with developmentally disabled male and/or female adolescents and adults in their residences. Activities may include, but are not limited to, Arts & Crafts, Cooking/baking, Going out into the community, Musical activities, Exercise/Dance activities, and Reading/Games. As a Team Activity Leader you can also bring your own ideas and skills to the table. You must be caring and responsible, and willing to learn about the developmentally disabled population.
11219.title: Team Activity Leader- Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: The Mishkon Division services the needs of people with developmental disabilities via their residences, Medicaid Waiver program, respite program, and summer sleepaway camp. As a Personal Shopper for our Mishkon residents you will work together with staff and residence managers to collect clothing sizes of special needs men and women. The volunteer will shop with or without the individual, in program-approved locations and stay within a pre-established budget. The volunteer will be responsible for returning or exchanging items that don't fit. Volunteer must be willing to learn about the developmentally disabled population, have good communication skills, and work well with others.
11219.title: Personal Shopper- Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: The Mishkon Division services the needs of people with developmental disabilities via their residences, Medicaid Waiver program, respite program, and summer sleepaway camp. As a Fundraiser you will take initiative to fundraise, collect donations, or run a toy drive to collect approved items for children and adults with special needs. Creativity and \"out of the box thinking\" is welcome. Volunteer will hand out donated items to individuals. Volunteer must be open to learning about the developmentally disabled population, be able to take initiative, have excellent interpersonal and communication skills, and work well with others. Hours will vary.
11219.title: Fundraiser- Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

10031.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10031.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 192 Jacob H. Schiff, Manhattan)

10031.description: The Boys & Girls Club of Harlem seeks adult volunteers to support its academic support and enrichment programming for high school students at its Frederick Douglass Academy Clubhouse. Volunteer activities include: Providing support in the review and completion of homework assignments and class projects One-on-one and/or in small groups tutor on subjects which include high school mathematics (algebra, geometry, etc.); life science and English Language Arts Participate in interactive BGCHarlem-facilitated activities that support student competencies in time management, study skills and goal-setting Volunteers must: Over age 18 with a high school diploma; some college or college degree preferred. Ability to commit a minimum of 2 hours 1 day per week. Willingness to share knowledge, skills and experience in helping students understand complex concepts A passion for working with youth in achieving their academic and social potential. Schedule of Tutoring Rotation Between: 2:30pm to 5pm Monday - Math (Algebra) Tuesday - Science (Basic Biology) Wednesday - Social Studies (More Writing Based Help) Thursday - English Literacy (More Writing Based Help)
10031.title: High School Tutors Needed

10031.description: Seeking committed people interested in serving as volunteer tutors and mentors for our After School Enrichment Program which serves youth between the ages of 6 and 13 (3:00-7:00pm). Activites Include: Homework Help Mentoring Sports Health & Wellness Arts and Crafts Computer Science Social Recreation Schedule is very flexible.
10031.title: After School Volunteers

10031.description: City Tutors (CT), the tutoring arm of the Colin Powell School, is currently looking for two tutors to provide academic support for students in Intermediate Micro and Macroeconomics courses. Tutors for the Intermediate Economics courses will serve in the role of study group leaders. In this role, you would take the lead to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by CT coordinators. All majors are welcome to apply. This is a great opportunity especially for Economics/Business Management/Finance majors or minors. You should consider applying if you are interested in building professional contacts with faculty and staff at the Colin Powell School who can later speak to your professional capability at the cross section of your academic interests, would like to help your peers and make an impact on students' classroom learning experience, and if you are interested in exploring your academic interest area at the cross section of education. If you are applying for the study group leader position supporting the Intermediate Economics courses, you need to have taken the same intermediate economics course you wish to tutor, received A- or A in that economics course, have an overall GPA at 3.2 or higher All City Tutors are expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Spring semester. If you are unable to attend the regular training sessions, you will need to attend makeup sessions. The dates for these sessions will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinator’s. Learn more about the City Tutors here: thecitytutors.com The City Tutors (CT) was founded at The City College of New York with the premise that a volunteer tutoring program working collaboratively with educational partners can help improve retention and graduation rates.
10031.title: Seeking Volunteer Tutors to Support Courses in Intermediate Micro and/or Macro Economics

10031.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for a tutor to run study groups that provide academic support for CCNY Biology 102 class students this Spring Semester. Biology 102 is an introductory course for science students. Classes meet twice a week on Mondays and Wednesdays from 3:30pm to 4:45pm. This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience, and for those who are interested in tutoring in their subject area of interest. In this role, you will be in communication with an instructor to improve students’ performance. Throughout this process, you will be supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. A tutor supporting this Biology 102 class is expected to commit a minimum of three hours and thirty minutes every week. You will need to attend both the Monday and Wednesday classes, as well as provide a minimum of one hour study group support. Study group times will be determined from a survey done in class asking when students will be available for sessions. Times that fit with the majority of students and the tutor will be selected for study groups. You would identify and support students who are struggling, and provide feedback to the instructor regarding students' concerns and difficulties that can lead to changes in future lessons. You will also meet with the CCNY Biology Department staff. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are expected to complete 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Spring semester. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor support class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about CCNY Biology Department here: https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/biology To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program receiving higher than a 3.0 Make monthly meetings, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.
10031.title: Biology Tutor needed for Bio 102 course held through the CCNY Biology Department

10031.title: Biology Tutor needed for Bio 101 course held through the CCNY Biology Department

10031.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for tutors to run Group Study sessions that provide academic support in math for the Continuing Professional Studies at CCNY in two sections this Spring. Both meet twice weekly, Mondays and Wednesdays, or another that meets Tuesdays and Thursdays. The Group Study sessions run from 12:30 - 1:30 PM for day classes. This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience and who are interested in tutoring. In this role, you would collaborate with an instructor to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. The tutor for Continuing Professional Studies is expected to commit a minimum of an hour and a half to support one of the above-mentioned days. You would identify and support students who are struggling, and provide feedback to students so that they may improve their fundamental understanding of the material. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Spring semester. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor in the class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about Continuing Professional Studies here: https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/cps To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program Submit monthly reports, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.
10031.title: Math Tutor needed for Afternoon CCNY Continuing Professional Studies Spring 2017

10031.description: Description: The City Tutors-The City College of New York, are looking for a self-motivated, detailed oriented and creative graphic designer to assist with visuals for The City Tutors. Responsibilities Assist and create visuals for manuals, websites, and social media accounts Pitch ideas for visuals Required Skills Proficiency in Photoshop, Adobe InDesign, and Illustrator Knowledge of FinalCut Pro Strong typographic knowledge and a good sense of layout design Recommended Strong typographic knowledge and a good sense of layout design Front-end web design experience is also a plus The City Tutors are a volunteer organization that has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Our opportunities allow our volunteers to develop professional development skills for the purpose of gaining future employment.
10031.title: Graphic Designer Intern

10031.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for two embedded tutors to provide academic support for College Now English class students in two sections this Spring, one that meets once a week (Saturdays, 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM) and another that meets twice weekly (Mondays and Fridays, 3:30 PM - 4:45 PM). This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience and who are interested in tutoring. In this role, you would collaborate with an instructor to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. All embedded tutors for the College Now classes are expected to commit a minimum of three hours Saturdays per class session or an hour and half Mondays and Fridays per class session. You would identify and support students who are struggling, participate during the lecture to augment the class topic discussions, and provide feedback to the instructor regarding students' concerns and difficulties that can lead to changes in future lessons. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All embedded tutors are also expected to complete a three session comprehensive professional training regimen. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators. CT's embedded tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor in the class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about College Now here: https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/collegenow To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program Submit monthly reports, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.
10031.title: Saturday and Weekday English Classroom Tutors for College Now for Spring 2017

10031.description: Volunteer opportunity description | Exit preview The Actors Theatre Workshop is an award-winning non-profit theatre, community center and educational institution that teaches innovative educational techniques and theatre principles to adults and children from all walks of life; produces classical and contemporary plays and documentary films that maintain the highest artistic standards; and develops new dramatic works that examine the social issues of the day. Thurman E. Scott, ATW’s artistic director and award winning theatre artist, will be leading a 3 day event, on September 19,20 and 21, at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church. This workshop will focus on addressing diversity in our community and church family. This workshop aims to open the discussion on diversity. Participants will learn powerful techniques to forgive and accept people who are different and how to use curiosity to accept difference to build a community based on WE ARE ONE. We are looking for experienced event planners and marketers to help promote our important We Are One event. Because of ATW’s success with programs such as this, Convent Avenue Baptist Church has asked Mr. Scott to create a program that addresses the expanding and increasingly diverse population in Harlem, and the issues and conflicts that sometimes arise when individuals of different races and cultures interact. Mr. Scott’s weekend program will address these issues, the larger issues of classism, sexism and ant-Semitism, and provide techniques we can use every day to get past the barriers that divide us. At this time in our city, country and around the world, it is crucial that we learn to break down these barriers, and it is our hope and belief that this program will have an important impact on this process. Apply now! If interested, send us an email with your resume: outreach@actorstheatreworkshop.com For more information, about the event go to (event page on ATW) For more information about ATW, go to http://www.actorstheatreworkshop.com. Contact us at outreach@actorstheatreworkshop.com or call the theatre at 212-947-1386.
10031.title: Event/Marketing Volunteers needed for Non Profit Theatre for big 3 day Event on Diversity

The program coordinator will contact you to provide more details, make arrangements, and discuss their needs and yours. 1. Thursday, February 16th from 9:30 - 10:45 am with author Caron Levis and her book Stuck with the Blooz (kindergarteners in Crown Heights, Brooklyn) 2. Monday, February 27th from 9:40 - 11:15 am with author Zetta Elliott and her book Bird (art workshop with 5th-gradersin Fort Greene, Brooklyn) 3. 10030.description: Behind the Book works directly in New York City public schools, providing rich, innovative literacy programs to urban classrooms. Working with students from pre-K to 12th grade, Behind the Book identifies books that speak to students, then partners with teachers to create immersive curriculum units that bring the authors into classrooms. Through a series of workshops, authors discuss their book and teach a genre of writing, encouraging students to see themselves as readers and writers. Behind the Book seeks a Program Intern to assist with the design, implementation, and administration of our school programs. The intern will work closely with the Director of Programming and the Program Coordinators to support all aspects of our programs. The position is based in our Harlem office. The commitment is for one semester, minimum two days per week, hours are flexible. Responsibilities include: Working with students in classrooms Managing the Behind the Book library; conducting research and managing review copies Assisting with student book publication as needed Supporting staff with program logistics and administration Assisting in creating lesson plans, activities and worksheets for our school programs QUALIFICATIONS: Detail-oriented, eager to learn, and able to manage tasks independently. Excellent written and oral communication skills in English are required, as are strong skills in Microsoft Office. A background in education theory or previous teaching experience a plus. TO APPLY: Please submit a resume, cover letter, and a one-page writing sample to Jo Umans at info@BehindtheBook.org. \"Program Intern\" should appear in the subject heading of your email. Deadlines to apply for next two semesters: Spring 2017: February 13th Summer 2017: May 31st Behind the Book is committed to providing equal opportunity to all employees and applicants without regard to race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, marital status, sexual orientation, disability, political affiliation, family responsibilities, or any other characteristic protected under federal, state, or local law. We are committed to maximizing the diversity of our organization, as we want to engage all those who can contribute to this effort.

10030.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10030.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 175 Henry Granet, Manhattan)

10030.description: Behind the Book is a non-profit children's literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. We bring accomplished authors into pre-K-12 classrooms in high-needs communities, where they lead workshops that guide students in creating their own writing and art projects. Our rich, innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula and meet Common Core Learning Standards, have a proven record of building literacy skills and creating engaged, motivated readers at schools in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Inwood, Harlem, and the Bronx. BtB is looking for volunteer photographers to document students and authors during classroom workshops and field trips. This is a challenging task involving several children and a lot of activity, so it's a plus if you have experience with pre-kindergarteners to high school-age students. Photographers may also cover events for fundraising and promotion of our mission, and/or shoot portraits of staff, board members, and volunteers for social media, publications, and promotional campaigns. They might also appear in the books written and illustrated by our students as their classroom projects. All images will be credited. To apply or for more information, please contact volunteer@behindthebook.org. Include a link to your website, portfolio or samples of your work.
10030.title: Photographer

10030.description: Join the volunteer team at Behind the Book, a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. We bring accomplished authors and illustrators into pre-K-12th grade classrooms in high-needs schools, where they guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. Our rich, innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula and meet Common Core Learning Standards, have a successful record of building literacy skills and creating motivated readers at schools around the city. You need no experience or training to volunteer as a writing, research or art coach, or in another active role to engage and encourage students as they work on their projects. You might help a student edit a short story or essay, guide small groups in researching animals or civil rights issues, or oversee kids creating collages, drawings, or murals. Individual workshops run about 90 minutes on a school day, usually in the morning. You can participate in any number of workshops in a program series of 3 to 6 dates, scheduled over a few weeks. With a slate of wonderful authors leading creative, thought-provoking programs every school year, you'll find many workshops you'll want to be part of. For dates of upcoming workshops, including the anchor books, authors, and descriptions of the class project, please visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new volunteer opportunities, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/ For more information, contact volunteer@behindthebook.org.
10030.title: Classroom Volunteer/Writing Coach

10033.description: Our program depends on a lot of volunteer labor for many jobs and tasks. Our population is diverse and many of the parents of our students speak only Spanish. We need a point person to co-ordinate all of the volunteers, motivate them and train them and make sure all jobs are covered each week. This person should be outgoing and friendly, very organized, and needs to be bilingual Spanish/English. A major part of our mission is community building, and this is a crucial role for accomplishing that. We want all parents and other volunteers to feel like a part of the team and important to our organization's work in the community.
10033.title: Volunteer Coordinator

10032.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. Through our innovative programs, accomplished authors lead workshops in high-needs classrooms, where they guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. No experience or training is necessary to work with pre-K-12 students. As a writing, research or art coach, you'll engage and encourage their progress on a project. This workshop needs your support at an elementary school in Washington Heights: Program 42VSK-S Tuesday, February 28th, 2017 9:00 - 10:15 AM Writing Coach Second graders read A Suprise for Teresita, a bilingual story of a New York City girl who discovers her Puerto Rican community while waiting for a surprise from her uncle. Author Dr. Virginia Sanchez-Korrol leads workshops that engage students in an exploration of the book’s main ideas, and their experiences and thoughts about their own communities. Guided by Teresita’s story, students will take a neighborhood walk, and with help from coaches, write letters depicting their discoveries. For details about other Behind the Book programs around the city, visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new volunteer opportunities, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10032.title: Inspire Washington Heights, NY public school students to love reading

10032.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for tutors to provide academic support in reading and writing for the Sugar Hill Project’s Homework Club this Spring. Sessions meet three times each week on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays. The sessions run from 3:00 - 5:30 PM. This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience and who are interested in tutoring. In this role, you would take the lead to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by City Tutor’s coordinators. The tutor for Sugar Hill Project’s Homework club is expected to commit a minimum of an hour and a half to support one of the above-mentioned days. You would identify and support students who are struggling, and provide feedback to students so that they may improve their fundamental understanding of the material. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Spring semester. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having tutors in these sessions early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about Sugar Hill Project here: http://www.bhc.org/sugarhill/ To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program Submit monthly reports, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.

Learn more about Sugar Hill Project here: http://www.bhc.org/sugarhill/ To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program Submit monthly reports, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.
10032.title: Math Tutor needed for Sugar Hill Broadway Housing Communities

10032.description: The City Tutors (CT) provides in-class academic support for a 9th grade algebra class (a total of little more than 30 students) at Community Health Academy High School (located a block away from the 157th stop on the 1 train). The teacher has really enjoyed working with City Tutors, and we would like to continue to support her course in Spring 2016. The tutor would attend the class on Weds from 1:56-2:48PM. This is a great opportunity for individuals who have a strong foundation in the material, and are interested in gaining practical experience working in the classroom. As an embedded tutor, you will collaborate with an instructor to improve students’ performance, while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. All embedded tutors commit three hours for the week. You will sit in on the class, and sometimes provide tutoring support after class (or on a different day if that's more agreeable) depending on students’ availability and interest. You will speak with the instructor weekly to prep for the next class and debrief after the Wed session. You would identify and support students who are struggling and provide feedback to the instructor regarding students' concerns and difficulties that can lead to changes in future lessons. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. CT's embedded tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model at the site. To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor. Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have received a degree recently. Be willing to complete 11.5 hours of College Reading and Learning Aligned (CRLA) training at City College of New York. We can accommodate your schedule for the training sessions.
10032.title: In-Class Tutoring Support for a 9th Grade Algebra Class

10032.description: Would your child like to contribute to science and help other kids? If so, please consider enrolling your child in a study to help create a new language test! Participation involves interesting paper and pencil tasks and requires 1-3 visits, as some children will be randomly requested to participate in one month or one year follow-up visits. The first visit and one year visit lasts approximately 1 hour and your child will be paid $20 for each of these visits. The one month visit lasts approximately 10 minutes and your child will be paid $10 for this visit. P arents will be paid $20 each visit for your time. Location: Either Columbia University Medical Center (transportation costs reimbursed up to $100) or your home at your convenience Requirements: Your child must be a healthy, 6-15 year old native English speaker Please contact Alicia at (212) 305-1801 or aw2165@cumc.columbia.edu to learn more about the study
10032.title: Paid Research Study - Children Ages 6-15 ($$ for Parent & Child)
10032.org: Columbia University Medical Center/National Center for Children in Poverty

10032.description: Are you age 61 or older? Would you like to help scientists learn about language? Please consider participating in our research study! Study involves approximately 2 hours of interesting pencil and paper language tasks and you will receive $40 for your participation. Location: Either Columbia University Medical Center (transportation costs reimbursed) or your home at your convenience! Requirements: Must be in good health (e.g. no neurological or psychiatric disorders) and must be age 61 or older. Please call Alicia at (212) 305-1801 or email at aw2165@columbia.edu to learn more about the study
10032.title: Paid Research Study - Adults Ages 61 and Older
10032.org: Columbia University Medical Center/National Center for Children in Poverty

10032.description: Sunrise on Wheels brings the fun of day camp to children in hospitals. We play games and toys with children, have arts and crafts projects and we seek to help the children get through a very difficfult day with a little fun and laughter.

07738.description: Protect our environment and the special place in which we live! Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL) wants you! As a volunteer, you’ll be a member of the fastest growing and most effective climate advocacy group. You will work with concerned New Jersey citizens to slow the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our beautiful ecosystems, livelihoods and way of life. Please respond to our posting for an invitation to learn more. You will: Meet with Congressional leaders. Write letters to the editors and op-eds. Meet with local media. Educate your community about global warming and legislative solutions. We provide: Monthly national conference calls with expert guest speakers. Weekly skill building sessions. On-line network with CCL volunteers across the U.S. National conference and lobby week in D.C. Volunteers commit to an average of 4-6 hours a month. Some of our volunteers dedicate more time than that. We hold no upper limit on your dedication to a stable climate and livable world. To learn more about us, please join an Introductory Conference Call. The next call is Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Pacific/6:00 p.m. Mountain/7:00 p.m. Central/8:00 p.m. Eastern. This is an opportunity to learn about CCL. It is one hour, and there will be opportunities to ask questions. The conference call number is 1-866-642-1665, passcode 440699#.
07738.title: Sustainable Climate Environment Advocate Central NJ

07738.description: Experienced business professionals (currently employed or retired) from either a corporate or small business management background who wish to help those who are considering a business opportunity or are in business and need advice. We are also looking for individuals who have technical skills and prefer to volunteer in a support function.
07738.title: Mentors and Service Support Volunteers

08820.description: If you have an hour or more per week to give, Ascend Hospice welcomes your gifts of time and compassion. Whether you choose to work directly with patients and families or to volunteer in one of many other ways, you can make a profound difference in someone's life, including your own. Volunteers are an integral part of the hospice team. Volunteer Opportunities: Companionship Volunteers work directly with patients providing companionship, offering friendly visits, reading to patients, writing letters, offering a gentle touch or sharing a quiet moment. Complementary Volunteers are certified/trained professionals who can provide complementary modalities of reflexologly, music, Reiki, & massage. Pet Therapy Volunteers provide companionship from our certified therapy dogs. Administrative Volunteers provide help in our Cranford office by assisting with typing, addressing cards, organizing newsletters, creating packets, collating manuals and other varied clerical duties Craft Volunteers consist of individuals or groups who touch patients in a special way by making lap blankets, shawls, memory bears and other articles for patients to enjoy. Bereavement Volunteers offer support to the families of patients who have passed. During the grieving process the bereavement volunteer can be a valuable resource, especially for those who lack a solid support network. They often make phone calls to check up on family members and also send cards of comfort and care. Ascend Hospice serves counties throughout New Jersey. Areas where you are needed include: Atlantic County, Bergen County, Cape May County, Essex County, Hudson County, Mercer County, Middlesex County, Monmouth County, Morris County, North Passaic County, Ocean County, Somerset County, South Passaic County, Burlington County, Camden County and Union County. For more information about our free volunteer training and available opportunities, call our Volunteer Department or visit our website at Ascendhospice.com! We look forward to hearing from you! do NOT contact me with unsolicited services or offers
08820.title: Hospice Volunteer

08820.description: Mentoring needy children while teaching basketball skills and drills that will stick with these kids for the rest of their lives. Setting an example as a role model while teaching kid's lessons about life through sports. Many children never have the opportuniity to play in a team setting because of the lack of finances, health challenges, or fear. This is where you will have an opportunity to help a child soar to their life goals and guide them through the process.
08820.title: Basketball Coaches Needed for Youth

08820.description: Get Fit / Equipped to Rid Diabetes program Offers children from 5 years to 21 years the opportunity to engage in physical fitness exercises to combat diabetes and obesity. What are the health risks for children who are overweight or obese? Doctors and scientists are concerned about the rise of obesity in children and teens because obesity may lead to the following health problems: Heart disease Type 2 diabetes Asthma Sleep apnea Social discrimination Obese children may experience immediate health consequences which can lead to weight-related health problems in adulthood. Obese children and teens have been found to have risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD), including high cholesterol levels, high blood pressure, and abnormal glucose tolerance. In a sample of 5-to 17-year-olds, almost 60% of overweight children had at least one CVD risk factor and 25% of overweight children had two or more CVD risk factors. In addition, studies have shown that obese children and teens are more likely to become obese as adults. Stigma and Self-Esteem. In addition to suffering from poor physical health, overweight and obese children can often be targets of early social discrimination. The psychological stress of social stigmatization can cause low self-esteem which, in turn, can hinder academic and social functioning, and persist into adulthood. While research is still being conducted, there have been some studies showing that obese children are not learning as well as those who are not obese. Further, physical fitness has been shown to be associated with higher achievement.
08820.title: Mentoring Special Needs Children

08824.description: Looking for Energetic, Passionate, Dedicated individuals who are 18 years or Older, to be part of our First Aid Squad. We are looking for members living in and around Kendall Park, Franklin Park, Monmouth Junction, Dayton, Griggstown, Somerset ONLY. Squad will Train you on Basic Life Support Skills like CPR, First Aid and provide you with Uniforms, Radios and Pagers. 07732.description: Over 560 acres of the Navesink River is downgraded due to pollution. We need your help to Rally the Navesink! Join us as we begin to develop volunteer opportunities for education and outreach programs, storm drain detectives and policy/science opportunities. Contact info@cleanoceanaction.org for more information or \"Like\" our Facebook page at Facebook.com/RallyfortheNavesink Rally for the Navesink: An alliance of groups coordinated by Clean Ocean Action, including American Littoral Society, Bayshore Regional Watershed Council, Clean Ocean Action, Fair Haven Sailing Club/River Rats, Hartshorne Woods Association, Monmouth Conservation Foundation, Navesink Maritime Heritage Association, Navesink River Rowing Club, Navesink Shrewsbury River Fishing Club, NY/NJ Baykeeper, Oceanport Water Watch, Pirates Care, Recreational Fishing Alliance - NJ Chapter, Shrewsbury Yacht Club, and Sierra Club-Shore Group
07732.title: Rally for the Navesink & Clean Up River Pollution!

07732.description: With nearly 27,000 members, the U.S. Coast Guard Auxiliary actively provides safety patrols on area waterways and regularly meets with the boating public at marinas and in classrooms. We also directly assist the U.S. Coast Guard in non-law enforcement programs such as search and rescue, and marine environmental protection. Flotilla 22 is based at the tip of Sandy Hook, NJ at the USCG Station. We operate over 12 surface facilities and have more than 50 active members supporting Station Sandy Hook in all aspects of Search & Rescue, Marine Safety, Environmental Protection, and Recreational Boating Safety. As a member of our Flotilla we will provide you with hands-on training in the programs and activities that interest you. You can perform safety examinations of recreational boats, or crew on Search & Rescue patrols, and much more! Contact us today to learn more! http://boatsafenj.org

10550.description: MISSION - Our mission is to introduce the marvels of science to children on a systematic, frequent and regularly scheduled basis, enabling them to experience, explore and personalize the resulting discoveries. Science centers embedded in the community, embraced by the school system and freely available to children, parents and teachers alike have proven to be successful interveners needed in the metropolitan areas around the country. We seek to duplicate and expand the success of those centers in Mount Vernon. VISION - Our vision of success includes directly impacting the lives of the 9,000 students attending public school inMount Vernoneach year with a state-of-the-art facility that is embraced by current and succeeding generations of students, parents, the school system and the surrounding corporate community. Our facility will impact academic studies and outcomes and influence career choices for years to come, further validating the community value and impact of such well-thought-out initiatives for urban areas.
10550.title: The Real Cost of Educational Injustice
10550.org: Northeast STEM Starter Academy at Mt. Vernon

10550.description: Do you have wisdom to share? Are you 60 or better and enjoy offering guidance to younger generations? Members of the Elder Wisdom Circle are seniors who share their wisdom with young advice seekers from across the world. Via the Internet, Elders answer advice requests at their own convenience, offering young readers personalized and free advice on a wide range of topics - love and relationships, family and child-rearing, career and self-improvement, and more. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, the Elder Wisdom Circle has more than 600 Elders (aged 60 to 105) across North America. The EWC program and our Elders have been featured on ABC, BBC, CBS, FOX, NPR and in such publications as Glamour, the LA Times, Ladies Home Journal, Real Simple, Time & USA Today. We are one of the largest providers of personal advice, with hundreds of thousands of readers. We are looking for seniors in your area to help expand our national reach. Please visit our site at www.ElderWisdomCircle.org and then the 'Offer Advice' tab on the top of the homepage. All advice providers must be 60 or better, no exceptions. Volunteers must complete an application and screening process.
10550.title: Mount Vernon>>>Advice Counselor

07940.description: Spending time with youth is a fun and rewarding experience. While mothers are attending a Dress For Success seminar to build the skills needed for a new job or interview, volunteers are needed to watch over the children. Arts & crafts, reading stories, homework help and playing games are just a few of the fun possibilities volunteers can engage in with the children. Ages range from 7 - 17 and the total number of youth can reach up to 15. NOTE: To participate in this project you must be a Jersey Cares volunteer. To sign up as a Jersey Cares volunteer: 1. Visit www.jerseycares.org 2. Click on \"Log-In\" 3. Click on \"Not a Member? Register\" 4. Fill out all necessary information. 5. Register for a project!
07940.title: Kiddy Care in Madison

07424.description: We are looking for sporting enthusiasts (ie. Basketball, Baseball, Tennis, etc.) who are interested in sharing their passion with individuals who are striving to embark on having a more active and healthy lifestyle through our Active Life for a Healthy Mind program. We have regularly scheduled activities for individuals who self-identify with anxiety and/or depression. Volunteers would be expected to help in guiding individuals in these activities, while maintaining a fun and safe atmosphere during the activity. Candidates volunteering in this capacity should be proficient in the basic skills of the sport(s) in which they would volunteer to lead and be interested in teaching them to individuals with little or no experience with them. Active Life for a Healthy Mind activities will be held throughout the northern NJ/Tristate area.
07424.title: ALHM Activity Leaders - Sports

07424.description: We are looking for outdoor enthusiasts who are interested in sharing their passion of the outdoors with individuals who are striving to embark on having a more active and healthy lifestyle through our Active Life for a Healthy Mind program. We have regularly scheduled hikes for individuals who self-identify with anxiety and/or depression. Volunteers would be expected to help in guiding individuals on local hikes of varying difficulty levels and help in maintaining safety during the activity. Candidates volunteering in this capacity should be comfortable with being outdoors and knowledgeable about hiking in general. Active Life for a Healthy Mind activities will be held throughout the northern NJ/Tristate area.
07424.title: ALHM Activity Leaders - Outdoor

11501.description: This is an opportunity to advocate for residents living in nursing homes, adult homes and assisted living facilities in Nassau County. Before placement in a facility a volunteer must complete 6 days of training to satisfy the NYS Certification requirement. Ongoing training is required and provided throughout the volunteer experience. As a NYS Certified Ombudsperson, you would advocate for the residients to ensure that their rights, dignity and quality of care are being met. The volunteer works in collaboration with resident, resident's family, facility administrtion and regulatory agencies. This volunteer opportunity requires a two year commitment to visit their assigned facility for approximately 2 to 4 hours a week, one day a week. Margaret Hromada, Program Director,Family and Children's Association Ombudservice 516-466-9718
11501.title: Advocate for residents in nursing homes, adult homes and assisted living facilities.

07306.description: My name is Michelle and I am a Host Family Coordinator with AnB Education. We are a Non-Profit Organization looking for willing host families in your area. We wanted to reach out with this opportunity to host an international exchange student in your local community. Every year thousands of host families across the United States welcome International Exchange Students, AnB Education is grateful to be working with hundreds of host families across the country. An exchange student not only attends school, but becomes immersed in our world. Host families welcome a new sons, daughters, sisters and brothers from across the world. To us Host Families, you, are an essential part of helping create a better world! Through the personal relationships, language and cultural immersion we can help teach tomorrow’s leaders today. Students provide for all their own financial needs, and host families are supported with a generous monthly reimbursement. Our International students need . . . -A caring and friendly host family who is willing to provide quiet space for studying, access to TV and internet, and access to laundry facilities. - A home where English is the primary language spoken -A private bedroom (not in the basement please) and a shared or private bathroom in a safe and clean environment. -Breakfast and dinner meals with host family during the week. (The student would buy their lunch at school) and 3 meals during the weekend. (Most international students like to share meals with their American hosts every day. They benefit from speaking English in relaxed, natural situations outside of their English courses. ) http://www.anbeducation.com/become-a-host-family.html
07306.title: Host Families Needed for International High School Students

07306.description: \"We have absolutely loved having an exchange student. We have learned so much about another culture and have enjoyed introducing our student to American traditions. It has been a wonderful experience for our whole family!\" - Gayle My name is Michelle and I am a Host Family Coordinator with AnB Education. We are a Non-Profit Organization looking for willing host families in your area. We wanted to reach out with this opportunity to host an international exchange student in your local community. Every year thousands of host families across the United States welcome International Exchange Students, AnB Education is grateful to be working with hundreds of host families across the country. An exchange student not only attends school, but becomes immersed in our world. Host families welcome a new sons, daughters, sisters and brothers from across the world. To us Host Families, you, are an essential part of helping create a better world! Through the personal relationships, language and cultural immersion we can help teach tomorrow’s leaders today. Students provide for all their own financial needs, and host families are supported with a generous monthly reimbursement. Our International students need : -A caring and friendly host family who is willing to provide quiet space for studying, access to TV and internet, and access to laundry facilities. -A private bedroom (not in the basement please) and a shared or private bathroom in a safe and clean environment. -Breakfast and dinner meals with host family during the week. (The student would buy their lunch at school) and 3 meals during the weekend. (Most international students like to share meals with their American hosts every day. They benefit from speaking English in relaxed, natural situations outside of their English courses. ) http://www.anbeducation.com/become-a-host-family.html
07306.title: Spring Host Families Needed- Help Change the Life of an International Student

07306.description: The Retired & Senior Volunteer Program Center (RSVP) Center of Essex and Hudson Counties is a comprehensive community service organization through JFS MetroWest NJ designed to mobilize members of the community who are 55 and older in giving back to their own neighborhoods through volunteer service within Essex and Hudson Counties. Our Hudson County office is located in the United Way of Hudson County at 857 Bergen Ave in Jersey City. For potential volunteers, RSVP Center of Essex and Hudson Counties provides a single location where they can review a number of local volunteer opportunities and receive the help of a trained Volunteer Coordinator. This assistance ensures that volunteers are placed in a position that matches their skills, desired time commitment and interests. RSVP also provides volunteers with supplemental insurance while volunteering, annual volunteer recognition events and connection to a nationwide network of volunteers. We are currently placing volunteers in opportunities where they can assist childen, people with developmental disabilities, domestic violence victims, aging adults, hungry families, etc. Our placements occur throughout local hospitals, non profits, daycares, food pantries, public agencies, and many more. Contact us for a full listing of opportunities.
07306.title: RSVP Center of Essex and Hudson Counties

07306.description: Marketplace in Jersey City is a project dedicated to battling hunger and poverty in our community through an emergency food pantry. This project provides a meaningful volunteer experience in a positive, safe environment that is perfect for individuals, families, and groups of almost any size. Volunteer today and make a measurable difference in the lives of many by, helping sort and organize the food pantry, and package the items for distribution to needy families. On Friday, volunteers do prep work for Saturday which is distribution day. Tasks may include, but are not limited to the following: Setting up Bagging perishables Cleaning Up What to bring? Gently used plastic trash bags for clients. This is not required but is certainly helpful. NOTE: To participate in this project you must be a Jersey Cares volunteer. To sign up as a Jersey Cares volunteer: 1. Visit www.jerseycares.org 2. Click on \"Log-In\" 3. Click on \"Not a Member? Register\" 4. Fill out all necessary information. 5. Register for a project!
07306.title: Marketplace in Jersey City

07306.description: GSECDC - Garden State Episcopal Community Development Corp., (which used to be called Jersey City Episcopal Community Development Corp.) is a multi-service organization serving very-low- and low-income, homeless, hungry, needy and/or special needs individuals and families, as well as aspiring first-time home-buyers. Our primary focus is to provide extensive supportive services for the Homeless, threough Intensive, individualized Case Management and Drop-In Centers. We also provide affordable housing paired with supportive services for Special Needs individuals and families, a Emergency Food Pantry and opportunities for Middle-Income First-Time Home-Buyers. Our Front-Desk Reception Volunteers are the voices and \"faces\" of this agency - the first person someone meets when they enter the door, the first voice they hear when they call up -- an \"Ambassador\" from GSECDC out to the world. We need help weekdays, daytimes, between 9am-4pm -- Mornings, Afternoons or All Day, one day a week or more, or a few times a month. We try to be as flexible as possible Answering the phone, greeting our needy Consumers and other visitors, responding to phone & visitor inquiries regarding our programs and services -- that and more -- make the time fly by! We provide you with lots of information & there are always staff nearby to answer questions! If you choose to also help get involved with our constant need for donations of Essential supplies to assist the Homeless, that's great, too - but your choice. We serve more and more very-low folks and families, so we need more and more help to do it all! We'd love to welcome you into our front-desk reception team!
07306.title: Be the Welcoming Face & Voice of our Homeless Services

07306.description: CASA volunteers are ordinary people - men and women, students and executives, retirees and busy professionals. We are looking for individuals with a desire to help children and a willingness to commit themselves to a foster child in need of the unique one-on-one attention of a CASA volunteer. The first step to becoming a volunteer is to attend an information session. Please join us for a half-hour to learn how you can make a difference in a foster child’s life. For more information or to RSVP for an information session, email Clare Daley at cdaley@hudsoncountycasa.org or visit our website www.hudsoncountycasa.org.
07306.title: Become a Volunteer Advocate for a Foster Child

11354.description: Status: Accepting Applications - Ongoing Project L.E.A.R.N - Adult Tutoring Program Are you seeking to develop your teaching skills for a career in education? Build your resume by completing volunteer service hours? Become more involved in your community or to simply share your love and knowledge of English? Then this volunteer opportunity is for you - learn more about how you can make a difference in the lives of victim-survivors of domestic violence today! How to Apply: Please send your resume to volunteer_associate@kafsc.org and complete our volunteer application form here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdmEp-K8bU7L-b4N2-EHLIfioD1vQ0c_Rb475CvBkKhAy2Dsw/viewform Please feel free to contact Carmen Wang, Volunteer Engagement Associate for any questions or concerns at volunteer_associate@kafsc.org or (718) 460-3801 ext. 36. Program Description The Self-Sufficiency Program at the Korean American Family Service Center (KAFSC) provides those who are affected by domestic violence basic job-readiness skills to enter today’s workforce and to gain employment. As part of our eight-week program to help clients become self-sufficient in their everyday life, our instructors teach English and Computer classes during the winter, fall, summer and spring semesters. Volunteers will provide one-on-one or group tutoring sessions to students who need help with homework, to learn the materials covered in class, or to practice and retain their knowledge. Also, tutors may develop their own or create new teaching lessons for students! Volunteer Title: English Tutor Summary of Position Provide one-on-one or group English lessons on grammar, pronunciation, spelling, everyday life phrases, and etc. Tutors will identify students’ specific needs and what they have to practice to gain English-proficiency. Ability to communicate clearly and slowly for students to understand is essential. Responsibilities Provides one-on-one or English group tutoring/conversations with 2-3 adult second-language learners in one setting. Follow-up with students who are currently taking English classes to help them review what they have learned in class or to catch up on their lessons. Track student progress to document what they have learned or need to work on in the next tutor session. You may develop your own instructional curriculum/materials to teach resume writing or job interview skills that may not be introduced to students in their classes. Create a safe learning experience for all students Required Qualifications Ability to keep ALL personal information that students shared with you confidential, such as their names and where they live (avoid sharing information with friends, family & social media) Trustworthy and respectful At least 21 years old or older with no criminal background Currently enrolled in college as a student OR have completed your bachelors/ master’s degree OR have two or more years of experience teaching English Attended our Volunteer Orientation Preferred Education/Skills: Bi-lingual in Korean and English is preferred, but not required College degree in English or TESOL is preferred, certification in ESL/ESOL is a plus Prior experience teaching adults or children Possesses a friendly demeanor and patience for students to learn at their own pace Able to communicate to students clearly so they understand your instructions Have a sense of empathy towards victims or individuals who have experienced trauma Schedule/Time Commitment Begins January until June 2017 (tentative dates) Commit at least four months of volunteer service Meet with students at least once a week for 45 minutes to 1 hour outside of classroom time when classes are in-session and during semester breaks Attend a bi-weekly meeting (10-20 minutes) with Volunteer Coordinator after tutor session. Have a flexible schedule; Monday to Fridays, 9:30 am to 4:30 pm OR be available for one weekday Location KAFSC Physical Address (Confidential) *A confidential agreement form must be signed before you can begin volunteering. Why Volunteer at KAFSC? *** By volunteering for at least four months at KAFSC, you are choosing to help our clients gain self-confidence, dignity, and economic self-sufficiency, so they no longer have to depend on their domestic violence abusers. Additionally, some benefits of volunteering for you include: Invitation to our annual Volunteer Appreciation Party, where you can meet and network with other staff and volunteers Add volunteer experience to your resume and gain new references Write a letter of recommendation for school or work Write a letter to confirm your hours of participation Presidential Award Service (PVSA) Certificates are awarded to those who are U.S. Citizens. *** References and letters are made available only upon request and only after you have completed at least four months of volunteer service. Thank you for your interest in volunteering at KAFSC! About KAFSC Founded in 1989, the Korean American Family Service Center (KAFSC) is a leading, nonprofit organization that supports and empowers adults, youth, and children to lead safe and healthy lives based on dignity, compassion and mutual respect. We are committed to preventing and ending domestic violence and relationship abuse, and creating a violence-free society. Our counseling, education and advocacy programs for individuals and families in the New York Tri-State area are provided in a culturally and linguistically appropriate setting. Through the historical merger with Rainbow Center of NY (aka Women in Need Center) in January 2014, KAFSC has increased capacity to add and provide an emergency shelter for women and children, the only-of-its-kind in the greater New York Korean community.
11354.title: English Tutor (Project L.E.A.R.N. - Adult Tutoring Program)

Tutors will assess whether a student is in the beginner, intermediate, or advanced level of computers and then teach according to their needs. Repetition and patience will allow our students to remember what they have learned. Responsibilities Provides one-on-one computer tutoring for adult students. Have a flexible schedule; Monday to Fridays, 9:30 am to 4:30 pm OR be available for at least one day of the week Location KAFSC Physical Address (Confidential) *A confidential agreement form must be signed before you can begin volunteering. Why Volunteer at KAFSC? *** By volunteering for at least four months at KAFSC, you are choosing to help our clients gain self-confidence, dignity, and economic self-sufficiency, so they no longer have to depend on their domestic violence abusers. Additionally, some benefits of volunteering for you include: Invitation to our annual Volunteer Appreciation Party, where you can meet and network with other staff and volunteers Add volunteer experience to your resume and gain new references Letter of recommendation for school or work Letter to confirm your hours of participation Presidential Award Service (PVSA) Certificates are awarded to those who are U.S. Citizens. *** References and letters are made available only upon request and only after you have completed at least four months of volunteer service. Thank you for your interest in volunteering at KAFSC! About KAFSC Founded in 1989, the Korean American Family Service Center (KAFSC) is a leading, nonprofit organization that supports and empowers adults, youth, and children to lead safe and healthy lives based on dignity, compassion and mutual respect. We are committed to preventing and ending domestic violence and relationship abuse, and creating a violence-free society. Our counseling, education and advocacy programs for individuals and families in the New York Tri-State area are provided in a culturally and linguistically appropriate setting. Through the historical merger with Rainbow Center of NY (aka Women in Need Center) in January 2014, KAFSC has increased capacity to add and provide an emergency shelter for women and children, the only-of-its-kind in the greater New York Korean community.
